<p about="#mwt18" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"pp-semi-indef","href":"./Template:Pp-semi-indef"},"params":{},"i":0}},"\n",{"template":{"target":{"wt":"pp-move-indef","href":"./Template:Pp-move-indef"},"params":{},"i":1}},"\n",{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Use mdy dates","href":"./Template:Use_mdy_dates"},"params":{"date":{"wt":"January 2022"}},"i":2}},"\n",{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Automatic taxobox\n","href":"./Template:Automatic_taxobox"},"params":{"name":{"wt":"Dinosaurs"},"fossil_range":{"wt":"{{fossilrange|233.23|0|[[Late Triassic]]–[[Holocene|Present]], 233.23 – 0 Mya | |earliest=245 |PS=(Range includes birds (Aves)) }} (Possible Middle Triassic record)"},"image":{"wt":"Dinosauria montage 2.jpg"},"image_upright":{"wt":"1.3"},"image_caption":{"wt":"A compilation of dinosaur skeletons. Clockwise from top left: &apos;&apos;[[Microraptor|Microraptor gui]]&apos;&apos; (a winged [[Theropoda|theropod]]), &apos;&apos;[[Apatosaurus|Apatosaurus louisae]]&apos;&apos; (a giant [[Sauropoda|sauropod]]), &apos;&apos;[[Edmontosaurus|Edmontosaurus regalis]]&apos;&apos; (a duck-billed [[Ornithopoda|ornithopod]]), &apos;&apos;[[Triceratops|Triceratops horridus]]&apos;&apos; (a horned [[ceratopsia]]n), &apos;&apos;[[Stegosaurus|Stegosaurus stenops]]&apos;&apos; (a plated [[Stegosauria|stegosaur]]), &apos;&apos;[[Pinacosaurus|Pinacosaurus grangeri]]&apos;&apos; (an armored [[Ankylosauria|ankylosaur]])"},"display_parents":{"wt":"7"},"taxon":{"wt":"Dinosauria"},"authority":{"wt":"[[Richard Owen|Owen]], 1842"},"subdivision_ranks":{"wt":"Major groups"},"subdivision":{"wt":"*{{extinct}}[[Ornithischia]]\n*{{extinct}}[[Sauropodomorpha]]\n*[[Theropoda]]\n**[[Aves]]\n{{Collapse top|title=Possible dinosaurs of uncertain affinity|left=yes|padding=0|border=0|border2=0|bg=clear|bg2=clear}}\n*{{extinct}}&apos;&apos;[[Alwalkeria]]&apos;&apos;?\n*{{extinct}}&apos;&apos;[[Chilesaurus]]&apos;&apos;\n*{{extinct}}&apos;&apos;[[Chindesaurus]]&apos;&apos;?\n*{{extinct}}&apos;&apos;[[Daemonosaurus]]&apos;&apos;?\n*{{extinct}}&apos;&apos;[[Eodromaeus]]&apos;&apos;?\n*{{extinct}}&apos;&apos;[[Nhandumirim]]&apos;&apos;\n*{{extinct}}&apos;&apos;[[Nyasasaurus]]&apos;&apos;?\n*{{extinct}}&apos;&apos;[[Pisanosaurus]]&apos;&apos;?\n*{{extinct}}&apos;&apos;[[Smok (archosaur)|Smok]]&apos;&apos;?\n*{{extinct}}&apos;&apos;[[Tawa hallae|Tawa]]&apos;&apos;?\n*{{extinct}}&apos;&apos;[[Thecospondylus]]&apos;&apos;\n*{{extinct}}[[Guaibasauridae]]?\n*{{extinct}}[[Herrerasauria]]?&lt;ref>Matthew G. Baron; Megan E. Williams (2018). \"A re-evaluation of the enigmatic dinosauriform Caseosaurus crosbyensis from the Late Triassic of Texas, USA and its implications for early dinosaur evolution\". <td colspan="2" style="text-align: center; font-size: 88%">A compilation of dinosaur skeletons. <li><abbr title="Extinct" aria-label="Extinct" style="border: none; text-decoration: none; cursor: inherit; font-weight: normal; font-style: normal;">†</abbr><i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thecospondylus" title="Thecospondylus">Thecospondylus</a></i></li>
<li><abbr title="Extinct" aria-label="Extinct" style="border: none; text-decoration: none; cursor: inherit; font-weight: normal; font-style: normal;">†</abbr><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Guaibasauridae" title="Guaibasauridae">Guaibasauridae</a>?</li>
<li><abbr title="Extinct" aria-label="Extinct" style="border: none; text-decoration: none; cursor: inherit; font-weight: normal; font-style: normal;">†</abbr><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Herrerasauria" title="Herrerasauria" class="mw-redirect">Herrerasauria</a>?<sup about="#mwt29" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-1"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-1" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 1;" id="mwBw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCA">[1]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt33" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-2"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-2" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 2;" id="mwCQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCg">[2]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><abbr title="Extinct" aria-label="Extinct" style="border: none; text-decoration: none; cursor: inherit; font-weight: normal; font-style: normal;">†</abbr><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Silesauridae" title="Silesauridae">Silesauridae</a>? <small>(<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paraphyletic" title="Paraphyletic" class="mw-redirect">paraphyletic</a>?)</small><sup about="#mwt37" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-3" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-3"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-3" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 3;" id="mwCw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwDA">[3]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt41" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-4" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-4"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-4" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 4;" id="mwDQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwDg">[4]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt45" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-cabreira2016_5-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"cabreira2016"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-cabreira2016-5"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-cabreira2016-5" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 5;" id="mwDw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwEA">[5]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt49" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-6" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-6"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-6" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 6;" id="mwEQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwEg">[6]</span></a></sup></li></ul></td></tr>
</tbody></table></div></td></tr>

















</tbody></table><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_with_'species'_microformats" about="#mwt18" id="mwEw"/>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwFA"><a href="./File:Neognathae.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwFQ"><img alt="montage of four birds" resource="./File:Neognathae.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Neognathae.jpg/220px-Neognathae.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="968" data-file-type="bitmap" height="213" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Neognathae.jpg/330px-Neognathae.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Neognathae.jpg/440px-Neognathae.jpg 2x" id="mwFg"/></a><figcaption id="mwFw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Birds" title="Birds" class="mw-redirect" id="mwGA">Birds</a> are avian dinosaurs, and in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Phylogenetics" title="Phylogenetics" id="mwGQ">phylogenetic</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Taxonomy_(biology)" title="Taxonomy (biology)" id="mwGg">taxonomy</a> are included in the group Dinosauria.</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwGw"><b id="mwHA">Dinosaurs</b> are<!-- Please use "are", as the scientific consensus is that birds are also dinosaurs themselves. --> a diverse group of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Reptile" title="Reptile" id="mwHQ">reptiles</a><sup about="#mwt50" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-cold-blooded_7-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Transclusion mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"refn","href":"./Template:Refn"},"params":{"group":{"wt":"note"},"name":{"wt":"cold-blooded"},"1":{"wt":"Dinosaurs (including birds) are members of the [[clade|natural group]] [[Reptilia]]. Their biology does not precisely correspond to the antiquated [[Class (biology)|class]] Reptilia of [[Linnaean taxonomy]], consisting of [[Ectotherm|cold-blooded]] [[amniote]]s without fur or feathers. As Linnean taxonomy was formulated for modern animals prior to the study of evolution and paleontology, it fails to account for extinct animals with intermediate traits between traditional classes."}},"i":0}}]}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-cold-blooded-7" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 1;" data-mw-group="note" id="mwHg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwHw">[note 1]</span></a></sup> of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Clade" title="Clade" id="mwIA">clade</a> <b id="mwIQ">Dinosauria</b>. They first appeared during the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Triassic" title="Triassic" id="mwIg">Triassic</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geological_period" title="Geological period" class="mw-redirect" id="mwIw">period</a>, between 245 and 233.23<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwJA"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Million_years_ago" title="Million years ago" class="mw-redirect" id="mwJQ">million years ago</a> (mya), although the exact origin and timing of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dinosaur#Evolutionary_history" id="mwJg">evolution of dinosaurs</a> is a subject of active research. They became the dominant terrestrial <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vertebrate" title="Vertebrate" id="mwJw">vertebrates</a> after the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Triassic–Jurassic_extinction_event" title="Triassic–Jurassic extinction event" id="mwKA">Triassic–Jurassic extinction event</a> 201.3<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwKQ"> </span>mya and their dominance continued throughout the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jurassic" title="Jurassic" id="mwKg">Jurassic</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cretaceous" title="Cretaceous" id="mwKw">Cretaceous</a> periods. The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fossil" title="Fossil" id="mwLA">fossil</a> record shows that <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bird" title="Bird" id="mwLQ">birds</a> are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feathered_dinosaur" title="Feathered dinosaur" id="mwLg">feathered dinosaurs</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Evolution_of_birds" title="Evolution of birds" id="mwLw">having evolved</a> from earlier <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Theropoda" title="Theropoda" id="mwMA">theropods</a> during the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Late_Jurassic" title="Late Jurassic" id="mwMQ">Late Jurassic</a> epoch, and are the only dinosaur lineage known to have survived the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cretaceous–Paleogene_extinction_event" title="Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event" id="mwMg">Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event</a> approximately 66<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwMw"> </span>mya. Dinosaurs can therefore be divided into <b id="mwNA">avian dinosaurs</b>—birds—and the extinct <b id="mwNQ">non-avian dinosaurs</b>, which are all dinosaurs other than birds.</p>

<p id="mwNg">Dinosaurs are varied from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Taxonomy_(biology)" title="Taxonomy (biology)" id="mwNw">taxonomic</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Morphology_(biology)" title="Morphology (biology)" id="mwOA">morphological</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ecological" title="Ecological" class="mw-redirect" id="mwOQ">ecological</a> standpoints. Birds, at over 10,700 living <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Species" title="Species" id="mwOg">species</a>, are among the most diverse groups of vertebrates. Using fossil evidence, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paleontologists" title="Paleontologists" class="mw-redirect" id="mwOw">paleontologists</a> have identified over 900 distinct <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Genera" title="Genera" class="mw-redirect" id="mwPA">genera</a> and more than 1,000 different species of non-avian dinosaurs. Dinosaurs are represented on every continent by both <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neontology" title="Neontology" id="mwPQ">extant</a> species (birds) and fossil remains. Through the first half of the 20th century, before birds were recognized as dinosaurs, most of the scientific community believed dinosaurs to have been sluggish and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Poikilotherm" title="Poikilotherm" id="mwPg">cold-blooded</a>. Most <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dinosaur_renaissance" title="Dinosaur renaissance" id="mwPw">research conducted since the 1970s</a>, however, has indicated that dinosaurs were active animals with elevated <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Metabolism" title="Metabolism" id="mwQA">metabolisms</a> and numerous adaptations for social interaction. Some were <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Herbivorous" title="Herbivorous" class="mw-redirect" id="mwQQ">herbivorous</a>, others <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnivorous" title="Carnivorous" class="mw-redirect" id="mwQg">carnivorous</a>. Evidence suggests that all dinosaurs were <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Egg-laying" title="Egg-laying" class="mw-redirect" id="mwQw">egg-laying</a>, and that <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nest" title="Nest" id="mwRA">nest</a>-building was a trait shared by many dinosaurs, both avian and non-avian.</p>

<p id="mwRQ">While dinosaurs were ancestrally <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bipedal" title="Bipedal" class="mw-redirect" id="mwRg">bipedal</a>, many <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Extinct" title="Extinct" class="mw-redirect" id="mwRw">extinct</a> groups included <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Quadrupedal" title="Quadrupedal" class="mw-redirect" id="mwSA">quadrupedal</a> species, and some were able to shift between these stances. Elaborate display structures such as horns or crests are common to all dinosaur groups, and some extinct groups developed <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Skeletal" title="Skeletal" class="mw-redirect" id="mwSQ">skeletal</a> modifications such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Armour_(anatomy)" title="Armour (anatomy)" id="mwSg">bony armor</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spine_(zoology)" title="Spine (zoology)" id="mwSw">spines</a>. While the dinosaurs' modern-day surviving avian lineage (birds) are generally small due to the constraints of flight, many prehistoric dinosaurs (non-avian and avian) were large-bodied—the largest <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sauropoda" title="Sauropoda" id="mwTA">sauropod</a> dinosaurs are estimated to have reached lengths of <span about="#mwt53" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"39.7"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"abbr":{"wt":"off"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwTQ">39.7 meters (130 feet)</span> and heights of <span about="#mwt54" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"18"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwTg">18</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt54"> </span><span about="#mwt54">m (59</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt54"> </span><span about="#mwt54">ft)</span> and were the largest land animals of all time. The misconception that non-avian dinosaurs were uniformly gigantic is based in part on <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Taphonomy" title="Taphonomy" id="mwTw">preservation bias</a>, as large, sturdy <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bone" title="Bone" id="mwUA">bones</a> are more likely to last until they are fossilized. Many dinosaurs were quite small, some measuring about <span about="#mwt55" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"50"},"2":{"wt":"cm"},"3":{"wt":"in"},"abbr":{"wt":"off"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwUQ">50 centimeters (20 inches)</span> in length.</p>

<p id="mwUg">The first dinosaur fossils were recognized in the early 19th century, with the name "dinosaur" (meaning "terrible lizard") being coined by Sir <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Richard_Owen" title="Richard Owen" id="mwUw">Richard Owen</a> in 1841 to refer to these "great fossil lizards". Since then, mounted fossil dinosaur skeletons have been major attractions at museums worldwide, and dinosaurs have become an enduring part of popular culture. The large sizes of some dinosaurs, as well as their seemingly monstrous and fantastic nature, have ensured their regular appearance in best-selling books and films, such as <i id="mwVA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jurassic_Park" title="Jurassic Park" id="mwVQ">Jurassic Park</a></i>. Persistent public enthusiasm for the animals has resulted in significant funding for dinosaur science, and new discoveries are regularly covered by the media.</p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="1" id="mwVg"><h2 id="Definition">Definition</h2>
<p id="mwVw">Under <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Phylogenetic_nomenclature" title="Phylogenetic nomenclature" id="mwWA">phylogenetic nomenclature</a>, dinosaurs are usually defined as the group consisting of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Most_recent_common_ancestor" title="Most recent common ancestor" id="mwWQ">most recent common ancestor</a> (MRCA) of <i id="mwWg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Triceratops" title="Triceratops" id="mwWw">Triceratops</a></i> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bird#Diversification_of_modern_birds" title="Bird" id="mwXA">modern birds</a> (Neornithes), and all its descendants.<sup about="#mwt59" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MJB04dino_8-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MJB04dino"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-MJB04dino-8" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 7;" id="mwXQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwXg">[7]</span></a></sup> It has also been suggested that Dinosauria be defined with respect to the MRCA of <i id="mwXw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Megalosaurus" title="Megalosaurus" id="mwYA">Megalosaurus</a></i> and <i id="mwYQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Iguanodon" title="Iguanodon" id="mwYg">Iguanodon</a></i>, because these were two of the three genera cited by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Richard_Owen" title="Richard Owen" id="mwYw">Richard Owen</a> when he recognized the Dinosauria.<sup about="#mwt60" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-olshevsky2000_9-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"olshevsky2000"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-olshevsky2000-9" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 8;" id="mwZA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwZQ">[8]</span></a></sup> Both definitions result in the same set of animals being defined as dinosaurs: "Dinosauria = <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ornithischia" title="Ornithischia" id="mwZg">Ornithischia</a> + <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Saurischia" title="Saurischia" id="mwZw">Saurischia</a>". This definition includes major groups such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ankylosauria" title="Ankylosauria" id="mwaA">ankylosaurians</a> (armored herbivorous quadrupeds), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stegosauria" title="Stegosauria" id="mwaQ">stegosaurians</a> (plated herbivorous quadrupeds), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ceratopsia" title="Ceratopsia" id="mwag">ceratopsians</a> (bipedal or quadrupedal herbivores with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neck_frill" title="Neck frill" id="mwaw">neck frills</a>), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pachycephalosauria" title="Pachycephalosauria" id="mwbA">pachycephalosaurians</a> (bipedal herbivores with thick skulls), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ornithopoda" title="Ornithopoda" id="mwbQ">ornithopods</a> (bipedal or quadrupedal herbivores including "<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hadrosauridae" title="Hadrosauridae" id="mwbg">duck-bills</a>"), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Theropoda" title="Theropoda" id="mwbw">theropods</a> (mostly bipedal carnivores and birds), and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sauropodomorpha" title="Sauropodomorpha" id="mwcA">sauropodomorphs</a> (mostly large herbivorous quadrupeds with long necks and tails).<sup about="#mwt61" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Letal05_10-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Letal05"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Letal05-10" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 9;" id="mwcQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwcg">[9]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwcw">Birds are now recognized as being the sole surviving lineage of theropod dinosaurs. In traditional <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Taxonomy_(biology)" title="Taxonomy (biology)" id="mwdA">taxonomy</a>, birds were considered a separate <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Class_(biology)" title="Class (biology)" id="mwdQ">class</a> that had evolved from dinosaurs, a distinct <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Superorder" title="Superorder" class="mw-redirect" id="mwdg">superorder</a>. However, a majority of contemporary paleontologists concerned with dinosaurs reject the traditional style of classification in favor of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Phylogenetics" title="Phylogenetics" id="mwdw">phylogenetic</a> taxonomy; this approach requires that, for a group to be natural, all descendants of members of the group must be included in the group as well. Birds are thus considered to be dinosaurs and dinosaurs are, therefore, not extinct.<sup about="#mwt67" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-11" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-11"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-11" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 10;" id="mweA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mweQ">[10]</span></a></sup> Birds are classified as belonging to the subgroup <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Maniraptora" title="Maniraptora" id="mweg">Maniraptora</a>, which are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Coelurosauria" title="Coelurosauria" id="mwew">coelurosaurs</a>, which are theropods, which are saurischians, which are dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt68" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-KP04_12-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"KP04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-KP04-12" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 11;" id="mwfA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwfQ">[11]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwfg">Research by Matthew G. Baron, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./David_B._Norman" title="David B. Norman" id="mwfw">David B. Norman</a>, and Paul M. Barrett in 2017 suggested a radical revision of dinosaurian systematics. Phylogenetic analysis by Baron <i id="mwgA">et al.</i> recovered the Ornithischia as being closer to the Theropoda than the Sauropodomorpha, as opposed to the traditional union of theropods with sauropodomorphs. They resurrected the clade <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ornithoscelida" title="Ornithoscelida" id="mwgQ">Ornithoscelida</a> to refer to the group containing Ornithischia and Theropoda. Dinosauria itself was re-defined as the last common ancestor of <i id="mwgg">Triceratops horridus</i>, <i id="mwgw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./House_sparrow" title="House sparrow" id="mwhA">Passer domesticus</a></i> and <i id="mwhQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diplodocus" title="Diplodocus" id="mwhg">Diplodocus carnegii</a></i>, and all of its descendants, to ensure that sauropods and kin remain included as dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt74" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20170322_13-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NYT-20170322"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-NYT-20170322-13"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-NYT-20170322-13" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 12;" id="mwhw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwiA">[12]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt79" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NAT-20170322_14-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NAT-20170322"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-NAT-20170322-14"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-NAT-20170322-14" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 13;" id="mwiQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwig">[13]</span></a></sup></p>

<section data-mw-section-id="2" id="mwiw"><h3 id="General_description">General description</h3>
<figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwjA"><a href="./File:LA-Triceratops_mount-2.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwjQ"><img resource="./File:LA-Triceratops_mount-2.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/LA-Triceratops_mount-2.jpg/250px-LA-Triceratops_mount-2.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="4560" data-file-height="3460" data-file-type="bitmap" height="190" width="250" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/LA-Triceratops_mount-2.jpg/375px-LA-Triceratops_mount-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/LA-Triceratops_mount-2.jpg/500px-LA-Triceratops_mount-2.jpg 2x" id="mwjg"/></a><figcaption id="mwjw"><i id="mwkA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Triceratops" title="Triceratops" id="mwkQ">Triceratops</a></i> skeleton, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Natural_History_Museum_of_Los_Angeles_County" title="Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County" id="mwkg">Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County</a></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwkw">Using one of the above definitions, dinosaurs can be generally described as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Archosaur" title="Archosaur" id="mwlA">archosaurs</a> with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Terrestrial_locomotion#Posture" title="Terrestrial locomotion" id="mwlQ">hind limbs held erect beneath the body</a>.<sup about="#mwt83" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-DFG97_15-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"DFG97"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-DFG97-15" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 14;" id="mwlg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwlw">[14]</span></a></sup> Other prehistoric animals, including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pterosaur" title="Pterosaur" id="mwmA">pterosaurs</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mosasaur" title="Mosasaur" id="mwmQ">mosasaurs</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ichthyosaur" title="Ichthyosaur" id="mwmg">ichthyosaurs</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Plesiosauria" title="Plesiosauria" class="mw-redirect" id="mwmw">plesiosaurs</a>, and <i id="mwnA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dimetrodon" title="Dimetrodon" id="mwnQ">Dimetrodon</a></i>, while often popularly conceived of as dinosaurs, are not taxonomically classified as dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt87" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Forbes_16-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Forbes"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Forbes-16"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Forbes-16" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 15;" id="mwng"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwnw">[15]</span></a></sup> Pterosaurs are distantly related to dinosaurs, being members of the clade <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Avemetatarsalia" title="Avemetatarsalia" id="mwoA">Ornithodira</a>. The other groups mentioned are, like dinosaurs and pterosaurs, members of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sauropsida" title="Sauropsida" id="mwoQ">Sauropsida</a> (the reptile and bird clade), except <i id="mwog">Dimetrodon</i> (which is a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Synapsid" title="Synapsid" id="mwow">synapsid</a>). None of them had the erect hind limb posture characteristic of true dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt88" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-DL90_17-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"DL90"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-DL90-17" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 16;" id="mwpA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwpQ">[16]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwpg">Dinosaurs were the dominant terrestrial vertebrates of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mesozoic" title="Mesozoic" id="mwpw">Mesozoic</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Era" title="Era" id="mwqA">Era</a>, especially the Jurassic and Cretaceous periods. Other groups of animals were restricted in size and niches; <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammal" title="Mammal" id="mwqQ">mammals</a>, for example, rarely exceeded the size of a domestic cat, and were generally rodent-sized carnivores of small prey.<sup about="#mwt94" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MM97_18-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MM97"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-MM97-18" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 17;" id="mwqg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwqw">[17]</span></a></sup> They have always been recognized as an extremely varied group of animals; over 900 non-avian dinosaur genera have been identified with certainty as of 2018, and the total number of genera preserved in the fossil record has been estimated at around 1850, nearly 75% of which remain to be discovered, and 1124 species by 2016.<sup about="#mwt98" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Genera900_19-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Genera900"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Genera900-19"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Genera900-19" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 18;" id="mwrA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwrQ">[18]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt102" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Howmany_20-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Howmany"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Howmany-20"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Howmany-20" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 19;" id="mwrg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwrw">[19]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt103" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Wang&amp;Dodson_21-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Wang&amp;Dodson"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Wang&amp;Dodson-21" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 20;" id="mwsA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwsQ">[20]</span></a></sup> A 1995 study predicted that about 3,400 dinosaur genera ever existed, including many that would not have been preserved in the fossil record.<sup about="#mwt104" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-russell1995_22-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"russell1995"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-russell1995-22" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 21;" id="mwsg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwsw">[21]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwtA">In 2016, the estimated number of dinosaur species that existed in the Mesozoic was 1,543–2,468.<sup about="#mwt113" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-23" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-23"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-23" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 22;" id="mwtQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwtg">[22]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt117" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-24" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-24"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-24" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 23;" id="mwtw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwuA">[23]</span></a></sup> In 2021, the number of modern-day birds (avian dinosaurs) was estimated to be at 10,806 species.<sup about="#mwt121" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-25" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-25"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-25" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 24;" id="mwuQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwug">[24]</span></a></sup> Some are herbivorous, others carnivorous, including seed-eaters, fish-eaters, insectivores, and omnivores. While dinosaurs were ancestrally bipedal (as are all modern birds), some prehistoric species were quadrupeds, and others, such as <i id="mwuw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Anchisaurus" title="Anchisaurus" id="mwvA">Anchisaurus</a></i> and <i id="mwvQ">Iguanodon</i>, could walk just as easily on two or four legs. Cranial modifications like horns and crests are common dinosaurian traits, and some extinct species had bony armor. Although known for large size, many Mesozoic dinosaurs were human-sized or smaller, and modern birds are generally small in size. Dinosaurs today inhabit every continent, and fossils show that they had achieved global distribution by at least the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Early_Jurassic" title="Early Jurassic" id="mwvg">Early Jurassic</a> epoch.<sup about="#mwt125" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MacLeod_26-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MacLeod"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-MacLeod-26"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-MacLeod-26" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 25;" id="mwvw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwwA">[25]</span></a></sup> Modern birds inhabit most available habitats, from terrestrial to marine, and there is evidence that some non-avian dinosaurs (such as <i id="mwwQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Microraptor" title="Microraptor" id="mwwg">Microraptor</a></i>) could fly or at least glide, and others, such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spinosauridae" title="Spinosauridae" id="mwww">spinosaurids</a>, had <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Semiaquatic" title="Semiaquatic" id="mwxA">semiaquatic</a> habits.<sup about="#mwt126" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-theropods_27-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"theropods"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-theropods-27" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 26;" id="mwxQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwxg">[26]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="3" id="mwxw"><h3 id="Distinguishing_anatomical_features">Distinguishing anatomical features</h3>
<p id="mwyA">While recent discoveries have made it more difficult to present a universally agreed-upon list of their distinguishing features, nearly all dinosaurs discovered so far share certain modifications to the ancestral archosaurian skeleton, or are clearly descendants of older dinosaurs showing these modifications. Although some later groups of dinosaurs featured further modified versions of these traits, they are considered typical for Dinosauria; the earliest dinosaurs had them and passed them on to their descendants. Such modifications, originating in the most recent common ancestor of a certain taxonomic group, are called the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Synapomorphy_and_apomorphy" title="Synapomorphy and apomorphy" class="mw-redirect" id="mwyQ">synapomorphies</a> of such a group.<sup about="#mwt128" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-B012_28-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"B012"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-B012-28" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 27;" id="mwyg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwyw">[27]</span></a></sup></p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwzA"><a href="./File:Dromaeosaurus_skull_en.svg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwzQ"><img resource="./File:Dromaeosaurus_skull_en.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Dromaeosaurus_skull_en.svg/220px-Dromaeosaurus_skull_en.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="680" data-file-height="400" data-file-type="drawing" height="129" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Dromaeosaurus_skull_en.svg/330px-Dromaeosaurus_skull_en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Dromaeosaurus_skull_en.svg/440px-Dromaeosaurus_skull_en.svg.png 2x" id="mwzg"/></a><figcaption id="mwzw">Labeled diagram of a typical archosaur skull, the skull of <i id="mw0A"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dromaeosaurus" title="Dromaeosaurus" id="mw0Q">Dromaeosaurus</a></i></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mw0g">A detailed assessment of archosaur interrelations by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sterling_Nesbitt" title="Sterling Nesbitt" id="mw0w">Sterling Nesbitt</a><sup about="#mwt130" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-nesbitt2011_29-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"nesbitt2011"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-nesbitt2011-29" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 28;" id="mw1A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw1Q">[28]</span></a></sup> confirmed or found the following twelve unambiguous synapomorphies, some previously known:</p>
<ul id="mw1g"><li id="mw1w">In the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Skull" title="Skull" id="mw2A">skull</a>, a supratemporal fossa (excavation) is present in front of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Skull#Structure" title="Skull" id="mw2Q">supratemporal fenestra</a>, the main opening in the rear skull roof</li>
<li id="mw2g"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Epipophyses" title="Epipophyses" id="mw2w">Epipophyses</a>, obliquely backward-pointing processes on the rear top corners of the anterior (front) neck <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vertebra" title="Vertebra" id="mw3A">vertebrae</a> behind the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Atlas_(anatomy)" title="Atlas (anatomy)" id="mw3Q">atlas</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Axis_(anatomy)" title="Axis (anatomy)" id="mw3g">axis</a>, the first two neck vertebrae</li>
<li id="mw3w">Apex of a deltopectoral crest (a projection on which the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Clavipectoral_triangle" title="Clavipectoral triangle" id="mw4A">deltopectoral</a> muscles attach) located at or more than 30% down the length of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Humerus" title="Humerus" id="mw4Q">humerus</a> (upper arm bone)</li>
<li id="mw4g"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Radius_(bone)" title="Radius (bone)" id="mw4w">Radius</a>, a lower arm bone, shorter than 80% of humerus length</li>
<li id="mw5A"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fourth_trochanter" title="Fourth trochanter" id="mw5Q">Fourth trochanter</a> (projection where the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Caudofemoralis" title="Caudofemoralis" id="mw5g">caudofemoralis</a> muscle attaches on the inner rear shaft) on the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Femur" title="Femur" id="mw5w">femur</a> (thigh bone) is a sharp flange</li>
<li id="mw6A">Fourth trochanter asymmetrical, with distal, lower, margin forming a steeper angle to the shaft</li>
<li id="mw6Q">On the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Talus_bone" title="Talus bone" id="mw6g">astragalus</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Calcaneus" title="Calcaneus" id="mw6w">calcaneum</a>, upper ankle bones, the proximal articular facet, the top connecting surface, for the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fibula" title="Fibula" id="mw7A">fibula</a> occupies less than 30% of the transverse width of the element</li>
<li id="mw7Q">Exoccipitals (bones at the back of the skull) do not meet along the midline on the floor of the endocranial cavity, the inner space of the braincase</li>
<li id="mw7g">In the pelvis, the proximal articular surfaces of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ischium" title="Ischium" id="mw7w">ischium</a> with the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ilium_(bone)" title="Ilium (bone)" id="mw8A">ilium</a> and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pubis_(bone)" title="Pubis (bone)" id="mw8Q">pubis</a> are separated by a large concave surface (on the upper side of the ischium a part of the open hip joint is located between the contacts with the pubic bone and the ilium)</li>
<li id="mw8g"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cnemial_crest" title="Cnemial crest" id="mw8w">Cnemial crest</a> on the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tibia" title="Tibia" id="mw9A">tibia</a> (protruding part of the top surface of the shinbone) arcs anterolaterally (curves to the front and the outer side)</li>
<li id="mw9Q">Distinct proximodistally oriented (vertical) ridge present on the posterior face of the distal end of the tibia (the rear surface of the lower end of the shinbone)</li>
<li id="mw9g">Concave articular surface for the fibula of the calcaneum (the top surface of the calcaneum, where it touches the fibula, has a hollow profile)</li></ul>

<p id="mw9w">Nesbitt found a number of further potential synapomorphies and discounted a number of synapomorphies previously suggested. Some of these are also present in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Silesauridae" title="Silesauridae" id="mw-A">silesaurids</a>, which Nesbitt recovered as a sister group to Dinosauria, including a large anterior trochanter, metatarsals II and IV of subequal length, reduced contact between ischium and pubis, the presence of a cnemial crest on the tibia and of an ascending process on the astragalus, and many others.<sup about="#mwt132" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MJB04dino_8-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MJB04dino"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-MJB04dino-8" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 7;" id="mw-Q"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mw-g">[7]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mw-w"><a href="./File:Sprawling_and_erect_hip_joints_-_horizontal.svg" class="mw-file-description" id="mw_A"><img resource="./File:Sprawling_and_erect_hip_joints_-_horizontal.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Sprawling_and_erect_hip_joints_-_horizontal.svg/220px-Sprawling_and_erect_hip_joints_-_horizontal.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="492" data-file-height="218" data-file-type="drawing" height="97" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Sprawling_and_erect_hip_joints_-_horizontal.svg/330px-Sprawling_and_erect_hip_joints_-_horizontal.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Sprawling_and_erect_hip_joints_-_horizontal.svg/440px-Sprawling_and_erect_hip_joints_-_horizontal.svg.png 2x" id="mw_Q"/></a><figcaption id="mw_g">Hip joints and hindlimb postures of: (left to right) typical <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Reptile" title="Reptile" id="mw_w">reptiles</a> (sprawling), dinosaurs and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mammal" title="Mammal" id="mwAQA">mammals</a> (erect), and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rauisuchia" title="Rauisuchia" id="mwAQE">rauisuchians</a> (pillar-erect)</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwAQI">A variety of other skeletal features are shared by dinosaurs. However, because they are either common to other groups of archosaurs or were not present in all early dinosaurs, these features are not considered to be synapomorphies. For example, as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diapsid" title="Diapsid" id="mwAQM">diapsids</a>, dinosaurs ancestrally had two pairs of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Infratemporal_fenestra" title="Infratemporal fenestra" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAQQ">Infratemporal fenestrae</a> (openings in the skull behind the eyes), and as members of the diapsid group Archosauria, had additional openings in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antorbital_fenestra" title="Antorbital fenestra" id="mwAQU">snout</a> and lower jaw.<sup about="#mwt138" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-TRHJ00_30-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"TRHJ00"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-TRHJ00-30" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 29;" id="mwAQY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAQc">[29]</span></a></sup> Additionally, several characteristics once thought to be synapomorphies are now known to have appeared before dinosaurs, or were absent in the earliest dinosaurs and independently evolved by different dinosaur groups. These include an elongated <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scapula" title="Scapula" id="mwAQg">scapula</a>, or shoulder blade; a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sacrum" title="Sacrum" id="mwAQk">sacrum</a> composed of three or more fused vertebrae (three are found in some other archosaurs, but only two are found in <i id="mwAQo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Herrerasaurus" title="Herrerasaurus" id="mwAQs">Herrerasaurus</a></i>);<sup about="#mwt139" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MJB04dino_8-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MJB04dino"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-MJB04dino-8" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 7;" id="mwAQw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAQ0">[7]</span></a></sup> and a perforate <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Acetabulum" title="Acetabulum" id="mwAQ4">acetabulum</a>, or hip socket, with a hole at the center of its inside surface (closed in <i id="mwAQ8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Saturnalia_tupiniquim" title="Saturnalia tupiniquim" id="mwARA">Saturnalia tupiniquim</a></i>, for example).<sup about="#mwt143" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-UC_Berkeley_Journal_of_Earth_Sciences_31-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"UC Berkeley Journal of Earth Sciences"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-UC_Berkeley_Journal_of_Earth_Sciences-31"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-UC_Berkeley_Journal_of_Earth_Sciences-31" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 30;" id="mwARE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwARI">[30]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt144" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-LARB99_32-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"LARB99"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-LARB99-32" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 31;" id="mwARM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwARQ">[31]</span></a></sup> Another difficulty of determining distinctly dinosaurian features is that early dinosaurs and other archosaurs from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Late_Triassic" title="Late Triassic" id="mwARU">Late Triassic</a> epoch are often poorly known and were similar in many ways; these animals have sometimes been misidentified in the literature.<sup about="#mwt145" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NIP07_33-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NIP07"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-NIP07-33" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 32;" id="mwARY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwARc">[32]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwARg">Dinosaurs stand with their hind limbs erect in a manner similar to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Evolution_of_mammals#Erect_limbs" title="Evolution of mammals" id="mwARk">most modern mammals</a>, but distinct from most other reptiles, whose limbs sprawl out to either side.<sup about="#mwt151" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Holland1909_34-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Holland1909"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Holland1909-34" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 33;" id="mwARo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwARs">[33]</span></a></sup> This posture is due to the development of a laterally facing recess in the pelvis (usually an open socket) and a corresponding inwardly facing distinct head on the femur.<sup about="#mwt152" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MJB00_35-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MJB00"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-MJB00-35" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 34;" id="mwARw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAR0">[34]</span></a></sup> Their erect posture enabled early dinosaurs to breathe easily while moving, which likely permitted stamina and activity levels that <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carrier's_constraint" title="Carrier's constraint" id="mwAR4">surpassed those of "sprawling" reptiles</a>.<sup about="#mwt153" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-RC05_36-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"RC05"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-RC05-36" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 35;" id="mwAR8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwASA">[35]</span></a></sup> Erect limbs probably also helped support the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Evolution" title="Evolution" id="mwASE">evolution</a> of large size by reducing bending stresses on limbs.<sup about="#mwt154" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-TKMB07_37-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"TKMB07"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-TKMB07-37" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 36;" id="mwASI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwASM">[36]</span></a></sup> Some non-dinosaurian archosaurs, including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rauisuchia" title="Rauisuchia" id="mwASQ">rauisuchians</a>, also had erect limbs but achieved this by a "pillar-erect" configuration of the hip joint, where instead of having a projection from the femur insert on a socket on the hip, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ilium_(bone)" title="Ilium (bone)" id="mwASU">upper pelvic bone</a> was rotated to form an overhanging shelf.<sup about="#mwt155" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-TKMB07_37-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"TKMB07"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-TKMB07-37" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 36;" id="mwASY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwASc">[36]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="4" id="mwASg"><h2 id="History_of_study">History of study</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt156" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Further","href":"./Template:Further"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"History of paleontology"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwASk"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt156" id="mwASo">Further information: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./History_of_paleontology" title="History of paleontology">History of paleontology</a></div>

<section data-mw-section-id="5" id="mwASs"><h3 id="Pre-scientific_history">Pre-scientific history</h3>
<p id="mwASw">Dinosaur fossils have been known for millennia, although their true nature was not recognized. The Chinese considered them to be <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chinese_dragon" title="Chinese dragon" id="mwAS0">dragon</a> bones and documented them as such. For example, <i id="mwAS4"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chronicles_of_Huayang" title="Chronicles of Huayang" id="mwAS8">Huayang Guo Zhi</a></i><span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwATA"> </span>(<span lang="zh-Hant" about="#mwt162" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"zh","href":"./Template:Zh"},"params":{"t":{"wt":"華陽國志"},"labels":{"wt":"no"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwATE"><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_traditional_Chinese-language_text"/>華陽國志</span>), a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gazetteer" title="Gazetteer" id="mwATI">gazetteer</a> compiled by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chang_Qu" title="Chang Qu" id="mwATM">Chang Qu</a><span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwATQ"> </span>(<span lang="zh-Hant" about="#mwt163" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"zh","href":"./Template:Zh"},"params":{"t":{"wt":"常璩"},"labels":{"wt":"no"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwATU"><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_traditional_Chinese-language_text"/>常璩</span>) during the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jin_dynasty_(266–420)" title="Jin dynasty (266–420)" id="mwATY">Western Jin Dynasty</a> (265–316), reported the discovery of dragon bones at Wucheng in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sichuan" title="Sichuan" id="mwATc">Sichuan</a> Province.<sup about="#mwt164" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-dong1992_38-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"dong1992"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-dong1992-38" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 37;" id="mwATg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwATk">[37]</span></a></sup> Villagers in central <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./China" title="China" id="mwATo">China</a> have long unearthed fossilized "dragon bones" for use in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Traditional_Chinese_medicine" title="Traditional Chinese medicine" id="mwATs">traditional medicines</a>.<sup about="#mwt165" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-BBCdinobonemed_39-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"BBCdinobonemed"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-BBCdinobonemed-39" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 38;" id="mwATw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAT0">[38]</span></a></sup> In <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Europe" title="Europe" id="mwAT4">Europe</a>, dinosaur fossils were generally believed to be the remains of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Giant" title="Giant" id="mwAT8">giants</a> and other <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bible" title="Bible" id="mwAUA">biblical</a> creatures.<sup about="#mwt167" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-benton2000_40-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"benton2000"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-benton2000-40"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-benton2000-40" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 39;" id="mwAUE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAUI">[39]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="6" id="mwAUM"><h3 id="Early_dinosaur_research">Early dinosaur research</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAUQ"><a href="./File:William_Buckland_detail.png" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAUU"><img resource="./File:William_Buckland_detail.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/2b/William_Buckland_detail.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="130" data-file-height="160" data-file-type="bitmap" height="160" width="130" id="mwAUY"/></a><figcaption id="mwAUc"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./William_Buckland" title="William Buckland" id="mwAUg">William Buckland</a></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwAUk">Scholarly descriptions of what would now be recognized as dinosaur bones first appeared in the late 17th century in England. Part of a bone, now known to have been the femur of a <i id="mwAUo">Megalosaurus</i>,<sup about="#mwt175" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-WAS97_41-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"WAS97"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-WAS97-41" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 40;" id="mwAUs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAUw">[40]</span></a></sup> was recovered from a limestone quarry at <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cornwell,_Oxfordshire" title="Cornwell, Oxfordshire" id="mwAU0">Cornwell</a> near <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chipping_Norton" title="Chipping Norton" id="mwAU4">Chipping Norton</a>, Oxfordshire, in 1676. The fragment was sent to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Robert_Plot" title="Robert Plot" id="mwAU8">Robert Plot</a>, Professor of Chemistry at the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./University_of_Oxford" title="University of Oxford" id="mwAVA">University of Oxford</a> and first curator of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ashmolean_Museum" title="Ashmolean Museum" id="mwAVE">Ashmolean Museum</a>, who published a description in his <i id="mwAVI">The Natural History of Oxford-shire</i> (1677).<sup about="#mwt177" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-42" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-42"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-42" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 41;" id="mwAVM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAVQ">[41]</span></a></sup> He correctly identified the bone as the lower extremity of the femur of a large animal, and recognized that it was too large to belong to any known species. He, therefore, concluded it to be the femur of a huge human, perhaps a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Titan_(mythology)" title="Titan (mythology)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAVU">Titan</a> or another type of giant featured in legends.<sup about="#mwt179" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-43" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-43"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-43" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 42;" id="mwAVY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAVc">[42]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt183" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-44" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-44"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-44" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 43;" id="mwAVg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAVk">[43]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Edward_Lhuyd" title="Edward Lhuyd" id="mwAVo">Edward Lhuyd</a>, a friend of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Isaac_Newton" title="Isaac Newton" id="mwAVs">Sir Isaac Newton</a>, published <i id="mwAVw">Lithophylacii Britannici ichnographia</i> (1699), the first scientific treatment of what would now be recognized as a dinosaur when he described and named a sauropod <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tooth" title="Tooth" id="mwAV0">tooth</a>, "<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rutellum" title="Rutellum" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAV4">Rutellum impicatum</a>",<sup about="#mwt184" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-L99_45-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"L99"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-L99-45" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 44;" id="mwAV8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAWA">[44]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt185" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-DS02_46-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"DS02"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-DS02-46" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 45;" id="mwAWE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAWI">[45]</span></a></sup> that had been found in Caswell, near <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Witney" title="Witney" id="mwAWM">Witney</a>, Oxfordshire.<sup about="#mwt186" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-G45_47-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"G45"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-G45-47" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 46;" id="mwAWQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAWU">[46]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAWY"><a href="./File:Dinosaur_coining_of_the_word_in_1841.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAWc"><img resource="./File:Dinosaur_coining_of_the_word_in_1841.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Dinosaur_coining_of_the_word_in_1841.jpg/220px-Dinosaur_coining_of_the_word_in_1841.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1687" data-file-height="1571" data-file-type="bitmap" height="205" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Dinosaur_coining_of_the_word_in_1841.jpg/330px-Dinosaur_coining_of_the_word_in_1841.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Dinosaur_coining_of_the_word_in_1841.jpg/440px-Dinosaur_coining_of_the_word_in_1841.jpg 2x" id="mwAWg"/></a><figcaption id="mwAWk"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Richard_Owen" title="Richard Owen" id="mwAWo">Sir Richard Owen's</a> coining of the word <i id="mwAWs">dinosaur</i>, at a meeting of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./British_Science_Association" title="British Science Association" id="mwAWw">British Association for the Advancement of Science</a> in 1841</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwAW0">Between 1815 and 1824, the Rev <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./William_Buckland" title="William Buckland" id="mwAW4">William Buckland</a>, the first Reader of Geology at the University of Oxford, collected more fossilized bones of <i id="mwAW8">Megalosaurus</i> and became the first person to describe a non-avian dinosaur in a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scientific_journal" title="Scientific journal" id="mwAXA">scientific journal</a>.<sup about="#mwt191" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-WAS97_41-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"WAS97"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-WAS97-41" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 40;" id="mwAXE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAXI">[40]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt192" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-buckland1824_48-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"buckland1824"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-buckland1824-48" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 47;" id="mwAXM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAXQ">[47]</span></a></sup> The second non-avian dinosaur genus to be identified, <i id="mwAXU">Iguanodon</i>, was discovered in 1822 by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mary_Ann_Mantell" title="Mary Ann Mantell" id="mwAXY">Mary Ann Mantell</a><span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAXc"> </span>– the wife of English geologist <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gideon_Mantell" title="Gideon Mantell" id="mwAXg">Gideon Mantell</a>. Gideon Mantell recognized similarities between his fossils and the bones of modern <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Iguana" title="Iguana" id="mwAXk">iguanas</a>. He published his findings in 1825.<sup about="#mwt193" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-GM25_49-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"GM25"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-GM25-49" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 48;" id="mwAXo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAXs">[48]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt194" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-HDS97_50-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"HDS97"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-HDS97-50" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 49;" id="mwAXw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAX0">[49]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAX4">The study of these "great fossil lizards" soon became of great interest to European and American scientists, and in 1841 the English paleontologist Sir Richard Owen coined the term "dinosaur", using it to refer to the "distinct tribe or sub-order of Saurian Reptiles" that were then being recognized in England and around the world.<sup about="#mwt202" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Owen1841_51-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Owen1841"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Owen1841-51" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 50;" id="mwAX8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAYA">[50]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt206" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-52" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-52"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-52" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 51;" id="mwAYE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAYI">[51]</span></a></sup> The term is derived <span about="#mwt201" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"ety","href":"./Template:Ety"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"grc"},"2":{"wt":"&apos;&apos;[[wikt:δεινός|δεινός]]&apos;&apos; (deinos)"},"3":{"wt":"terrible, potent or fearfully great"},"4":{"wt":""},"5":{"wt":"&apos;&apos;[[wikt:σαῦρος|σαῦρος]]&apos;&apos; (sauros)"},"6":{"wt":"lizard or reptile"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAYM">from</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt201"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ancient_Greek_language" title="Ancient Greek language" about="#mwt201" class="mw-redirect">Ancient Greek</a><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt201"> </span><i about="#mwt201"> </i><a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/δεινός" title="wikt:δεινός" about="#mwt201" class="extiw">δεινός</a><i about="#mwt201"> (deinos)</i><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt201"> </span><span about="#mwt201">'terrible, potent or fearfully great',</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt201"> </span><span about="#mwt201">and</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt201"> </span><i about="#mwt201"> </i><a rel="mw:WikiLink/Interwiki" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/σαῦρος" title="wikt:σαῦρος" about="#mwt201" class="extiw">σαῦρος</a><i about="#mwt201"> (sauros)</i><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt201"> </span><span about="#mwt201">'lizard or reptile'</span>.<sup about="#mwt207" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Owen1841_51-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Owen1841"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Owen1841-51" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 50;" id="mwAYQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAYU">[50]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt208" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-LSJ_53-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"LSJ"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-LSJ-53" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 52;" id="mwAYY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAYc">[52]</span></a></sup> Though the taxonomic name has often been interpreted as a reference to dinosaurs' teeth, claws, and other fearsome characteristics, Owen intended it to also evoke their size and majesty.<sup about="#mwt209" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-FBS97_54-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"FBS97"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-FBS97-54" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 53;" id="mwAYg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAYk">[53]</span></a></sup> Owen recognized that the remains that had been found so far, <i id="mwAYo">Iguanodon</i>, <i id="mwAYs">Megalosaurus</i> and <i id="mwAYw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hylaeosaurus" title="Hylaeosaurus" id="mwAY0">Hylaeosaurus</a></i>, shared a number of distinctive features, and so decided to present them as a distinct taxonomic group. With the backing of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Albert,_Prince_Consort" title="Albert, Prince Consort" id="mwAY4">Prince Albert</a>, the husband of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Queen_Victoria" title="Queen Victoria" id="mwAY8">Queen Victoria</a>, Owen established the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Natural_History_Museum,_London" title="Natural History Museum, London" id="mwAZA">Natural History Museum, London</a>, to display the national collection of dinosaur fossils and other biological and geological exhibits.<sup about="#mwt211" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-owen94_55-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"owen94"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-owen94-55"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-owen94-55" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 54;" id="mwAZE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAZI">[54]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="7" id="mwAZM"><h3 id="Discoveries_in_North_America">Discoveries in North America</h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" about="#mwt212" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"multiple image","href":"./Template:Multiple_image"},"params":{"align":{"wt":"left"},"perrow":{"wt":"2/1"},"total_width":{"wt":"300"},"caption_align":{"wt":"center"},"image1":{"wt":"Edcope.jpg"},"caption1":{"wt":"[[Edward Drinker Cope]]"},"image2":{"wt":"OthnielCharlesMarsh.jpg"},"caption2":{"wt":"[[Othniel Charles Marsh]]"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAZQ">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti
