.thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tleft" about="#mwt212"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:138px;max-width:138px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:175px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:Edcope.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:Edcope.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Edcope.jpg/136px-Edcope.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="465" data-file-height="600" data-file-type="bitmap" height="175" width="136" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Edcope.jpg/204px-Edcope.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Edcope.jpg/272px-Edcope.jpg 2x"/></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Edward_Drinker_Cope" title="Edward Drinker Cope">Edward Drinker Cope</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:150px;max-width:150px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:175px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:OthnielCharlesMarsh.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:OthnielCharlesMarsh.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/OthnielCharlesMarsh.jpg/148px-OthnielCharlesMarsh.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="343" data-file-height="408" data-file-type="bitmap" height="176" width="148" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/OthnielCharlesMarsh.jpg/222px-OthnielCharlesMarsh.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/OthnielCharlesMarsh.jpg/296px-OthnielCharlesMarsh.jpg 2x"/></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Othniel_Charles_Marsh" title="Othniel Charles Marsh">Othniel Charles Marsh</a></div></div></div></div></div><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Pages_using_multiple_image_with_auto_scaled_images" about="#mwt212" id="mwAZU"/>

<p id="mwAZY">In 1858, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./William_Parker_Foulke" title="William Parker Foulke" id="mwAZc">William Parker Foulke</a> discovered the first known American dinosaur, in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Marl" title="Marl" id="mwAZg">marl</a> pits in the small town of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Haddonfield,_New_Jersey" title="Haddonfield, New Jersey" id="mwAZk">Haddonfield, New Jersey</a>. (Although fossils had been found before, their nature had not been correctly discerned.) The creature was named <i id="mwAZo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hadrosaurus" title="Hadrosaurus" id="mwAZs">Hadrosaurus foulkii</a></i>. It was an extremely important find: <i id="mwAZw">Hadrosaurus</i> was one of the first nearly complete dinosaur skeletons found (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Iguanodon#Gideon_Mantell,_Sir_Richard_Owen,_and_the_discovery_of_dinosaurs" title="Iguanodon" id="mwAZ0">the first</a> was in 1834, in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Maidstone" title="Maidstone" id="mwAZ4">Maidstone, England</a>), and it was clearly a bipedal creature. This was a revolutionary discovery as, until that point, most scientists had believed dinosaurs walked on four feet, like other lizards. Foulke's discoveries sparked a wave of interests in dinosaurs in the United States, known as dinosaur mania.<sup about="#mwt219" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-weishampel06_56-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"weishampel06"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-weishampel06-56"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-weishampel06-56" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 55;" id="mwAZ8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAaA">[55]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAaE">Dinosaur mania was exemplified by the fierce rivalry between <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Edward_Drinker_Cope" title="Edward Drinker Cope" id="mwAaI">Edward Drinker Cope</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Othniel_Charles_Marsh" title="Othniel Charles Marsh" id="mwAaM">Othniel Charles Marsh</a>, both of whom raced to be the first to find new dinosaurs in what came to be known as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bone_Wars" title="Bone Wars" id="mwAaQ">Bone Wars</a>. This fight between the two scientists lasted for over 30 years, ending in 1897 when Cope died after spending his entire fortune on the dinosaur hunt. Unfortunately, many valuable dinosaur specimens were damaged or destroyed due to the pair's rough methods: for example, their diggers often used <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dynamite" title="Dynamite" id="mwAaU">dynamite</a> to unearth bones. Modern paleontologists would find such methods crude and unacceptable, since blasting easily destroys fossil and stratigraphic evidence. Despite their unrefined methods, the contributions of Cope and Marsh to paleontology were vast: Marsh unearthed 86 new species of dinosaur and Cope discovered 56, a total of 142 new species. Cope's collection is now at the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./American_Museum_of_Natural_History" title="American Museum of Natural History" id="mwAaY">American Museum of Natural History</a> in New York City, while Marsh's is at the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Peabody_Museum_of_Natural_History" title="Peabody Museum of Natural History" id="mwAac">Peabody Museum of Natural History</a> at <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Yale_University" title="Yale University" id="mwAag">Yale University</a>.<sup about="#mwt221" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Holmes_57-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Holmes"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Holmes-57" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 56;" id="mwAak"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAao">[56]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="8" id="mwAas"><h3 id='"Dinosaur_renaissance"_and_beyond'><span id=".22Dinosaur_renaissance.22_and_beyond" typeof="mw:FallbackId"></span>"Dinosaur renaissance" and beyond</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt222" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Dinosaur renaissance"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAaw"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt222" id="mwAa0">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dinosaur_renaissance" title="Dinosaur renaissance">Dinosaur renaissance</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAa4"><a href="./File:Bulletin_(1969)_(19798844494).jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAa8"><img resource="./File:Bulletin_(1969)_(19798844494).jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Bulletin_%281969%29_%2819798844494%29.jpg/220px-Bulletin_%281969%29_%2819798844494%29.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="3184" data-file-height="1272" data-file-type="bitmap" height="88" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Bulletin_%281969%29_%2819798844494%29.jpg/330px-Bulletin_%281969%29_%2819798844494%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Bulletin_%281969%29_%2819798844494%29.jpg/440px-Bulletin_%281969%29_%2819798844494%29.jpg 2x" id="mwAbA"/></a><figcaption id="mwAbE"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./John_Ostrom" title="John Ostrom" id="mwAbI">John Ostrom</a>'s original restoration of <i id="mwAbM"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deinonychus" title="Deinonychus" id="mwAbQ">Deinonychus</a></i>, published in 1969</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAbU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./World_War_II" title="World War II" id="mwAbY">World War II</a> caused a pause in palaeontological research; after the war, research attention was also diverted increasingly to fossil mammals rather than dinosaurs, which were seen as sluggish and cold-blooded.<sup about="#mwt236" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-taylor2010_58-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"taylor2010"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-taylor2010-58"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-taylor2010-58" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 57;" id="mwAbc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAbg">[57]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt240" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Naish_59-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Naish"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Naish-59"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Naish-59" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 58;" id="mwAbk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAbo">[58]</span></a></sup> At the end of the 1960s, however, the field of dinosaur research experienced a surge in activity that remains ongoing.<sup about="#mwt244" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-arbour2018_60-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"arbour2018"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-arbour2018-60"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-arbour2018-60" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 59;" id="mwAbs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAbw">[59]</span></a></sup> Several seminal studies led to this activity. First, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./John_Ostrom" title="John Ostrom" id="mwAb0">John Ostrom</a> discovered the bird-like <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dromaeosauridae" title="Dromaeosauridae" id="mwAb4">dromaeosaurid</a> theropod <i id="mwAb8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deinonychus" title="Deinonychus" id="mwAcA">Deinonychus</a></i> and described it in 1969. Its anatomy indicated that it was an active predator that was likely warm-blooded, in marked contrast to the then-prevailing image of dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt245" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-taylor2010_58-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"taylor2010"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-taylor2010-58" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 57;" id="mwAcE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAcI">[57]</span></a></sup> Concurrently, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Robert_T._Bakker" title="Robert T. Bakker" id="mwAcM">Robert T. Bakker</a> published a series of studies that likewise argued for active lifestyles in dinosaurs based on anatomical and ecological evidence (see <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dinosaur#Physiology" about="#mwt232" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"section link","href":"./Template:Section_link"},"params":{"1":{"wt":""},"2":{"wt":"Physiology"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAcQ">§<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>Physiology</a>),<sup about="#mwt246" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bakker1968_61-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bakker1968"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-bakker1968-61" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 60;" id="mwAcU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAcY">[60]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt247" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bakker1972_62-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bakker1972"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-bakker1972-62" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 61;" id="mwAcc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAcg">[61]</span></a></sup> which were subsequently summarized in his 1986 book <i id="mwAck"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./The_Dinosaur_Heresies" title="The Dinosaur Heresies" id="mwAco">The Dinosaur Heresies</a></i>.<sup about="#mwt249" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bakker86_63-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bakker86"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-bakker86-63"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-bakker86-63" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 62;" id="mwAcs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAcw">[62]</span></a></sup></p> 

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAc0"><a href="./File:Dr._Bob_Bakker_with_Dino.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAc4"><img resource="./File:Dr._Bob_Bakker_with_Dino.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Dr._Bob_Bakker_with_Dino.jpg/220px-Dr._Bob_Bakker_with_Dino.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="907" data-file-height="604" data-file-type="bitmap" height="147" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Dr._Bob_Bakker_with_Dino.jpg/330px-Dr._Bob_Bakker_with_Dino.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Dr._Bob_Bakker_with_Dino.jpg/440px-Dr._Bob_Bakker_with_Dino.jpg 2x" id="mwAc8"/></a><figcaption id="mwAdA">Paleontologist <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Robert_T._Bakker" title="Robert T. Bakker" id="mwAdE">Robert T. Bakker</a> with a mounted skeleton of a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tyrannosauridae" title="Tyrannosauridae" id="mwAdI">tyrannosaurid</a> (<i id="mwAdM"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gorgosaurus" title="Gorgosaurus" id="mwAdQ">Gorgosaurus libratus</a></i>)</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAdU">New revelations were supported by an increase in dinosaur discoveries. Major new dinosaur discoveries have been made by paleontologists working in previously unexplored regions, including India, South America, Madagascar, Antarctica, and most significantly China. Across theropods, sauropodomorphs, and ornithischians, the number of named genera began to increase exponentially in the 1990s.<sup about="#mwt256" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Genera900_19-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Genera900"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Genera900-19" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 18;" id="mwAdY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAdc">[18]</span></a></sup> As of 2008, over 30 new species of dinosaurs were named each year.<sup about="#mwt257" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-benton2008_64-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"benton2008"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-benton2008-64" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 63;" id="mwAdg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAdk">[63]</span></a></sup> At least sauropodomorphs experienced a further increase in the number of named species in the 2010s, with an average of 9.3 new species having been named each year between 2009 and 2020. As a consequence, more sauropodomorphs were named between 1990 and 2020 than in all previous years combined.<sup about="#mwt261" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-cashmore2020_65-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"cashmore2020"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-cashmore2020-65"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-cashmore2020-65" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 64;" id="mwAdo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAds">[64]</span></a></sup> These new localities also led to improvements in overall specimen quality, with new species being increasingly named not on scrappy fossils but on more complete skeletons, sometimes from multiple individuals. Better specimens also led to new species being invalidated less frequently.<sup about="#mwt265" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-benton2008_64-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"benton2008"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-benton2008-64"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-benton2008-64" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 63;" id="mwAdw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAd0">[63]</span></a></sup> Asian localities have produced the most complete theropod specimens,<sup about="#mwt269" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-cashmore2019_66-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"cashmore2019"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-cashmore2019-66"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-cashmore2019-66" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 65;" id="mwAd4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAd8">[65]</span></a></sup> while North American localities have produced the most complete sauropodomorph specimens.<sup about="#mwt270" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-cashmore2020_65-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"cashmore2020"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-cashmore2020-65" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 64;" id="mwAeA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAeE">[64]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAeI">Prior to the dinosaur renaissance, dinosaurs were mostly classified using the traditional rank-based system of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Linnaean_taxonomy" title="Linnaean taxonomy" id="mwAeM">Linnaean taxonomy</a>. The renaissance was also accompanied by the increasingly widespread application of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cladistics" title="Cladistics" id="mwAeQ">cladistics</a>, a more objective method of classification based on ancestry and shared traits, which has proved tremendously useful in the study of dinosaur systematics and evolution. Cladistic analysis, among other techniques, helps to compensate for an often incomplete and fragmentary fossil record.<sup about="#mwt278" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-holtz1997_67-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"holtz1997"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-holtz1997-67"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-holtz1997-67" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 66;" id="mwAeU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAeY">[66]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt282" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20161208_68-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NYT-20161208"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-NYT-20161208-68"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-NYT-20161208-68" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 67;" id="mwAec"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAeg">[67]</span></a></sup> Reference books summarizing the state of dinosaur research, such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./David_B._Weishampel" title="David B. Weishampel" id="mwAek">David B. Weishampel</a> and colleagues' <i id="mwAeo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./The_Dinosauria" title="The Dinosauria" id="mwAes">The Dinosauria</a></i>, made knowledge more accessible<sup about="#mwt286" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-lockley2000_69-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"lockley2000"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-lockley2000-69"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-lockley2000-69" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 68;" id="mwAew"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAe0">[68]</span></a></sup> and spurred further interest in dinosaur research. The release of the first and second editions of <i id="mwAe4">The Dinosauria</i> in 1990 and 2004, and of a review paper by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paul_Sereno" title="Paul Sereno" id="mwAe8">Paul Sereno</a> in 1998, were accompanied by increases in the number of published <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Phylogenetic_tree" title="Phylogenetic tree" id="mwAfA">phylogenetic trees</a> for dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt290" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-lloyd2008_70-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"lloyd2008"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-lloyd2008-70"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-lloyd2008-70" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 69;" id="mwAfE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAfI">[69]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="9" id="mwAfM"><h3 id="Soft_tissue_and_molecular_preservation">Soft tissue and molecular preservation</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAfQ"><a href="./File:Dakota_skin_impression.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAfU"><img resource="./File:Dakota_skin_impression.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Dakota_skin_impression.jpg/220px-Dakota_skin_impression.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800" data-file-type="bitmap" height="147" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Dakota_skin_impression.jpg/330px-Dakota_skin_impression.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Dakota_skin_impression.jpg/440px-Dakota_skin_impression.jpg 2x" id="mwAfY"/></a><figcaption id="mwAfc">An <i id="mwAfg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Edmontosaurus" title="Edmontosaurus" id="mwAfk">Edmontosaurus</a></i> specimen's skin impressions found in 1999</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAfo">Dinosaur fossils are not limited to bones, but also include imprints or mineralized remains of skin coverings, organs, and other tissues. Of these, skin coverings based on <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Keratin" title="Keratin" id="mwAfs">keratin</a> proteins are most easily preserved because of their <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cross-link" title="Cross-link" id="mwAfw">cross-linked</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hydrophobe" title="Hydrophobe" id="mwAf0">hydrophobic</a> molecular structure.<sup about="#mwt299" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-schweitzer2011_71-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"schweitzer2011"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-schweitzer2011-71"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-schweitzer2011-71" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 70;" id="mwAf4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAf8">[70]</span></a></sup> Fossils of keratin-based skin coverings or bony skin coverings are known from most major groups of dinosaurs. Dinosaur fossils with scaly skin impressions have been found since the 19th century. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Samuel_Beckles" title="Samuel Beckles" id="mwAgA">Samuel Beckles</a> discovered a sauropod forelimb with preserved skin in 1852 that was incorrectly attributed to a crocodile; it was correctly attributed by Marsh in 1888 and subject to further study by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Reginald_Hooley" title="Reginald Hooley" id="mwAgE">Reginald Hooley</a> in 1917.<sup about="#mwt300" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hooley1917_72-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hooley1917"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-hooley1917-72" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 71;" id="mwAgI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgM">[71]</span></a></sup> Among ornithischians, in 1884 Jacob Wortman found skin impressions on the first known specimen of <i id="mwAgQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Edmontosaurus_annectens" title="Edmontosaurus annectens" id="mwAgU">Edmontosaurus annectens</a></i>, which were largely destroyed during the specimen's excavation.<sup about="#mwt304" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-osborn1912_73-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"osborn1912"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-osborn1912-73"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-osborn1912-73" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 72;" id="mwAgY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgc">[72]</span></a></sup> Owen and Hooley subsequently described skin impressions of <i id="mwAgg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hypsilophodon" title="Hypsilophodon" id="mwAgk">Hypsilophodon</a></i> and <i id="mwAgo">Iguanodon</i> in 1885 and 1917.<sup about="#mwt308" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hooley1917_72-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hooley1917"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-hooley1917-72"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-hooley1917-72" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 71;" id="mwAgs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAgw">[71]</span></a></sup> Since then, scale impressions have been most frequently found among hadrosaurids, where the impressions are known from nearly the entire body across multiple specimens.<sup about="#mwt312" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bell2014_74-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bell2014"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-bell2014-74"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-bell2014-74" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 73;" id="mwAg0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAg4">[73]</span></a></sup></p> 

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" about="#mwt313" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"multiple image","href":"./Template:Multiple_image"},"params":{"align":{"wt":"left"},"perrow":{"wt":"1/2"},"caption_align":{"wt":"center"},"image1":{"wt":"Sinosauropteryx color.jpg"},"caption1":{"wt":"Colour restoration of &apos;&apos;[[Sinosauropteryx]]&apos;&apos;"},"image2":{"wt":"Psittacosaurus (Vinther et al. 2016, cropped).png"},"caption2":{"wt":"Colour restoration of &apos;&apos;[[Psittacosaurus]]&apos;&apos;"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAg8"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft" about="#mwt313" id="mwAhA"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:Sinosauropteryx_color.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:Sinosauropteryx_color.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Sinosauropteryx_color.jpg/200px-Sinosauropteryx_color.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1345" data-file-height="380" data-file-type="bitmap" height="57" width="200" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Sinosauropteryx_color.jpg/300px-Sinosauropteryx_color.jpg 1.5x,
