<i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sinosauropteryx" title="Sinosauropteryx">Sinosauropteryx</a></i></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:Psittacosaurus_(Vinther_et_al._2016,_cropped).png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:Psittacosaurus_(Vinther_et_al._2016,_cropped).png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Psittacosaurus_%28Vinther_et_al._2016%2C_cropped%29.png/200px-Psittacosaurus_%28Vinther_et_al._2016%2C_cropped%29.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="1561" data-file-height="685" data-file-type="bitmap" height="88" width="200" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Psittacosaurus_%28Vinther_et_al._2016%2C_cropped%29.png/300px-Psittacosaurus_%28Vinther_et_al._2016%2C_cropped%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Psittacosaurus_%28Vinther_et_al._2016%2C_cropped%29.png/400px-Psittacosaurus_%28Vinther_et_al._2016%2C_cropped%29.png 2x"/></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">Colour restoration of <i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Psittacosaurus" title="Psittacosaurus">Psittacosaurus</a></i></div></div></div></div></div>
<p id="mwAhE">Starting from the 1990s, major discoveries of exceptionally preserved fossils in deposits known as conservation <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lagerstätte" title="Lagerstätte" id="mwAhI">Lagerstätten</a> contributed to research on dinosaur soft tissues.<sup about="#mwt335" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-eliason2017_75-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"eliason2017"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-eliason2017-75"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-eliason2017-75" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 74;" id="mwAhM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAhQ">[74]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt339" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-benton1998_76-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"benton1998"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-benton1998-76"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-benton1998-76" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 75;" id="mwAhU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAhY">[75]</span></a></sup> Chiefly among these were the rocks that produced the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jehol_Biota" title="Jehol Biota" id="mwAhc">Jehol</a> (Early Cretaceous) and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Yanliao_Biota" title="Yanliao Biota" id="mwAhg">Yanliao</a> (Mid-to-Late Jurassic) <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biota_(ecology)" title="Biota (ecology)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAhk">biotas</a> of northeastern China, from which hundreds of dinosaur specimens bearing impressions of feather-like structures (both closely related to birds and otherwise, see <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dinosaur#Origin_of_birds" about="#mwt331" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"section link","href":"./Template:Section_link"},"params":{"1":{"wt":""},"2":{"wt":"Origin of birds"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAho">§<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>Origin of birds</a>) have been described by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Xu_Xing_(paleontologist)" title="Xu Xing (paleontologist)" id="mwAhs">Xing Xu</a> and colleagues.<sup about="#mwt343" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-zhou2017_77-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"zhou2017"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-zhou2017-77"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-zhou2017-77" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 76;" id="mwAhw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAh0">[76]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt347" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-norell2005_78-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"norell2005"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-norell2005-78"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-norell2005-78" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 77;" id="mwAh4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAh8">[77]</span></a></sup> In living reptiles and mammals, pigment-storing cellular structures known as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Melanosome" title="Melanosome" id="mwAiA">melanosomes</a> are partially responsible for producing colouration.<sup about="#mwt348" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-roy2020_79-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"roy2020"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-roy2020-79" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 78;" id="mwAiE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAiI">[78]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt352" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-vinther2020_80-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"vinther2020"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-vinther2020-80"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-vinther2020-80" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 79;" id="mwAiM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAiQ">[79]</span></a></sup> Both chemical traces of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Melanin" title="Melanin" id="mwAiU">melanin</a> and characteristically-shaped melanosomes have been reported from feathers and scales of Jehol and Yanliao dinosaurs, including both theropods and ornithischians.<sup about="#mwt356" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-zhang2010_81-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"zhang2010"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-zhang2010-81"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-zhang2010-81" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 80;" id="mwAiY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAic">[80]</span></a></sup> This has enabled multiple full-body reconstructions of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dinosaur_colouration" title="Dinosaur colouration" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAig">dinosaur colouration</a>, such as for <i id="mwAik"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sinosauropteryx" title="Sinosauropteryx" id="mwAio">Sinosauropteryx</a></i><sup about="#mwt360" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-smithwick2017_82-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"smithwick2017"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-smithwick2017-82"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-smithwick2017-82" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 81;" id="mwAis"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAiw">[81]</span></a></sup> and <i id="mwAi0"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Psittacosaurus" title="Psittacosaurus" id="mwAi4">Psittacosaurus</a></i><sup about="#mwt364" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-vinther2016_83-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"vinther2016"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-vinther2016-83"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-vinther2016-83" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 82;" id="mwAi8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAjA">[82]</span></a></sup> by Jakob Vinther and colleagues, and similar techniques have also been extended to dinosaur fossils from other localities.<sup about="#mwt368" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-roy2020_79-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"roy2020"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-roy2020-79"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-roy2020-79" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 78;" id="mwAjE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAjI">[78]</span></a></sup> (However, some researchers have also suggested that fossilized melanosomes represent bacterial remains.<sup about="#mwt372" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-lindgren2015_84-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"lindgren2015"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-lindgren2015-84"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-lindgren2015-84" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 83;" id="mwAjM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAjQ">[83]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt376" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-schweitzer2015_85-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"schweitzer2015"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-schweitzer2015-85"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-schweitzer2015-85" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 84;" id="mwAjU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAjY">[84]</span></a></sup>) Stomach contents in some Jehol and Yanliao dinosaurs closely related to birds have also provided indirect indications of diet and digestive system anatomy (e.g., <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crop_(anatomy)" title="Crop (anatomy)" id="mwAjc">crops</a>).<sup about="#mwt380" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-zhou2014_86-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"zhou2014"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-zhou2014-86"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-zhou2014-86" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 85;" id="mwAjg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAjk">[85]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt384" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-oconnor2019_87-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"oconnor2019"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-oconnor2019-87"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-oconnor2019-87" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 86;" id="mwAjo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAjs">[86]</span></a></sup> More concrete evidence of internal anatomy has been reported in <i id="mwAjw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scipionyx" title="Scipionyx" id="mwAj0">Scipionyx</a></i> from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pietraroja_Plattenkalk" title="Pietraroja Plattenkalk" id="mwAj4">Pietraroja Plattenkalk</a> of Italy. It preserves portions of the intestines, colon, liver, muscles, and windpipe.<sup about="#mwt385" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-softtissue_88-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"softtissue"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-softtissue-88" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;" id="mwAj8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAkA">[87]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAkE"><a href="./File:9121_-_Milano,_Museo_storia_naturale_-_Scipionyx_samniticus_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall'Orto_22-Apr-2007a.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAkI"><img resource="./File:9121_-_Milano,_Museo_storia_naturale_-_Scipionyx_samniticus_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall'Orto_22-Apr-2007a.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/9121_-_Milano%2C_Museo_storia_naturale_-_Scipionyx_samniticus_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto_22-Apr-2007a.jpg/220px-9121_-_Milano%2C_Museo_storia_naturale_-_Scipionyx_samniticus_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto_22-Apr-2007a.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1360" data-file-type="bitmap" height="146" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/9121_-_Milano%2C_Museo_storia_naturale_-_Scipionyx_samniticus_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto_22-Apr-2007a.jpg/330px-9121_-_Milano%2C_Museo_storia_naturale_-_Scipionyx_samniticus_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto_22-Apr-2007a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/9121_-_Milano%2C_Museo_storia_naturale_-_Scipionyx_samniticus_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto_22-Apr-2007a.jpg/440px-9121_-_Milano%2C_Museo_storia_naturale_-_Scipionyx_samniticus_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto_22-Apr-2007a.jpg 2x" id="mwAkM"/></a><figcaption id="mwAkQ"><i id="mwAkU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scipionyx" title="Scipionyx" id="mwAkY">Scipionyx</a></i> fossil with intestines, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Museo_Civico_di_Storia_Naturale_di_Milano" title="Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Milano" id="mwAkc">Natural History Museum of Milan</a></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAkg">Concurrently, a line of work led by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mary_Higby_Schweitzer" title="Mary Higby Schweitzer" id="mwAkk">Mary Higby Schweitzer</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jack_Horner_(paleontologist)" title="Jack Horner (paleontologist)" id="mwAko">Jack Horner</a>, and colleagues reported various occurrences of preserved soft tissues and proteins within dinosaur bone fossils. Various mineralized structures that likely represented <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Red_blood_cell" title="Red blood cell" id="mwAks">red blood cells</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Collagen" title="Collagen" id="mwAkw">collagen</a> fibres had been found by Schweitzer and others in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tyrannosauridae" title="Tyrannosauridae" id="mwAk0">tyrannosaurid</a> bones as early as 1991.<sup about="#mwt403" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-morell1993_89-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"morell1993"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-morell1993-89"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-morell1993-89" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 88;" id="mwAk4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAk8">[88]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt407" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pawlicki1996_90-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pawlicki1996"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-pawlicki1996-90"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-pawlicki1996-90" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 89;" id="mwAlA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAlE">[89]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt411" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pawlicki1998_91-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pawlicki1998"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-pawlicki1998-91"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-pawlicki1998-91" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 90;" id="mwAlI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAlM">[90]</span></a></sup> However, in 2005, Schweitzer and colleagues reported that a femur of <i id="mwAlQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tyrannosaurus" title="Tyrannosaurus" id="mwAlU">Tyrannosaurus</a></i> preserved soft, flexible tissue within, including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Blood_vessel" title="Blood vessel" id="mwAlY">blood vessels</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Osteon" title="Osteon" id="mwAlc">bone matrix</a>, and connective tissue (bone fibers) that had retained their microscopic structure.<sup about="#mwt412" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Schweitzer2005_92-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Schweitzer2005"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Schweitzer2005-92" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 91;" id="mwAlg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAlk">[91]</span></a></sup> This discovery suggested that original soft tissues could be preserved over geological time.<sup about="#mwt413" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-schweitzer2011_71-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"schweitzer2011"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-schweitzer2011-71" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 70;" id="mwAlo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAls">[70]</span></a></sup> Later, in 2009, Schweitzer and colleagues reported that a <i id="mwAlw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Brachylophosaurus" title="Brachylophosaurus" id="mwAl0">Brachylophosaurus</a></i> femur preserved similar microstructures, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Immunohistochemistry" title="Immunohistochemistry" id="mwAl4">immunohistochemical</a> techniques (based on <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Antibody" title="Antibody" id="mwAl8">antibody</a> binding) demonstrated the presence of proteins such as collagen, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Elastin" title="Elastin" id="mwAmA">elastin</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Laminin" title="Laminin" id="mwAmE">laminin</a>.<sup about="#mwt417" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-schweitzer2009_93-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"schweitzer2009"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-schweitzer2009-93"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-schweitzer2009-93" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 92;" id="mwAmI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAmM">[92]</span></a></sup> Both specimens yielded collagen protein sequences that were viable for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Molecular_phylogenetics" title="Molecular phylogenetics" id="mwAmQ">molecular phylogenetic analyses</a>, which grouped them with birds as would be expected.<sup about="#mwt418" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-schweitzer2009_93-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"schweitzer2009"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-schweitzer2009-93" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 92;" id="mwAmU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAmY">[92]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt422" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-organ2008_94-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"organ2008"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-organ2008-94"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-organ2008-94" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 93;" id="mwAmc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAmg">[93]</span></a></sup> The extraction of fragmentary DNA has also been reported for both of these fossils,<sup about="#mwt426" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-schweitzer2013_95-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"schweitzer2013"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-schweitzer2013-95"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-schweitzer2013-95" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 94;" id="mwAmk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAmo">[94]</span></a></sup> along with a specimen of <i id="mwAms"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hypacrosaurus" title="Hypacrosaurus" id="mwAmw">Hypacrosaurus</a></i>.<sup about="#mwt430" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bailleul2020_96-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bailleul2020"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-bailleul2020-96"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-bailleul2020-96" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 95;" id="mwAm0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAm4">[95]</span></a></sup> In 2015, Sergio Bertazzo and colleagues reported the preservation of collagen fibres and red blood cells in eight Cretaceous dinosaur specimens that did not show any signs of exceptional preservation, indicating that soft tissue may be preserved more commonly than previously thought.<sup about="#mwt434" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bertazzo2015_97-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bertazzo2015"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-bertazzo2015-97"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-bertazzo2015-97" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 96;" id="mwAm8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAnA">[96]</span></a></sup> Suggestions that these structures represent bacterial <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biofilm" title="Biofilm" id="mwAnE">biofilms</a><sup about="#mwt438" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-kaye2008_98-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"kaye2008"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-kaye2008-98"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-kaye2008-98" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 97;" id="mwAnI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAnM">[97]</span></a></sup> have been rejected,<sup about="#mwt442" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-peterson2010_99-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"peterson2010"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-peterson2010-99"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-peterson2010-99" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 98;" id="mwAnQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAnU">[98]</span></a></sup> but cross-contamination remains a possibility that is difficult to detect.<sup about="#mwt446" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-buckley2017_100-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"buckley2017"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-buckley2017-100"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-buckley2017-100" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 99;" id="mwAnY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAnc">[99]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="10" id="mwAng"><h2 id="Evolutionary_history">Evolutionary history</h2>
<section data-mw-section-id="11" id="mwAnk"><h3 id="Origins_and_early_evolution">Origins and early evolution</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAno"><a href="./File:Herrerasaurusskeleton.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAns"><img alt="Full skeleton of an early carnivorous dinosaur, displayed in a glass case in a museum" resource="./File:Herrerasaurusskeleton.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Herrerasaurusskeleton.jpg/220px-Herrerasaurusskeleton.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="2549" data-file-height="1604" data-file-type="bitmap" height="138" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Herrerasaurusskeleton.jpg/330px-Herrerasaurusskeleton.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Herrerasaurusskeleton.jpg/440px-Herrerasaurusskeleton.jpg 2x" id="mwAnw"/></a><figcaption id="mwAn0">The early dinosaurs <i id="mwAn4"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Herrerasaurus" title="Herrerasaurus" id="mwAn8">Herrerasaurus</a></i> (large), <i id="mwAoA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eoraptor" title="Eoraptor" id="mwAoE">Eoraptor</a></i> (small) and a <i id="mwAoI"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Plateosaurus" title="Plateosaurus" id="mwAoM">Plateosaurus</a></i> skull, from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Triassic" title="Triassic" id="mwAoQ">Triassic</a></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAoU">Dinosaurs diverged from their archosaur ancestors during the Middle to Late Triassic epochs, roughly 20<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAoY"> </span>million years after the devastating <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Permian–Triassic_extinction_event" title="Permian–Triassic extinction event" id="mwAoc">Permian–Triassic extinction event</a> wiped out an estimated 96% of all marine species and 70% of terrestrial vertebrate species approximately 252<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAog"> </span>million years ago.<sup about="#mwt450" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-KPA_101-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"KPA"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-KPA-101" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 100;" id="mwAok"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAoo">[100]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt451" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-TannerLucas_102-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"TannerLucas"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-TannerLucas-102" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 101;" id="mwAos"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAow">[101]</span></a></sup> The oldest dinosaur fossils known from substantial remains date to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnian" title="Carnian" id="mwAo0">Carnian</a> epoch of the Triassic period, which have been primarily found in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ischigualasto_Formation" title="Ischigualasto Formation" id="mwAo4">Ischigualasto</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Santa_Maria_Formation" title="Santa Maria Formation" id="mwAo8">Santa Maria Formations</a> of Argentina, and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pebbly_Arkose_Formation" title="Pebbly Arkose Formation" id="mwApA">Pebbly Arkose Formation</a> of Zimbabwe.<sup about="#mwt455" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-griffin2022_103-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"griffin2022"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-griffin2022-103"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-griffin2022-103" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 102;" id="mwApE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwApI">[102]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwApM">The Ischigualasto Formation (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Radiometric_dating" title="Radiometric dating" id="mwApQ">radiometrically dated</a> to be approximately 231-230 million years old<sup about="#mwt469" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-desojo2020_104-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"desojo2020"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-desojo2020-104"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-desojo2020-104" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 103;" id="mwApU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwApY">[103]</span></a></sup>) has produced the early saurischian <i id="mwApc"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eoraptor" title="Eoraptor" id="mwApg">Eoraptor</a></i>, originally considered a member of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Herrerasauridae" title="Herrerasauridae" id="mwApk">Herrerasauridae</a><sup about="#mwt473" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-OARM2010_105-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"OARM2010"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-OARM2010-105"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-OARM2010-105" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 104;" id="mwApo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAps">[104]</span></a></sup> but now considered to be an early sauropodomorph, along with the herrerasaurids <i id="mwApw">Herrerasaurus</i> and <i id="mwAp0"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sanjuansaurus" title="Sanjuansaurus" id="mwAp4">Sanjuansaurus</a></i>, and the sauropodomorphs <i id="mwAp8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chromogisaurus" title="Chromogisaurus" id="mwAqA">Chromogisaurus</a></i>, <i id="mwAqE"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eodromaeus" title="Eodromaeus" id="mwAqI">Eodromaeus</a></i>, and <i id="mwAqM"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Panphagia" title="Panphagia" id="mwAqQ">Panphagia</a></i>.<sup about="#mwt477" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-novas2021_106-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"novas2021"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-novas2021-106"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-novas2021-106" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 105;" id="mwAqU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAqY">[105]</span></a></sup> <i id="mwAqc">Eoraptor</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;" about="#mwt465" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"&apos;s","href":"./Template:&apos;s"},"params":{},"i":0}}]}' id="mwAqg"><span typeof="mw:Entity">'</span>s</span> likely resemblance to the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Common_descent" title="Common descent" id="mwAqk">common ancestor</a> of all dinosaurs suggests that the first dinosaurs would have been small, bipedal <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Predation" title="Predation" id="mwAqo">predators</a>.<sup about="#mwt481" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Daemonosaurus_107-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Daemonosaurus"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Daemonosaurus-107"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Daemonosaurus-107" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 106;" id="mwAqs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAqw">[106]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt482" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Sereno1999_108-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Sereno1999"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Sereno1999-108" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 107;" id="mwAq0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAq4">[107]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt483" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-SFRM93_109-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"SFRM93"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-SFRM93-109" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 108;" id="mwAq8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwArA">[108]</span></a></sup> The Santa Maria Formation (radiometrically dated to be older, at 233.23<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwArE"> </span>million years old<sup about="#mwt487" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-langer18_110-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"langer18"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-langer18-110"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-langer18-110" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 109;" id="mwArI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwArM">[109]</span></a></sup>) has produced the herrerasaurids <i id="mwArQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gnathovorax" title="Gnathovorax" id="mwArU">Gnathovorax</a></i> and <i id="mwArY"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Staurikosaurus" title="Staurikosaurus" id="mwArc">Staurikosaurus</a></i>, along with the sauropodomorphs <i id="mwArg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bagualosaurus" title="Bagualosaurus" id="mwArk">Bagualosaurus</a></i>, <i id="mwAro"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Buriolestes" title="Buriolestes" id="mwArs">Buriolestes</a></i>, <i id="mwArw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Guaibasaurus" title="Guaibasaurus" id="mwAr0">Guaibasaurus</a></i>, <i id="mwAr4"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Macrocollum" title="Macrocollum" id="mwAr8">Macrocollum</a></i>, <i id="mwAsA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nhandumirim" title="Nhandumirim" id="mwAsE">Nhandumirim</a></i>, <i id="mwAsI"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pampadromaeus" title="Pampadromaeus" id="mwAsM">Pampadromaeus</a></i>, <i id="mwAsQ">Saturnalia</i>, and <i id="mwAsU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Unaysaurus" title="Unaysaurus" id="mwAsY">Unaysaurus</a></i>.<sup about="#mwt488" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-novas2021_106-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"novas2021"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-novas2021-106" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 105;" id="mwAsc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAsg">[105]</span></a></sup> The Pebbly Arkose Formation, which is of uncertain age but was likely comparable to the other two, has produced the sauropodomorph <i id="mwAsk"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mbiresaurus" title="Mbiresaurus" id="mwAso">Mbiresaurus</a></i>, along with an unnamed herrerasaurid.<sup about="#mwt489" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-griffin2022_103-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"griffin2022"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-griffin2022-103" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 102;" id="mwAss"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAsw">[102]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAs0">Less well-preserved remains of the sauropodomorphs <i id="mwAs4"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jaklapallisaurus" title="Jaklapallisaurus" id="mwAs8">Jaklapallisaurus</a></i> and <i id="mwAtA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nambalia" title="Nambalia" id="mwAtE">Nambalia</a></i>, along with the early saurischian <i id="mwAtI"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Alwalkeria" title="Alwalkeria" id="mwAtM">Alwalkeria</a></i>, are respectively known fron the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Upper_Maleri_Formation" title="Upper Maleri Formation" id="mwAtQ">Upper Maleri</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lower_Maleri_Formation" title="Lower Maleri Formation" id="mwAtU">Lower Maleri Formations</a> of India.<sup about="#mwt499" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-novas2011_111-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"novas2011"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-novas2011-111"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-novas2011-111" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 110;" id="mwAtY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAtc">[110]</span></a></sup> Meanwhile, the Carnian-aged <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chañares_Formation" title="Chañares Formation" id="mwAtg">Chañares Formation</a> of Argentina preserves primitive, dinosaur-like ornithodirans such as <i id="mwAtk"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lagosuchus" title="Lagosuchus" id="mwAto">Lagosuchus</a></i> and <i id="mwAts"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lagerpeton" title="Lagerpeton" id="mwAtw">Lagerpeton</a></i> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Argentina" title="Argentina" id="mwAt0">Argentina</a>, making it another important site for understanding dinosaur evolution. These ornithodirans support the model of early dinosaurs as small, bipedal predators.<sup about="#mwt500" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-novas2021_106-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"novas2021"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-novas2021-106" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 105;" id="mwAt4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAt8">[105]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt504" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-mariscano2016_112-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"mariscano2016"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-mariscano2016-112"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-mariscano2016-112" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 111;" id="mwAuA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAuE">[111]</span></a></sup> Dinosaurs may have appeared as early as the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Anisian" title="Anisian" id="mwAuI">Anisian</a> epoch of the Triassic, approximately 245<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAuM"> </span>million years ago, which is the age of <i id="mwAuQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nyasasaurus" title="Nyasasaurus" id="mwAuU">Nyasasaurus</a></i> from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Manda_Formation" title="Manda Formation" id="mwAuY">Manda Formation</a> of Tanzania. However, its known fossils are too fragmentary to tell if it was a dinosaur or only a close relative.<sup about="#mwt508" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-nyasasaurus_113-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"nyasasaurus"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-nyasasaurus-113"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-nyasasaurus-113" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 112;" id="mwAuc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAug">[112]</span></a></sup> The referral of the Manda Formation to the Anisian is also uncertain. Regardless, dinosaurs existed alongside non-dinosaurian ornithodirans for a period of time, with estimates ranging from 5–10 million years<sup about="#mwt512" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-marsicano2015_114-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"marsicano2015"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-marsicano2015-114"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-marsicano2015-114" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 113;" id="mwAuk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAuo">[113]</span></a></sup> to 21 million years.<sup about="#mwt513" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-langer18_110-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"langer18"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-langer18-110" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 109;" id="mwAus"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAuw">[109]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAu0">When dinosaurs appeared, they were not the dominant terrestrial animals. The terrestrial habitats were occupied by various types of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Archosauromorpha" title="Archosauromorpha" id="mwAu4">archosauromorphs</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Therapsid" title="Therapsid" id="mwAu8">therapsids</a>, like <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cynodont" title="Cynodont" id="mwAvA">cynodonts</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rhynchosaur" title="Rhynchosaur" id="mwAvE">rhynchosaurs</a>. Their main competitors were the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pseudosuchians" title="Pseudosuchians" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAvI">pseudosuchians</a>, such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aetosaur" title="Aetosaur" id="mwAvM">aetosaurs</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ornithosuchidae" title="Ornithosuchidae" id="mwAvQ">ornithosuchids</a> and rauisuchians, which were more successful than the dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt523" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-115" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-115"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-115" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 114;" id="mwAvU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAvY">[114]</span></a></sup> Most of these other animals became extinct in the Triassic, in one of two events. First, at about 215<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAvc"> </span>million years ago, a variety of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Basal_(phylogenetics)" title="Basal (phylogenetics)" id="mwAvg">basal</a> archosauromorphs, including the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Protorosauria" title="Protorosauria" id="mwAvk">protorosaurs</a>, became extinct. This was followed by the Triassic–Jurassic extinction event (about 201<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwAvo"> </span>million years ago), that saw the end of most of the other groups of early archosaurs, like aetosaurs, ornithosuchids, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Phytosaur" title="Phytosaur" id="mwAvs">phytosaurs</a>, and rauisuchians. Rhynchosaurs and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dicynodont" title="Dicynodont" id="mwAvw">dicynodonts</a> survived (at least in some areas) at least as late as early –mid <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Norian" title="Norian" id="mwAv0">Norian</a> and late Norian or earliest <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rhaetian" title="Rhaetian" id="mwAv4">Rhaetian</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stage_(stratigraphy)" title="Stage (stratigraphy)" id="mwAv8">stages</a>, respectively,<sup about="#mwt525" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-116" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-116"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-116" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 115;" id="mwAwA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAwE">[115]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt529" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-117" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-117"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-117" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 116;" id="mwAwI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAwM">[116]</span></a></sup> and the exact date of their <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Extinction" title="Extinction" id="mwAwQ">extinction</a> is uncertain. These losses left behind a land fauna of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crocodylomorpha" title="Crocodylomorpha" id="mwAwU">crocodylomorphs</a>, dinosaurs, mammals, pterosaurians, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Turtle" title="Turtle" id="mwAwY">turtles</a>.<sup about="#mwt530" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MJB04dino_8-3" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MJB04dino"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-MJB04dino-8" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 7;" id="mwAwc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAwg">[7]</span></a></sup> The first few lines of early dinosaurs <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Adaptive_radiation" title="Adaptive radiation" id="mwAwk">diversified</a> through the Carnian and Norian stages of the Triassic, possibly by occupying the niches of the groups that became extinct.<sup about="#mwt531" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Letal05_10-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Letal05"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Letal05-10" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 9;" id="mwAwo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAws">[9]</span></a></sup> Also notably, there was a heightened rate of extinction during the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnian_pluvial_episode" title="Carnian pluvial episode" id="mwAww">Carnian pluvial event</a>.<sup about="#mwt535" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-118" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-118"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-118" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 117;" id="mwAw0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAw4">[117]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="12" id="mwAw8"><h3 id="Evolution_and_paleobiogeography">Evolution and paleobiogeography</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwAxA"><a href="./File:Pangaea_200Ma.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwAxE"><img resource="./File:Pangaea_200Ma.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Pangaea_200Ma.jpg/330px-Pangaea_200Ma.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1519" data-file-height="759" data-file-type="bitmap" height="165" width="330" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Pangaea_200Ma.jpg/495px-Pangaea_200Ma.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Pangaea_200Ma.jpg/660px-Pangaea_200Ma.jpg 2x" id="mwAxI"/></a><figcaption id="mwAxM">The supercontinent <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pangaea" title="Pangaea" id="mwAxQ">Pangaea</a> in the early <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mesozoic" title="Mesozoic" id="mwAxU">Mesozoic</a> (around 200 million years ago)</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwAxY">Dinosaur evolution after the Triassic followed changes in vegetation and the location of continents. In the Late Triassic and Early Jurassic, the continents were connected as the single landmass <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pangaea" title="Pangaea" id="mwAxc">Pangaea</a>, and there was a worldwide dinosaur fauna mostly composed of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Coelophysoidea" title="Coelophysoidea" id="mwAxg">coelophysoid</a> carnivores and early sauropodomorph herbivores.<sup about="#mwt541" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-HCL04_119-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"HCL04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-HCL04-119" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 118;" id="mwAxk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAxo">[118]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gymnosperm" title="Gymnosperm" id="mwAxs">Gymnosperm</a> plants (particularly <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pinophyta" title="Pinophyta" class="mw-redirect" id="mwAxw">conifers</a>), a potential food source, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Evolutionary_radiation" title="Evolutionary radiation" id="mwAx0">radiated</a> in the Late Triassic. Early sauropodomorphs did not have sophisticated mechanisms for processing food in the mouth, and so must have employed other means of breaking down food farther along the digestive tract.<sup about="#mwt542" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-FS04_120-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"FS04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-FS04-120" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 119;" id="mwAx4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAx8">[119]</span></a></sup> The general homogeneity of dinosaurian faunas continued into the Middle and Late Jurassic, where most localities had predators consisting of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ceratosauria" title="Ceratosauria" id="mwAyA">ceratosaurians</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Megalosauroidea" title="Megalosauroidea" id="mwAyE">megalosauroids</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Allosauroidea" title="Allosauroidea" id="mwAyI">allosauroids</a>, and herbivores consisting of stegosaurian ornithischians and large sauropods. Examples of this include the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Morrison_Formation" title="Morrison Formation" id="mwAyM">Morrison Formation</a> of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./North_America" title="North America" id="mwAyQ">North America</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tendaguru_Formation" title="Tendaguru Formation" id="mwAyU">Tendaguru Beds</a> of Tanzania. Dinosaurs in China show some differences, with specialized <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Metriacanthosauridae" title="Metriacanthosauridae" id="mwAyY">metriacanthosaurid</a> theropods and unusual, long-necked sauropods like <i id="mwAyc"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mamenchisaurus" title="Mamenchisaurus" id="mwAyg">Mamenchisaurus</a></i>.<sup about="#mwt543" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-HCL04_119-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"HCL04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-HCL04-119" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 118;" id="mwAyk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAyo">[118]</span></a></sup> Ankylosaurians and ornithopods were also becoming more common, but primitive sauropodomorphs had become extinct. Conifers and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pteridophyte" title="Pteridophyte" id="mwAys">pteridophytes</a> were the most common plants. Sauropods, like earlier sauropodomorphs, were not oral processors, but ornithischians were evolving various means of dealing with food in the mouth, including potential <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cheek" title="Cheek" id="mwAyw">cheek</a>-like organs to keep food in the mouth, and jaw motions to grind food.<sup about="#mwt544" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-FS04_120-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"FS04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-FS04-120" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 119;" id="mwAy0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAy4">[119]</span></a></sup> Another notable evolutionary event of the Jurassic was the appearance of true birds, descended from maniraptoran coelurosaurians.<sup about="#mwt545" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-KP04_12-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"KP04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-KP04-12" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 11;" id="mwAy8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwAzA">[11]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwAzE">By the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Early_Cretaceous" title="Early Cretaceous" id="mwAzI">Early Cretaceous</a> and the ongoing breakup of Pangaea, dinosaurs were becoming strongly differentiated by landmass. The earliest part of this time saw the spread of ankylosaurians, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Iguanodontia" title="Iguanodontia" id="mwAzM">iguanodontians</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Brachiosauridae" title="Brachiosauridae" id="mwAzQ">brachiosaurids</a> through Europe, North America, and northern <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Africa" title="Africa" id="mwAzU">Africa</a>. These were later supplemented or replaced in Africa by large spinosaurid and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carcharodontosauridae" title="Carcharodontosauridae" id="mwAzY">carcharodontosaurid</a> theropods, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rebbachisauridae" title="Rebbachisauridae" id="mwAzc">rebbachisaurid</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Titanosauria" title="Titanosauria" id="mwAzg">titanosaurian</a> sauropods, also found in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./South_America" title="South America" id="mwAzk">South America</a>. In <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Asia" title="Asia" id="mwAzo">Asia</a>, maniraptoran coelurosaurians like dromaeosaurids, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Troodontidae" title="Troodontidae" id="mwAzs">troodontids</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oviraptorosauria" title="Oviraptorosauria" id="mwAzw">oviraptorosaurians</a> became the common theropods, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ankylosauridae" title="Ankylosauridae" id="mwAz0">ankylosaurids</a> and early ceratopsians like <i id="mwAz4">Psittacosaurus</i> became important herbivores. Meanwhile, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Australia" title="Australia" id="mwAz8">Australia</a> was home to a fauna of basal ankylosaurians, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hypsilophodont" title="Hypsilophodont" id="mwA0A">hypsilophodonts</a>, and iguanodontians.<sup about="#mwt549" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-HCL04_119-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"HCL04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-HCL04-119" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 118;" id="mwA0E"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA0I">[118]</span></a></sup> The stegosaurians appear to have gone extinct at some point in the late Early Cretaceous or early <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Late_Cretaceous" title="Late Cretaceous" id="mwA0M">Late Cretaceous</a>. A major change in the Early Cretaceous, which would be amplified in the Late Cretaceous, was the evolution of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Flowering_plant" title="Flowering plant" id="mwA0Q">flowering plants</a>. At the same time, several groups of dinosaurian herbivores evolved more sophisticated ways to orally process food. Ceratopsians developed a method of slicing with teeth stacked on each other in batteries, and iguanodontians refined a method of grinding with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dinosaur_tooth#Dental_batteries" title="Dinosaur tooth" id="mwA0U">dental batteries</a>, taken to its extreme in hadrosaurids.<sup about="#mwt550" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-FS04_120-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"FS04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-FS04-120" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 119;" id="mwA0Y"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA0c">[119]</span></a></sup> Some sauropods also evolved tooth batteries, best exemplified by the rebbachisaurid <i id="mwA0g"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nigersaurus" title="Nigersaurus" id="mwA0k">Nigersaurus</a></i>.<sup about="#mwt551" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-serenoetal07_121-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"serenoetal07"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-serenoetal07-121" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 120;" id="mwA0o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA0s">[120]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA0w">There were three general dinosaur faunas in the Late Cretaceous. In the northern continents of North America and Asia, the major theropods were tyrannosaurids and various types of smaller maniraptoran theropods, with a predominantly ornithischian herbivore assemblage of hadrosaurids, ceratopsians, ankylosaurids, and pachycephalosaurians. In the southern continents that had made up the now-splitting supercontinent <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gondwana" title="Gondwana" id="mwA00">Gondwana</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abelisauridae" title="Abelisauridae" id="mwA04">abelisaurids</a> were the common theropods, and titanosaurian sauropods the common herbivores. Finally, in Europe, dromaeosaurids, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rhabdodontidae" title="Rhabdodontidae" id="mwA08">rhabdodontid</a> iguanodontians, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nodosauridae" title="Nodosauridae" id="mwA1A">nodosaurid</a> ankylosaurians, and titanosaurian sauropods were prevalent.<sup about="#mwt556" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-HCL04_119-3" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"HCL04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-HCL04-119" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 118;" id="mwA1E"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA1I">[118]</span></a></sup> Flowering plants were greatly radiating,<sup about="#mwt557" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-FS04_120-3" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"FS04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-FS04-120" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 119;" id="mwA1M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA1Q">[119]</span></a></sup> with the first grasses appearing by the end of the Cretaceous.<sup about="#mwt558" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-PSAS05_122-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"PSAS05"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-PSAS05-122" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 121;" id="mwA1U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA1Y">[121]</span></a></sup> Grinding hadrosaurids and shearing ceratopsians became very diverse across North America and Asia. Theropods were also radiating as herbivores or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Omnivore" title="Omnivore" id="mwA1c">omnivores</a>, with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Therizinosauria" title="Therizinosauria" id="mwA1g">therizinosaurians</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ornithomimosauria" title="Ornithomimosauria" id="mwA1k">ornithomimosaurians</a> becoming common.<sup about="#mwt559" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-FS04_120-4" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"FS04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-FS04-120" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 119;" id="mwA1o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA1s">[119]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA1w">The Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event, which occurred approximately 66<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwA10"> </span>million years ago at the end of the Cretaceous, caused the extinction of all dinosaur groups except for the neornithine birds. Some other diapsid groups, including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crocodilia" title="Crocodilia" id="mwA14">crocodilians</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dyrosauridae" title="Dyrosauridae" id="mwA18">dyrosaurs</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sebecosuchia" title="Sebecosuchia" id="mwA2A">sebecosuchians</a>, turtles, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lizard" title="Lizard" id="mwA2E">lizards</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Snake" title="Snake" id="mwA2I">snakes</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rhynchocephalia" title="Rhynchocephalia" id="mwA2M">sphenodontians</a>, and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Choristodera" title="Choristodera" id="mwA2Q">choristoderans</a>, also survived the event.<sup about="#mwt561" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-AF04_123-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"AF04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-AF04-123" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 122;" id="mwA2U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA2Y">[122]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA2c">The surviving lineages of neornithine birds, including the ancestors of modern <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ratite" title="Ratite" id="mwA2g">ratites</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fowl" title="Fowl" id="mwA2k">ducks and chickens</a>, and a variety of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Charadriiformes" title="Charadriiformes" id="mwA2o">waterbirds</a>, diversified rapidly at the beginning of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paleogene" title="Paleogene" id="mwA2s">Paleogene</a> period, entering <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ecological_niche" title="Ecological niche" id="mwA2w">ecological niches</a> left vacant by the extinction of Mesozoic dinosaur groups such as the arboreal <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Enantiornithine" title="Enantiornithine" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA20">enantiornithines</a>, aquatic <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hesperornithine" title="Hesperornithine" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA24">hesperornithines</a>, and even the larger terrestrial theropods (in the form of <i id="mwA28"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gastornis" title="Gastornis" id="mwA3A">Gastornis</a></i>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eogruidae" title="Eogruidae" id="mwA3E">eogruiids</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bathornithids" title="Bathornithids" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA3I">bathornithids</a>, ratites, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Geranoididae" title="Geranoididae" id="mwA3M">geranoidids</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mihirung" title="Mihirung" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA3Q">mihirungs</a>, and "<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Terror_bird" title="Terror bird" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA3U">terror birds</a>"). It is often stated that mammals out-competed the neornithines for dominance of most terrestrial niches but many of these groups co-existed with rich mammalian faunas for most of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cenozoic" title="Cenozoic" id="mwA3Y">Cenozoic</a> Era.<sup about="#mwt569" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-lindow_124-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"lindow"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-lindow-124"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-lindow-124" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 123;" id="mwA3c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA3g">[123]</span></a></sup> Terror birds and bathornithids occupied carnivorous guilds alongside predatory mammals,<sup about="#mwt573" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Cracraft_125-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Cracraft"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Cracraft-125"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Cracraft-125" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 124;" id="mwA3k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA3o">[124]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt577" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-126" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-126"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-126" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 125;" id="mwA3s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA3w">[125]</span></a></sup> and ratites are still fairly successful as mid-sized herbivores; eogruiids similarly lasted from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eocene" title="Eocene" id="mwA30">Eocene</a> to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pliocene" title="Pliocene" id="mwA34">Pliocene</a>, only becoming extinct very recently after over 20<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwA38"> </span>million years of co-existence with many mammal groups.<sup about="#mwt579" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-127" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-127"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-127" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 126;" id="mwA4A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA4E">[126]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="13" id="mwA4I"><h2 id="Classification">Classification</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt580" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Dinosaur classification"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA4M"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt580" id="mwA4Q">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dinosaur_classification" title="Dinosaur classification">Dinosaur classification</a></div>

<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" about="#mwt583" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" class="tsingle" style="width:148px;max-width:148px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:130px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="./File:Ornithischia_pelvis.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" resource="./File:Ornithischia_pelvis.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Ornithischia_pelvis.png/146px-Ornithischia_pelvis.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="580" data-file-height="520" data-file-type="bitmap" height="131" width="146" title="Ornithischia">Ornithischian</a> pelvis structure (left side)</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:190px;max-width:190px"><div class="thumbimage"
