src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Edmontosaurus_pelvis_left.jpg/188px-Edmontosaurus_pelvis_left.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1784" data-file-type="bitmap" height="131" width="188" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Edmontosaurus_pelvis_left.jpg/282px-Edmontosaurus_pelvis_left.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Edmontosaurus_pelvis_left.jpg/376px-Edmontosaurus_pelvis_left.jpg 2x"/></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption"><i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Edmontosaurus" title="Edmontosaurus">Edmontosaurus</a></i> pelvis (showing ornithischian structure<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>– left side)</div></div></div></div></div><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Pages_using_multiple_image_with_auto_scaled_images" about="#mwt583" id="mwA4Y"/>

<p id="mwA4c">Dinosaurs belong to a group known as archosaurs, which also includes modern crocodilians. Within the archosaur group, dinosaurs are differentiated most noticeably by their gait. Dinosaur legs extend directly beneath the body, whereas the legs of lizards and crocodilians sprawl out to either side.<sup about="#mwt587" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-B012_28-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"B012"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-B012-28" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 27;" id="mwA4g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA4k">[27]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA4o">Collectively, dinosaurs as a clade are divided into two primary branches, Saurischia and Ornithischia. Saurischia includes those taxa sharing a more recent common ancestor with birds than with Ornithischia, while Ornithischia includes all <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Taxon" title="Taxon" id="mwA4s">taxa</a> sharing a more recent common ancestor with <i id="mwA4w">Triceratops</i> than with Saurischia. Anatomically, these two groups can be distinguished most noticeably by their <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pelvis" title="Pelvis" id="mwA40">pelvic</a> structure. Early saurischians—"lizard-hipped", from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek" id="mwA44">Greek</a> <i id="mwA48"><span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text" about="#mwt595" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"grc-Latn"},"2":{"wt":"sauros"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA5A"><i lang="grc-Latn">sauros</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Ancient_Greek_(to_1453)-language_text" about="#mwt595" id="mwA5E"/></i> (<span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text" about="#mwt596" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"grc"},"2":{"wt":"σαῦρος"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA5I"><span lang="grc">σαῦρος</span></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Ancient_Greek_(to_1453)-language_text" about="#mwt596" id="mwA5M"/>) meaning "lizard" and <i id="mwA5Q"><span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text" about="#mwt597" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"grc-Latn"},"2":{"wt":"ischion"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA5U"><i lang="grc-Latn">ischion</i></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Ancient_Greek_(to_1453)-language_text" about="#mwt597" id="mwA5Y"/></i> (<span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text" about="#mwt598" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"lang","href":"./Template:Lang"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"grc"},"2":{"wt":"ἰσχίον"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwA5c"><span lang="grc">ἰσχίον</span></span><link rel="mw:PageProp/Category" href="./Category:Articles_containing_Ancient_Greek_(to_1453)-language_text" about="#mwt598" id="mwA5g"/>) meaning "hip joint"—retained the hip structure of their ancestors, with a pubis bone directed <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Anatomical_terms_of_location" title="Anatomical terms of location" id="mwA5k">cranially</a>, or forward.<sup about="#mwt599" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MJB00_35-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MJB00"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-MJB00-35" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 34;" id="mwA5o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA5s">[34]</span></a></sup> This basic form was modified by rotating the pubis backward to varying degrees in several groups (<i id="mwA5w">Herrerasaurus</i>,<sup about="#mwt600" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-GSP88_128-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"GSP88"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-GSP88-128" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 127;" id="mwA50"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA54">[127]</span></a></sup> therizinosauroids,<sup about="#mwt601" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-clarketal2004_129-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"clarketal2004"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-clarketal2004-129" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 128;" id="mwA58"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA6A">[128]</span></a></sup> dromaeosaurids,<sup about="#mwt602" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-MAPM04_130-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"MAPM04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-MAPM04-130" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 129;" id="mwA6E"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA6I">[129]</span></a></sup> and birds<sup about="#mwt603" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-KP04_12-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"KP04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-KP04-12" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 11;" id="mwA6M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA6Q">[11]</span></a></sup>). Saurischia includes the theropods (exclusively bipedal and with a wide variety of diets) and sauropodomorphs (long-necked herbivores which include advanced, quadrupedal groups).<sup about="#mwt604" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-theropods_27-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"theropods"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-theropods-27" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 26;" id="mwA6U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA6Y">[26]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt608" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sauropodomorphs_131-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sauropodomorphs"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-sauropodomorphs-131"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-sauropodomorphs-131" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 130;" id="mwA6c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA6g">[130]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwA6k">By contrast, ornithischians—"bird-hipped", from the Greek <i id="mwA6o">ornitheios</i> (ὀρνίθειος) meaning "of a bird" and <i id="mwA6s">ischion</i> (ἰσχίον) meaning "hip joint"—had a pelvis that superficially resembled a bird's pelvis: the pubic bone was oriented caudally (rear-pointing). Unlike birds, the ornithischian pubis also usually had an additional forward-pointing process. Ornithischia includes a variety of species that were primarily herbivores.</p>

<p id="mwA6w">Despite the terms "bird hip" (Ornithischia) and "lizard hip" (Saurischia), birds are not part of Ornithischia. Birds instead belong to Saurischia, the “lizard-hipped” dinosaurs—birds evolved from earlier dinosaurs with "lizard hips".<sup about="#mwt610" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-B012_28-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"B012"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-B012-28" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 27;" id="mwA60"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA64">[27]</span></a></sup></p>

<section data-mw-section-id="14" id="mwA68"><h3 id="Taxonomy">Taxonomy</h3>
<p id="mwA7A">The following is a simplified classification of dinosaur groups based on their evolutionary relationships, and those of the main dinosaur groups Theropoda, Sauropodomorpha and Ornithischia, compiled by Justin Tweet.<sup about="#mwt615" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-132" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-132"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-132" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 131;" id="mwA7E"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwA7I">[131]</span></a></sup> Further details and other hypotheses of classification may be found on individual articles.</p>

<ul id="mwA7M"><li id="mwA7Q">Dinosauria</li></ul>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwA7U"><a href="./File:Ornithopods_jconway.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwA7Y"><img resource="./File:Ornithopods_jconway.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Ornithopods_jconway.jpg/220px-Ornithopods_jconway.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="660" data-file-height="330" data-file-type="bitmap" height="110" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Ornithopods_jconway.jpg/330px-Ornithopods_jconway.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Ornithopods_jconway.jpg/440px-Ornithopods_jconway.jpg 2x" id="mwA7c"/></a><figcaption id="mwA7g">Restoration of six <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ornithopoda" title="Ornithopoda" id="mwA7k">ornithopods</a>; far left: <i id="mwA7o"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Camptosaurus" title="Camptosaurus" id="mwA7s">Camptosaurus</a></i>, left: <i id="mwA7w"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Iguanodon" title="Iguanodon" id="mwA70">Iguanodon</a></i>, center background: <i id="mwA74"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shantungosaurus" title="Shantungosaurus" id="mwA78">Shantungosaurus</a></i>, center foreground: <i id="mwA8A"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dryosaurus" title="Dryosaurus" id="mwA8E">Dryosaurus</a></i>, right: <i id="mwA8I"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Corythosaurus" title="Corythosaurus" id="mwA8M">Corythosaurus</a></i>, far right (large) <i id="mwA8Q"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tenontosaurus" title="Tenontosaurus" id="mwA8U">Tenontosaurus</a></i>.</figcaption></figure>
<dl id="mwA8Y"><dd id="mwA8c"><ul id="mwA8g"><li id="mwA8k">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ornithischia" title="Ornithischia" id="mwA8o">Ornithischia</a> ("bird-hipped"; diverse bipedal and quadrupedal herbivores)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwA8s"><dd id="mwA8w"><ul id="mwA80"><li id="mwA84">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Heterodontosauridae" title="Heterodontosauridae" id="mwA88">Heterodontosauridae</a> (small herbivores/omnivores with prominent <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Canine_tooth" title="Canine tooth" id="mwA9A">canine-like teeth</a>)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwA9E"><dd id="mwA9I"><ul id="mwA9M"><li id="mwA9Q">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Genasauria" title="Genasauria" id="mwA9U">Genasauria</a> ("cheeked lizards")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwA9Y"><dd id="mwA9c"><ul id="mwA9g"><li id="mwA9k">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thyreophora" title="Thyreophora" id="mwA9o">Thyreophora</a> (armored dinosaurs; bipeds and quadrupeds)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwA9s"><dd id="mwA9w"><ul id="mwA90"><li id="mwA94">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eurypoda" title="Eurypoda" class="mw-redirect" id="mwA98">Eurypoda</a> (heavy, quadrupedal thyreophorans)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwA-A"><dd id="mwA-E"><ul id="mwA-I"><li id="mwA-M">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stegosauria" title="Stegosauria" id="mwA-Q">Stegosauria</a> (spikes and plates as primary armor)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwA-U"><dd id="mwA-Y"><ul id="mwA-c"><li id="mwA-g">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Huayangosauridae" title="Huayangosauridae" id="mwA-k">Huayangosauridae</a> (small stegosaurs with flank osteoderms and tail clubs)</li>
<li id="mwA-o">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stegosauridae" title="Stegosauridae" id="mwA-s">Stegosauridae</a> (large stegosaurs)</li></ul></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwA-w"><li id="mwA-0">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ankylosauria" title="Ankylosauria" id="mwA-4">Ankylosauria</a> (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scute" title="Scute" id="mwA-8">scutes</a> as primary armor)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwA_A"><dd id="mwA_E"><ul id="mwA_I"><li id="mwA_M">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Parankylosauria" title="Parankylosauria" id="mwA_Q">Parankylosauria</a> (small, southern ankylosaurs with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Macuahuitl" title="Macuahuitl" id="mwA_U">macuahuitl</a>-like tails)</li>
<li id="mwA_Y">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nodosauridae" title="Nodosauridae" id="mwA_c">Nodosauridae</a> (mostly spiky, club-less ankylosaurs)</li>
<li id="mwA_g">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ankylosauridae" title="Ankylosauridae" id="mwA_k">Ankylosauridae</a> (characterized by flat scutes)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwA_o"><dd id="mwA_s"><ul id="mwA_w"><li id="mwA_0">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ankylosaurinae" title="Ankylosaurinae" id="mwA_4">Ankylosaurinae</a> (club-tailed ankylosaurids)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwA_8"><li id="mwBAA">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neornithischia" title="Neornithischia" id="mwBAE">Neornithischia</a> ("new ornithischians")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBAI"><dd id="mwBAM"><ul id="mwBAQ"><li id="mwBAU">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cerapoda" title="Cerapoda" id="mwBAY">Cerapoda</a> ("horned feet")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBAc"><dd id="mwBAg"><ul id="mwBAk"><li id="mwBAo">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Marginocephalia" title="Marginocephalia" id="mwBAs">Marginocephalia</a> (characterized by a cranial growth)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBAw"><a href="./File:Ceratopsidae-BW-003.png" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBA0"><img resource="./File:Ceratopsidae-BW-003.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Ceratopsidae-BW-003.png/220px-Ceratopsidae-BW-003.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="1385" data-file-height="830" data-file-type="bitmap" height="132" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Ceratopsidae-BW-003.png/330px-Ceratopsidae-BW-003.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Ceratopsidae-BW-003.png/440px-Ceratopsidae-BW-003.png 2x" id="mwBA4"/></a><figcaption id="mwBA8">Restoration of four <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ceratopsidae" title="Ceratopsidae" id="mwBBA">ceratopsids</a>: top left - <i id="mwBBE"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Triceratops" title="Triceratops" id="mwBBI">Triceratops</a></i>, top right - <i id="mwBBM"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Styracosaurus" title="Styracosaurus" id="mwBBQ">Styracosaurus</a></i>, bottom left - <i id="mwBBU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Anchiceratops" title="Anchiceratops" id="mwBBY">Anchiceratops</a></i>, bottom right - <i id="mwBBc"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chasmosaurus" title="Chasmosaurus" id="mwBBg">Chasmosaurus</a></i>.</figcaption></figure>
<dl id="mwBBk"><dd id="mwBBo"><dl id="mwBBs"><dd id="mwBBw"><dl id="mwBB0"><dd id="mwBB4"><dl id="mwBB8"><dd id="mwBCA"><dl id="mwBCE"><dd id="mwBCI"><dl id="mwBCM"><dd id="mwBCQ"><dl id="mwBCU"><dd id="mwBCY"><ul id="mwBCc"><li id="mwBCg">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pachycephalosauria" title="Pachycephalosauria" id="mwBCk">Pachycephalosauria</a> (bipeds with domed or knobby growth on skulls)</li>
<li id="mwBCo">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ceratopsia" title="Ceratopsia" id="mwBCs">Ceratopsia</a> (bipeds and quadrupeds; many had neck frills and horns)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBCw"><dd id="mwBC0"><ul id="mwBC4"><li id="mwBC8">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chaoyangsauridae" title="Chaoyangsauridae" id="mwBDA">Chaoyangsauridae</a> (small, frill-less basal ceratopsians)</li>
<li id="mwBDE">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neoceratopsia" title="Neoceratopsia" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBDI">Neoceratopsia</a> ("new ceratopsians")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBDM"><dd id="mwBDQ"><ul id="mwBDU"><li id="mwBDY">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Leptoceratopsidae" title="Leptoceratopsidae" id="mwBDc">Leptoceratopsidae</a> (little to no frills, hornless, with robust jaws)</li>
<li id="mwBDg">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Protoceratopsidae" title="Protoceratopsidae" id="mwBDk">Protoceratopsidae</a> (basal ceratopsians with small frills and stubby horns)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBDo"><dd id="mwBDs"><ul id="mwBDw"><li id="mwBD0">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ceratopsoidea" title="Ceratopsoidea" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBD4">Ceratopsoidea</a> (large-horned ceratopsians)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBD8"><dd id="mwBEA"><ul id="mwBEE"><li id="mwBEI">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ceratopsidae" title="Ceratopsidae" id="mwBEM">Ceratopsidae</a> (large, elaborately ornamented ceratopsians)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBEQ"><dd id="mwBEU"><ul id="mwBEY"><li id="mwBEc">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chasmosaurinae" title="Chasmosaurinae" id="mwBEg">Chasmosaurinae</a> (ceratopsids with enlarged brow horns)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBEk"><dd id="mwBEo"><ul id="mwBEs"><li id="mwBEw">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Triceratopsini" title="Triceratopsini" id="mwBE0">Triceratopsini</a> (very large chasmosaurines with long brow horns)</li></ul></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBE4"><li id="mwBE8">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Centrosaurinae" title="Centrosaurinae" id="mwBFA">Centrosaurinae</a> (ceratopsids mostly characterized by frill and nasal ornamentation)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBFE"><dd id="mwBFI"><ul id="mwBFM"><li id="mwBFQ">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nasutoceratopsini" title="Nasutoceratopsini" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBFU">Nasutoceratopsini</a> (centrosaurines with enlarged nasal cavities)</li>
<li id="mwBFY">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Centrosaurini" title="Centrosaurini" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBFc">Centrosaurini</a> (centrosaurines with enlarged nasal horns)</li>
<li id="mwBFg">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pachyrhinosaurini" title="Pachyrhinosaurini" id="mwBFk">Pachyrhinosaurini</a> (mostly had nasal bosses instead of horns)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBFo"><li id="mwBFs">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ornithopoda" title="Ornithopoda" id="mwBFw">Ornithopoda</a> (various sizes; bipeds and quadrupeds; evolved a method of chewing using skull flexibility and numerous teeth)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBF0"><dd id="mwBF4"><ul id="mwBF8"><li id="mwBGA">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jeholosauridae" title="Jeholosauridae" id="mwBGE">Jeholosauridae</a> (small Asian neornithischians)</li>
<li id="mwBGI">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thescelosauridae" title="Thescelosauridae" id="mwBGM">Thescelosauridae</a> ("wondrous lizards")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBGQ"><dd id="mwBGU"><ul id="mwBGY"><li id="mwBGc">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Orodrominae" title="Orodrominae" id="mwBGg">Orodrominae</a> (burrowers)</li>
<li id="mwBGk">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thescelosaurinae" title="Thescelosaurinae" id="mwBGo">Thescelosaurinae</a> (large thescelosaurids)</li></ul></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBGs"><li id="mwBGw">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Iguanodontia" title="Iguanodontia" id="mwBG0">Iguanodontia</a> ("iguana teeth"; advanced ornithopods)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBG4"><dd id="mwBG8"><ul id="mwBHA"><li id="mwBHE">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Elasmaria" title="Elasmaria" id="mwBHI">Elasmaria</a> (mostly southern ornithopods with mineralized plates along the ribs; may be thescelosaurids)</li>
<li id="mwBHM">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rhabdodontomorpha" title="Rhabdodontomorpha" id="mwBHQ">Rhabdodontomorpha</a> (with distinctive dentition)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBHU"><dd id="mwBHY"><ul id="mwBHc"><li id="mwBHg">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rhabdodontidae" title="Rhabdodontidae" id="mwBHk">Rhabdodontidae</a> (European rhabdodontomorphs)</li></ul></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBHo"><li id="mwBHs">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dryosauridae" title="Dryosauridae" id="mwBHw">Dryosauridae</a> (mid-sized, small headed)</li>
<li id="mwBH0">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Camptosauridae" title="Camptosauridae" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBH4">Camptosauridae</a> (mid-sized, stocky)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBH8"><dd id="mwBIA"><ul id="mwBIE"><li id="mwBII">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Styracosterna" title="Styracosterna" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBIM">Styracosterna</a> ("spiked <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sternum" title="Sternum" id="mwBIQ">sterna</a>")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBIU"><dd id="mwBIY"><ul id="mwBIc"><li id="mwBIg">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hadrosauriformes" title="Hadrosauriformes" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBIk">Hadrosauriformes</a> (ancestrally had a thumb spike)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBIo"><dd id="mwBIs"><ul id="mwBIw"><li id="mwBI0">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hadrosauroidea" title="Hadrosauroidea" id="mwBI4">Hadrosauroidea</a> (large quadrupedal herbivores, with teeth merged into dental batteries)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBI8"><dd id="mwBJA"><ul id="mwBJE"><li id="mwBJI">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hadrosauromorpha" title="Hadrosauromorpha" id="mwBJM">Hadrosauromorpha</a> (hadrosaurids and their closest relatives)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBJQ"><dd id="mwBJU"><ul id="mwBJY"><li id="mwBJc">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hadrosauridae" title="Hadrosauridae" id="mwBJg">Hadrosauridae</a> ("duck-billed dinosaurs"; often with crests)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBJk"><dd id="mwBJo"><ul id="mwBJs"><li id="mwBJw">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Saurolophinae" title="Saurolophinae" id="mwBJ0">Saurolophinae</a> (hadrosaurids with solid, small, no crests)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBJ4"><dd id="mwBJ8"><ul id="mwBKA"><li id="mwBKE">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Brachylophosaurini" title="Brachylophosaurini" id="mwBKI">Brachylophosaurini</a> (short-crested)</li>
<li id="mwBKM">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kritosaurini" title="Kritosaurini" id="mwBKQ">Kritosaurini</a> (enlarged, solid nasal crests)</li>
<li id="mwBKU">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Saurolophini" title="Saurolophini" id="mwBKY">Saurolophini</a> (small, spike-like crests)</li>
<li id="mwBKc">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Edmontosaurini" title="Edmontosaurini" id="mwBKg">Edmontosaurini</a> (flat-headed saurolophines)</li></ul></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBKk"><li id="mwBKo">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lambeosaurinae" title="Lambeosaurinae" id="mwBKs">Lambeosaurinae</a> (hadrosaurids often with hollow crests)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBKw"><dd id="mwBK0"><ul id="mwBK4"><li id="mwBK8">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aralosaurini" title="Aralosaurini" id="mwBLA">Aralosaurini</a> (solid-crested)</li>
<li id="mwBLE">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tsintaosaurini" title="Tsintaosaurini" id="mwBLI">Tsintaosaurini</a> (vertical, tube-like crests)</li>
<li id="mwBLM">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Parasaurolophini" title="Parasaurolophini" id="mwBLQ">Parasaurolophini</a> (long, backwards-arcing crests)</li>
<li id="mwBLU">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lambeosaurini" title="Lambeosaurini" id="mwBLY">Lambeosaurini</a> (usually rounded crests)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBLc"><li id="mwBLg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Saurischia" title="Saurischia" id="mwBLk">Saurischia</a></li></ul>
<dl id="mwBLo"><dd id="mwBLs"><ul id="mwBLw"><li id="mwBL0">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Herrerasauridae" title="Herrerasauridae" id="mwBL4">Herrerasauridae</a> (early bipedal carnivores)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBL8"><a href="./File:Macronaria_scrubbed_enh.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBMA"><img resource="./File:Macronaria_scrubbed_enh.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Macronaria_scrubbed_enh.jpg/220px-Macronaria_scrubbed_enh.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="582" data-file-type="bitmap" height="128" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Macronaria_scrubbed_enh.jpg/330px-Macronaria_scrubbed_enh.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Macronaria_scrubbed_enh.jpg/440px-Macronaria_scrubbed_enh.jpg 2x" id="mwBME"/></a><figcaption id="mwBMI">Restoration of four <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Macronaria" title="Macronaria" id="mwBMM">macronarian</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sauropoda" title="Sauropoda" id="mwBMQ">sauropods</a>: from left to right <i id="mwBMU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Camarasaurus" title="Camarasaurus" id="mwBMY">Camarasaurus</a></i>, <i id="mwBMc"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Brachiosaurus" title="Brachiosaurus" id="mwBMg">Brachiosaurus</a></i>, <i id="mwBMk"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Giraffatitan" title="Giraffatitan" id="mwBMo">Giraffatitan</a></i>, and <i id="mwBMs"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Euhelopus" title="Euhelopus" id="mwBMw">Euhelopus</a></i></figcaption></figure>
<dl id="mwBM0"><dd id="mwBM4"><dl id="mwBM8"><dd id="mwBNA"><ul id="mwBNE"><li id="mwBNI">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sauropodomorpha" title="Sauropodomorpha" id="mwBNM">Sauropodomorpha</a> (herbivores with small heads, long necks, and long tails)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBNQ"><dd id="mwBNU"><ul id="mwBNY"><li id="mwBNc">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Unaysauridae" title="Unaysauridae" id="mwBNg">Unaysauridae</a> (primitive, strictly bipedal "prosauropods")</li>
<li id="mwBNk">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Plateosauria" title="Plateosauria" id="mwBNo">Plateosauria</a> (diverse; bipeds and quadrupeds)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBNs"><dd id="mwBNw"><ul id="mwBN0"><li id="mwBN4">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Massospondylidae" title="Massospondylidae" id="mwBN8">Massospondylidae</a> (long-necked, primitive sauropodomorphs)</li>
<li id="mwBOA">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Riojasauridae" title="Riojasauridae" id="mwBOE">Riojasauridae</a> (large, primitive sauropodomorphs)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBOI"><dd id="mwBOM"><ul id="mwBOQ"><li id="mwBOU">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sauropodiformes" title="Sauropodiformes" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBOY">Sauropodiformes</a> (heavy, bipeds and quadrupeds)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBOc"><dd id="mwBOg"><ul id="mwBOk"><li id="mwBOo">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sauropoda" title="Sauropoda" id="mwBOs">Sauropoda</a> (very large and heavy; quadrupedal)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBOw"><dd id="mwBO0"><ul id="mwBO4"><li id="mwBO8">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lessemsauridae" title="Lessemsauridae" id="mwBPA">Lessemsauridae</a> (gigantic yet lacking several weight-saving adaptations)</li>
<li id="mwBPE">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gravisauria" title="Gravisauria" id="mwBPI">Gravisauria</a> ("heavy lizards")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBPM"><dd id="mwBPQ"><ul id="mwBPU"><li id="mwBPY">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eusauropoda" title="Eusauropoda" id="mwBPc">Eusauropoda</a> ("true sauropods")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBPg"><dd id="mwBPk"><ul id="mwBPo"><li id="mwBPs">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Turiasauria" title="Turiasauria" id="mwBPw">Turiasauria</a> (often large, widespread sauropods)</li>
<li id="mwBP0">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neosauropoda" title="Neosauropoda" id="mwBP4">Neosauropoda</a> ("new sauropods"; columnar limbs)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBP8"><dd id="mwBQA"><ul id="mwBQE"><li id="mwBQI">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diplodocoidea" title="Diplodocoidea" id="mwBQM">Diplodocoidea</a> (skulls and tails elongated; teeth typically narrow and pencil-like)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBQQ"><dd id="mwBQU"><ul id="mwBQY"><li id="mwBQc">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rebbachisauridae" title="Rebbachisauridae" id="mwBQg">Rebbachisauridae</a> (short-necked, low-browsing diplodocoids often with high backs)</li>
<li id="mwBQk">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Flagellicaudata" title="Flagellicaudata" id="mwBQo">Flagellicaudata</a> (whip-tailed)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBQs"><dd id="mwBQw"><ul id="mwBQ0"><li id="mwBQ4">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dicraeosauridae" title="Dicraeosauridae" id="mwBQ8">Dicraeosauridae</a> (small, short-necked diplodocoids with enlarged cervical and dorsal vertebrae)</li>
<li id="mwBRA">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diplodocidae" title="Diplodocidae" id="mwBRE">Diplodocidae</a> (extremely long-necked)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBRI"><dd id="mwBRM"><ul id="mwBRQ"><li id="mwBRU">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Apatosaurinae" title="Apatosaurinae" id="mwBRY">Apatosaurinae</a> (robust cervical vertebrae)</li>
<li id="mwBRc">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diplodocinae" title="Diplodocinae" id="mwBRg">Diplodocinae</a> (long, thin necks)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBRk"><li id="mwBRo">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Macronaria" title="Macronaria" id="mwBRs">Macronaria</a> (boxy skulls; spoon- or pencil-shaped teeth)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBRw"><dd id="mwBR0"><ul id="mwBR4"><li id="mwBR8">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Titanosauriformes" title="Titanosauriformes" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBSA">Titanosauriformes</a> ("titan lizard forms")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBSE"><dd id="mwBSI"><ul id="mwBSM"><li id="mwBSQ">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Brachiosauridae" title="Brachiosauridae" id="mwBSU">Brachiosauridae</a> (long-necked, long-armed macronarians)</li>
<li id="mwBSY">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Somphospondyli" title="Somphospondyli" id="mwBSc">Somphospondyli</a> ("porous vertebrae")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBSg"><dd id="mwBSk"><ul id="mwBSo"><li id="mwBSs">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Euhelopodidae" title="Euhelopodidae" id="mwBSw">Euhelopodidae</a> (stocky, mostly Asian)</li>
<li id="mwBS0">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Titanosauria" title="Titanosauria" id="mwBS4">Titanosauria</a> (diverse; stocky, with wide hips; most common in the Late Cretaceous of southern continents)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBS8"><li id="mwBTA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Theropoda" title="Theropoda" id="mwBTE">Theropoda</a> (carnivorous)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBTI"><dd id="mwBTM"><ul id="mwBTQ"><li id="mwBTU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neotheropoda" title="Neotheropoda" id="mwBTY">Neotheropoda</a> ("new theropods")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBTc"><dd id="mwBTg"><ul id="mwBTk"><li id="mwBTo">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Coelophysoidea" title="Coelophysoidea" id="mwBTs">Coelophysoidea</a> (early theropods; includes <i id="mwBTw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Coelophysis" title="Coelophysis" id="mwBT0">Coelophysis</a></i> and close relatives)</li>
<li id="mwBT4">†"Dilophosaur-grade neotheropods" (larger kink-snouted dinosaurs)</li>
<li id="mwBT8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Averostra" title="Averostra" id="mwBUA">Averostra</a> ("bird snouts")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBUE"><dd id="mwBUI"><ul id="mwBUM"><li id="mwBUQ">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ceratosauria" title="Ceratosauria" id="mwBUU">Ceratosauria</a> (generally elaborately horned carnivores that existed from the Jurassic to Cretaceous periods, originally included Coelophysoidea)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBUY"><dd id="mwBUc"><ul id="mwBUg"><li id="mwBUk">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ceratosauridae" title="Ceratosauridae" id="mwBUo">Ceratosauridae</a> (ceratosaurs with large teeth)</li>
<li id="mwBUs">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abelisauroidea" title="Abelisauroidea" id="mwBUw">Abelisauroidea</a> (ceratosaurs exemplified by reduced arms and hands)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBU0"><dd id="mwBU4"><ul id="mwBU8"><li id="mwBVA">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abelisauridae" title="Abelisauridae" id="mwBVE">Abelisauridae</a> (large abelisauroids with short arms and oftentimes elaborate facial ornamentation)</li>
<li id="mwBVI">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Noasauridae" title="Noasauridae" id="mwBVM">Noasauridae</a> (diverse, generally light theropods; may include several obscure taxa)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBVQ"><dd id="mwBVU"><ul id="mwBVY"><li id="mwBVc">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Elaphrosaurinae" title="Elaphrosaurinae" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBVg">Elaphrosaurinae</a> (bird-like; omnivorous as juveniles but herbivorous as adults)</li>
<li id="mwBVk">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Noasaurinae" title="Noasaurinae" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBVo">Noasaurinae</a> (small carnivores)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBVs"><li id="mwBVw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tetanurae" title="Tetanurae" id="mwBV0">Tetanurae</a> (stiff-tailed dinosaurs)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBV4"><dd id="mwBV8"><ul id="mwBWA"><li id="mwBWE">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Megalosauroidea" title="Megalosauroidea" id="mwBWI">Megalosauroidea</a> (early group of large carnivores)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBWM"><dd id="mwBWQ"><ul id="mwBWU"><li id="mwBWY">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Piatnitzkysauridae" title="Piatnitzkysauridae" id="mwBWc">Piatnitzkysauridae</a> (small basal megalosauroids endemic to the Americas)</li>
<li id="mwBWg">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Megalosauridae" title="Megalosauridae" id="mwBWk">Megalosauridae</a> (large megalosauroids with powerful arms and hands)</li>
<li id="mwBWo">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spinosauridae" title="Spinosauridae" id="mwBWs">Spinosauridae</a> (crocodile-like, semiaquatic carnivores)</li></ul></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBWw"><li id="mwBW0"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Avetheropoda" title="Avetheropoda" id="mwBW4">Avetheropoda</a> ("bird theropods")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBW8"><dd id="mwBXA"><ul id="mwBXE"><li id="mwBXI">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Megaraptora" title="Megaraptora" id="mwBXM">Megaraptora</a> (theropods with large hand claws; either carnosaurs or coelurosaurs, potentially tyrannosauroids)</li>
<li id="mwBXQ">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnosauria" title="Carnosauria" id="mwBXU">Carnosauria</a> (large meat-eating dinosaurs; megalosauroids sometimes included)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBXY"><dd id="mwBXc"><ul id="mwBXg"><li id="mwBXk">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Metriacanthosauridae" title="Metriacanthosauridae" id="mwBXo">Metriacanthosauridae</a> (primitive Asian allosauroids)</li>
<li id="mwBXs">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Allosauridae" title="Allosauridae" id="mwBXw">Allosauridae</a> (<i id="mwBX0"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Allosaurus" title="Allosaurus" id="mwBX4">Allosaurus</a></i> and its very closest relatives)</li>
<li id="mwBX8">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carcharodontosauria" title="Carcharodontosauria" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBYA">Carcharodontosauria</a> (robust allosauroids)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBYE"><dd id="mwBYI"><ul id="mwBYM"><li id="mwBYQ">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carcharodontosauridae" title="Carcharodontosauridae" id="mwBYU">Carcharodontosauridae</a> (includes some of the largest purely terrestrial carnivores)</li>
<li id="mwBYY">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neovenatoridae" title="Neovenatoridae" id="mwBYc">Neovenatoridae</a> ("new hunters"; may include megaraptorans)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBYg"><li id="mwBYk"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Coelurosauria" title="Coelurosauria" id="mwBYo">Coelurosauria</a> (feathered theropods, with a range of body sizes and niches)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBYs"><dd id="mwBYw"><ul id="mwBY0"><li id="mwBY4">†"Nexus of basal coelurosaurs" (used by Tweet to denote well-known taxa with unstable positions at the base of Coelurosauria)</li>
<li id="mwBY8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tyrannoraptora" title="Tyrannoraptora" id="mwBZA">Tyrannoraptora</a> ("tyrant thieves")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBZE"><dd id="mwBZI"><ul id="mwBZM"><li id="mwBZQ">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Compsognathidae" title="Compsognathidae" id="mwBZU">Compsognathidae</a> (small early coelurosaurs with short forelimbs)</li>
<li id="mwBZY">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tyrannosauroidea" title="Tyrannosauroidea" id="mwBZc">Tyrannosauroidea</a> (mostly large, primitive coelurosaurs)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBZg"><dd id="mwBZk"><ul id="mwBZo"><li id="mwBZs">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Proceratosauridae" title="Proceratosauridae" id="mwBZw">Proceratosauridae</a> (tyrannosauroids with head crests)</li>
<li id="mwBZ0">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tyrannosauridae" title="Tyrannosauridae" id="mwBZ4">Tyrannosauridae</a> (<i id="mwBZ8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tyrannosaurus" title="Tyrannosaurus" id="mwBaA">Tyrannosaurus</a></i> and close relatives)</li></ul></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBaE"><li id="mwBaI"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Maniraptoriformes" title="Maniraptoriformes" id="mwBaM">Maniraptoriformes</a> (bird-like dinosaurs)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBaQ"><dd id="mwBaU"><ul id="mwBaY"><li id="mwBac">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ornithomimosauria" title="Ornithomimosauria" id="mwBag">Ornithomimosauria</a> (small-headed, mostly toothless, omnivorous or possible herbivores)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBak"><dd id="mwBao"><ul id="mwBas"><li id="mwBaw">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ornithomimidae" title="Ornithomimidae" id="mwBa0">Ornithomimidae</a> (very ostrich-like dinosaurs)</li></ul></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBa4"><li id="mwBa8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Maniraptora" title="Maniraptora" id="mwBbA">Maniraptora</a> (dinosaurs with pennaceous feathers)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBbE"><a href="./File:Dromaeosaurs.png" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBbI"><img resource="./File:Dromaeosaurs.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Dromaeosaurs.png/220px-Dromaeosaurs.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="6369" data-file-height="2336" data-file-type="bitmap" height="81" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Dromaeosaurs.png/330px-Dromaeosaurs.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Dromaeosaurs.png/440px-Dromaeosaurs.png 2x" id="mwBbM"/></a><figcaption id="mwBbQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paleoart" title="Paleoart" id="mwBbU">Restoration</a> of six <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dromaeosauridae" title="Dromaeosauridae" id="mwBbY">dromaeosaurid</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Theropoda" title="Theropoda" id="mwBbc">theropods</a>: from left to right <i id="mwBbg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Microraptor" title="Microraptor" id="mwBbk">Microraptor</a></i>, <i id="mwBbo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Velociraptor" title="Velociraptor" id="mwBbs">Velociraptor</a></i>, <i id="mwBbw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Austroraptor" title="Austroraptor" id="mwBb0">Austroraptor</a></i>, <i id="mwBb4"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dromaeosaurus" title="Dromaeosaurus" id="mwBb8">Dromaeosaurus</a></i>, <i id="mwBcA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Utahraptor" title="Utahraptor" id="mwBcE">Utahraptor</a></i>, and <i id="mwBcI"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deinonychus" title="Deinonychus" id="mwBcM">Deinonychus</a></i></figcaption></figure>
<dl id="mwBcQ"><dd id="mwBcU"><dl id="mwBcY"><dd id="mwBcc"><dl id="mwBcg"><dd id="mwBck"><dl id="mwBco"><dd id="mwBcs"><dl id="mwBcw"><dd id="mwBc0"><dl id="mwBc4"><dd id="mwBc8"><dl id="mwBdA"><dd id="mwBdE"><dl id="mwBdI"><dd id="mwBdM"><dl id="mwBdQ"><dd id="mwBdU"><dl id="mwBdY"><dd id="mwBdc"><dl id="mwBdg"><dd id="mwBdk"><ul id="mwBdo"><li id="mwBds">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Alvarezsauroidea" title="Alvarezsauroidea" id="mwBdw">Alvarezsauroidea</a> (small hunters with reduced forelimbs)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBd0"><dd id="mwBd4"><ul id="mwBd8"><li id="mwBeA">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Alvarezsauridae" title="Alvarezsauridae" id="mwBeE">Alvarezsauridae</a> (insectivores with only one enlarged digit)</li></ul></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBeI"><li id="mwBeM">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Therizinosauria" title="Therizinosauria" id="mwBeQ">Therizinosauria</a> (tall, long-necked theropods; omnivores and herbivores)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBeU"><dd id="mwBeY"><ul id="mwBec"><li id="mwBeg">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Therizinosauroidea" title="Therizinosauroidea" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBek">Therizinosauroidea</a> (larger therizinosaurs)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBeo"><dd id="mwBes"><ul id="mwBew"><li id="mwBe0">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Therizinosauridae" title="Therizinosauridae" id="mwBe4">Therizinosauridae</a> (sloth-like herbivores, often with enlarged claws)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBe8"><li id="mwBfA">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oviraptorosauria" title="Oviraptorosauria" id="mwBfE">Oviraptorosauria</a> (omnivorous, beaked dinosaurs)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBfI"><dd id="mwBfM"><ul id="mwBfQ"><li id="mwBfU">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Caudipteridae" title="Caudipteridae" id="mwBfY">Caudipteridae</a> (bird-like, basal oviraptorosaurs)</li>
<li id="mwBfc">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Caenagnathoidea" title="Caenagnathoidea" id="mwBfg">Caenagnathoidea</a> (cassowary-like oviraptorosaurs)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBfk"><dd id="mwBfo"><ul id="mwBfs"><li id="mwBfw">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Caenagnathidae" title="Caenagnathidae" id="mwBf0">Caenagnathidae</a> (toothless oviraptorosaurs known from North America and Asia)</li>
<li id="mwBf4">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oviraptoridae" title="Oviraptoridae" id="mwBf8">Oviraptoridae</a> (characterized by two bony projections at the back of the mouth; exclusive to Asia)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBgA"><li id="mwBgE"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paraves" title="Paraves" id="mwBgI">Paraves</a> (avialans and their closest relatives)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBgM"><dd id="mwBgQ"><ul id="mwBgU"><li id="mwBgY">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scansoriopterygidae" title="Scansoriopterygidae" id="mwBgc">Scansoriopterygidae</a> (small tree-climbing theropods with membranous wings)</li>
<li id="mwBgg">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deinonychosauria" title="Deinonychosauria" id="mwBgk">Deinonychosauria</a> (toe-clawed dinosaurs; may not form a natural group)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBgo"><dd id="mwBgs"><ul id="mwBgw"><li id="mwBg0">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Archaeopterygidae" title="Archaeopterygidae" id="mwBg4">Archaeopterygidae</a> (small, winged theropods or primitive birds)</li>
<li id="mwBg8">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Troodontidae" title="Troodontidae" id="mwBhA">Troodontidae</a> (omnivores; enlarged brain cavities)</li>
<li id="mwBhE">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dromaeosauridae" title="Dromaeosauridae" id="mwBhI">Dromaeosauridae</a> ("raptors")</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBhM"><dd id="mwBhQ"><ul id="mwBhU"><li id="mwBhY">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Microraptoria" title="Microraptoria" id="mwBhc">Microraptoria</a> (characterized by large wings on both the arms and legs; may have been capable of powered flight)</li>
<li id="mwBhg">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Eudromaeosauria" title="Eudromaeosauria" id="mwBhk">Eudromaeosauria</a> (hunters with greatly enlarged sickle claws)</li></ul></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBho"><li id="mwBhs">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Unenlagiidae" title="Unenlagiidae" id="mwBhw">Unenlagiidae</a> (piscivores; may be dromaeosaurids)</li></ul>
<dl id="mwBh0"><dd id="mwBh4"><ul id="mwBh8"><li id="mwBiA">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Halszkaraptorinae" title="Halszkaraptorinae" id="mwBiE">Halszkaraptorinae</a> (duck-like; potentially semiaquatic)</li>
<li id="mwBiI">†<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Unenlagiinae" title="Unenlagiinae" id="mwBiM">Unenlagiinae</a> (long-snouted)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl>
<ul id="mwBiQ"><li id="mwBiU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Avialae" title="Avialae" id="mwBiY">Avialae</a> (modern birds and extinct relatives)</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl></dd></dl>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="15" id="mwBic"><h3 id="Timeline_of_major_groups">Timeline of major groups</h3>

<p id="mwBig">Timeline of major dinosaur groups per Holtz (2007).</p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="16" id="mwBio"><h2 id="Paleobiology">Paleobiology</h2>
<p id="mwBis">Knowledge about dinosaurs is derived from a variety of fossil and non-fossil records, including fossilized bones, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feces" title="Feces" id="mwBiw">feces</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fossil_trackway" title="Fossil trackway" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBi0">trackways</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gastrolith" title="Gastrolith" id="mwBi4">gastroliths</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feather" title="Feather" id="mwBi8">feathers</a>, impressions of skin, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Organ_(anatomy)" title="Organ (anatomy)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBjA">internal organs</a> and other <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Soft_tissue" title="Soft tissue" id="mwBjE">soft tissues</a>.<sup about="#mwt626" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-softtissue_88-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"softtissue"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-softtissue-88"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-softtissue-88" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 87;" id="mwBjI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBjM">[87]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt627" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Schweitzer2005_92-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Schweitzer2005"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Schweitzer2005-92" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 91;" id="mwBjQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBjU">[91]</span></a></sup> Many fields of study contribute to our understanding of dinosaurs, including <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Physics" title="Physics" id="mwBjY">physics</a> (especially <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biomechanics" title="Biomechanics" id="mwBjc">biomechanics</a>), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chemistry" title="Chemistry" id="mwBjg">chemistry</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Biology" title="Biology" id="mwBjk">biology</a>, and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Earth_science" title="Earth science" id="mwBjo">Earth sciences</a> (of which <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paleontology" title="Paleontology" id="mwBjs">paleontology</a> is a sub-discipline).<sup about="#mwt628" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-alexander2006_133-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"alexander2006"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-alexander2006-133" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 132;" id="mwBjw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBj0">[132]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt632" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-dinobiology_134-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"dinobiology"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-dinobiology-134"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-dinobiology-134" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 133;" id="mwBj4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBj8">[133]</span></a></sup> Two topics of particular interest and study have been dinosaur size and behavior.<sup about="#mwt634" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-135" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-135"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-135" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 134;" id="mwBkA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBkE">[134]</span></a></sup></p>

<section data-mw-section-id="17" id="mwBkI"><h3 id="Size">Size</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt635" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Dinosaur size"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBkM"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt635" id="mwBkQ">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dinosaur_size" title="Dinosaur size">Dinosaur size</a></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBkU"><a href="./File:Longest_dinosaur_by_clade.svg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBkY"><img alt="" resource="./File:Longest_dinosaur_by_clade.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Longest_dinosaur_by_clade.svg/320px-Longest_dinosaur_by_clade.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="3360" data-file-height="1150" data-file-type="drawing" height="110" width="320" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Longest_dinosaur_by_clade.svg/480px-Longest_dinosaur_by_clade.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Longest_dinosaur_by_clade.svg/640px-Longest_dinosaur_by_clade.svg.png 2x" id="mwBkc"/></a><figcaption id="mwBkg">Scale diagram comparing the average human to the longest known dinosaurs in five major <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Clade" title="Clade" id="mwBkk">clades</a>:<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" about="#mwt638" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#ae2032"},"2":{"wt":"[[Sauropoda]] (&apos;&apos;[[Supersaurus|Supersaurus vivianae]]&apos;&apos;)"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBko">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend" about="#mwt638" id="mwBks"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ae2032; color:white;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sauropoda" title="Sauropoda">Sauropoda</a> (<i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Supersaurus" title="Supersaurus">Supersaurus vivianae</a></i>)</div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt641" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#cc48cc"},"2":{"wt":"[[Ornithopod]]a (&apos;&apos;[[Shantungosaurus|Shantungosaurus giganteus]]&apos;&apos;)"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBkw"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt641" id="mwBk0"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#cc48cc; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ornithopod" title="Ornithopod" class="mw-redirect">Ornithopoda</a> (<i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shantungosaurus" title="Shantungosaurus">Shantungosaurus giganteus</a></i>)</div><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt644" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#50da50"},"2":{"wt":"[[Theropoda]] (&apos;&apos;[[Spinosaurus|Spinosaurus aegyptiacus]]&apos;&apos;)"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBk4"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt644" id="mwBk8"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#50da50; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Theropoda" title="Theropoda">Theropoda</a> (<i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spinosaurus" title="Spinosaurus">Spinosaurus aegyptiacus</a></i>)</div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt647" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#f8863b"},"2":{"wt":"[[Thyreophora]] (&apos;&apos;[[Stegosaurus|Stegosaurus ungulatus]]&apos;&apos;)"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBlA"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt647" id="mwBlE"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#f8863b; color:black;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thyreophora" title="Thyreophora">Thyreophora</a> (<i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Stegosaurus" title="Stegosaurus">Stegosaurus ungulatus</a></i>)</div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" about="#mwt650" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"legend","href":"./Template:Legend"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"#254c87"},"2":{"wt":"[[Marginocephalia]] (&apos;&apos;[[Triceratops|Triceratops prorsus]]&apos;&apos;)"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBlI"/><div class="legend" about="#mwt650" id="mwBlM"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#254c87; color:white;"><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Marginocephalia" title="Marginocephalia">Marginocephalia</a> (<i><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Triceratops" title="Triceratops">Triceratops prorsus</a></i>)</div></figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBlQ">Current evidence suggests that dinosaur average size varied through the Triassic, Early Jurassic, Late Jurassic and Cretaceous.<sup about="#mwt661" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Sereno1999_108-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Sereno1999"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Sereno1999-108" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 107;" id="mwBlU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBlY">[107]</span></a></sup> Predatory theropod dinosaurs, which occupied most terrestrial carnivore niches during the Mesozoic, most often fall into the <span about="#mwt657" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"100"},"2":{"wt":"to"},"3":{"wt":"1000"},"4":{"wt":"kg"},"5":{"wt":"lb"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"},"comma":{"wt":"gaps"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBlc">100 to </span><span style="white-space: nowrap" about="#mwt657">1<span style="margin-left: 0.25em">000</span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt657"> </span><span about="#mwt657">kg (220 to </span><span style="white-space: nowrap" about="#mwt657">2<span style="margin-left: 0.25em">200</span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt657"> </span><span about="#mwt657">lb)</span> category when sorted by estimated weight into categories based on <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Order_of_magnitude" title="Order of magnitude" id="mwBlg">order of magnitude</a>, whereas <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Holocene" title="Holocene" id="mwBlk">recent</a> predatory carnivoran mammals peak in the <span about="#mwt658" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"10"},"2":{"wt":"to"},"3":{"wt":"100"},"4":{"wt":"kg"},"5":{"wt":"lb"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBlo">10 to 100</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt658"> </span><span about="#mwt658">kg (22 to 220</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt658"> </span><span about="#mwt658">lb)</span> category.<sup about="#mwt662" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-JF93_136-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"JF93"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-JF93-136" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 135;" id="mwBls"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBlw">[135]</span></a></sup> The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mode_(statistics)" title="Mode (statistics)" id="mwBl0">mode</a> of Mesozoic dinosaur body masses is between <span about="#mwt659" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"1"},"2":{"wt":"to"},"3":{"wt":"10"},"4":{"wt":"MT"},"5":{"wt":"ST"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBl4">1 to 10 metric tons (1.1 to 11.0 short tons)</span>.<sup about="#mwt663" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Peczkis1994_137-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Peczkis1994"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Peczkis1994-137" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 136;" id="mwBl8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBmA">[136]</span></a></sup> This contrasts sharply with the average size of Cenozoic mammals, estimated by the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./National_Museum_of_Natural_History" title="National Museum of Natural History" id="mwBmE">National Museum of Natural History</a> as about <span about="#mwt660" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"2"},"2":{"wt":"to"},"3":{"wt":"5"},"4":{"wt":"kg"},"5":{"wt":"lb"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBmI">2 to 5</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt660"> </span><span about="#mwt660">kg (4.4 to 11.0</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt660"> </span><span about="#mwt660">lb)</span>.<sup about="#mwt664" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NMNH_138-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NMNH"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-NMNH-138" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 137;" id="mwBmM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBmQ">[137]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBmU">The sauropods were the largest and heaviest dinosaurs. For much of the dinosaur era, the smallest sauropods were larger than anything else in their habitat, and the largest was an order of magnitude more massive than anything else that has since walked the Earth. Giant prehistoric mammals such as <i id="mwBmY"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paraceratherium" title="Paraceratherium" id="mwBmc">Paraceratherium</a></i> (the largest land mammal ever) were dwarfed by the giant sauropods, and only modern whales approach or surpass them in size.<sup about="#mwt670" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sander2011_139-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sander2011"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-sander2011-139"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-sander2011-139" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 138;" id="mwBmg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBmk">[138]</span></a></sup> There are several proposed advantages for the large size of sauropods, including protection from predation, reduction of energy use, and longevity, but it may be that the most important advantage was dietary. Large animals are more efficient at digestion than small animals, because food spends more time in their digestive systems. This also permits them to subsist on food with lower nutritive value than smaller animals. Sauropod remains are mostly found in rock formations interpreted as dry or seasonally dry, and the ability to eat large quantities of low-nutrient browse would have been advantageous in such environments.<sup about="#mwt671" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-KC06_140-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"KC06"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-KC06-140" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 139;" id="mwBmo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBms">[139]</span></a></sup></p>

<section data-mw-section-id="18" id="mwBmw"><h4 id="Largest_and_smallest">Largest and smallest</h4>
<p id="mwBm0">Scientists will probably never be certain of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Largest_organisms" title="Largest organisms" id="mwBm4">largest and smallest dinosaurs</a> to have ever existed. This is because only a tiny percentage of animals were ever fossilized and most of these remain buried in the earth. Few of the specimens that are recovered are complete skeletons, and impressions of skin and other soft tissues are rare. Rebuilding a complete skeleton by comparing the size and morphology of bones to those of similar, better-known species is an inexact art, and reconstructing the muscles and other organs of the living animal is, at best, a process of educated guesswork.<sup about="#mwt674" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-141" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-141"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-141" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 140;" id="mwBm8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBnA">[140]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBnE"><a href="./File:Argentinosaurus_9.svg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBnI"><img resource="./File:Argentinosaurus_9.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Argentinosaurus_9.svg/220px-Argentinosaurus_9.svg.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="33384" data-file-height="13650" data-file-type="drawing" height="90" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Argentinosaurus_9.svg/330px-Argentinosaurus_9.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Argentinosaurus_9.svg/440px-Argentinosaurus_9.svg.png 2x" id="mwBnM"/></a><figcaption id="mwBnQ">Comparative size of <i id="mwBnU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Argentinosaurus" title="Argentinosaurus" id="mwBnY">Argentinosaurus</a></i> to the average human</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBnc">The tallest and heaviest dinosaur known from good skeletons is <i id="mwBng"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Giraffatitan" title="Giraffatitan" id="mwBnk">Giraffatitan brancai</a></i> (previously classified as a species of <i id="mwBno"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Brachiosaurus" title="Brachiosaurus" id="mwBns">Brachiosaurus</a></i>). Its remains were discovered in Tanzania between 1907 and 1912. Bones from several similar-sized individuals were incorporated into the skeleton now mounted and on display at the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Natural_History_Museum,_Berlin" title="Natural History Museum, Berlin" id="mwBnw">Museum für Naturkunde</a> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Berlin" title="Berlin" id="mwBn0">Berlin</a>;<sup about="#mwt689" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-EC68_142-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"EC68"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-EC68-142" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 141;" id="mwBn4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBn8">[141]</span></a></sup> this mount is <span about="#mwt680" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"12"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBoA">12 meters (39</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt680"> </span><span about="#mwt680">ft)</span> tall and <span about="#mwt681" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"21.8"},"2":{"wt":"to"},"3":{"wt":"22.5"},"4":{"wt":"m"},"5":{"wt":"ft"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBoE">21.8 to 22.5 meters (72 to 74</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt681"> </span><span about="#mwt681">ft)</span> long,<sup about="#mwt693" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-143" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-143"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-143" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 142;" id="mwBoI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBoM">[142]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt697" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-144" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-144"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-144" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 143;" id="mwBoQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBoU">[143]</span></a></sup> and would have belonged to an animal that weighed between <span style="white-space:nowrap" about="#mwt682" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"gaps","href":"./Template:Gaps"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"30"},"2":{"wt":"000"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBoY">30<span style="margin-left:0.25em">000</span></span> and <span style="white-space:nowrap" about="#mwt683" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"gaps","href":"./Template:Gaps"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"60"},"2":{"wt":"000"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBoc">60<span style="margin-left:0.25em">000</span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBog"> </span>kilograms (<span style="white-space:nowrap" about="#mwt684" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"gaps","href":"./Template:Gaps"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"70"},"2":{"wt":"000"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBok">70<span style="margin-left:0.25em">000</span></span> and <span style="white-space:nowrap" about="#mwt685" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"gaps","href":"./Template:Gaps"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"130"},"2":{"wt":"000"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBoo">130<span style="margin-left:0.25em">000</span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBos"> </span>lb). The longest complete dinosaur is the <span about="#mwt686" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"27"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBow">27 meters (89</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt686"> </span><span about="#mwt686">ft)</span> long <i id="mwBo0">Diplodocus</i>, which was discovered in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wyoming" title="Wyoming" id="mwBo4">Wyoming</a> in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./United_States" title="United States" id="mwBo8">United States</a> and displayed in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pittsburgh" title="Pittsburgh" id="mwBpA">Pittsburgh</a>'s <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carnegie_Museum_of_Natural_History" title="Carnegie Museum of Natural History" id="mwBpE">Carnegie Museum of Natural History</a> in 1907.<sup about="#mwt701" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-lucas04_145-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"lucas04"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-lucas04-145"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-lucas04-145" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 144;" id="mwBpI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBpM">[144]</span></a></sup> The longest dinosaur known from good fossil material is <i id="mwBpQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Patagotitan" title="Patagotitan" id="mwBpU">Patagotitan</a></i>: the skeleton mount in the American Museum of Natural History in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./New_York_City" title="New York City" id="mwBpY">New York</a> is <span about="#mwt687" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"37"},"2":{"wt":"meters"},"3":{"wt":"feet"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBpc">37 meters (121</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt687"> </span><span about="#mwt687">ft)</span> long. The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Museo_Carmen_Funes" title="Museo Carmen Funes" id="mwBpg">Museo Municipal Carmen Funes</a> in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Plaza_Huincul" title="Plaza Huincul" id="mwBpk">Plaza Huincul</a>, Argentina, has an <i id="mwBpo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Argentinosaurus" title="Argentinosaurus" id="mwBps">Argentinosaurus</a></i> reconstructed skeleton mount that is <span about="#mwt688" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"39.7"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"feet"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBpw">39.7 meters (130</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt688"> </span><span about="#mwt688">ft)</span> long.<sup about="#mwt705" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-plosone_146-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"plosone"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-plosone-146"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-plosone-146" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 145;" id="mwBp0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBp4">[145]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBp8"><a href="./File:Bee_hummingbird_(Mellisuga_helenae)_adult_male_in_flight-cropped.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBqA"><img resource="./File:Bee_hummingbird_(Mellisuga_helenae)_adult_male_in_flight-cropped.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Bee_hummingbird_%28Mellisuga_helenae%29_adult_male_in_flight-cropped.jpg/220px-Bee_hummingbird_%28Mellisuga_helenae%29_adult_male_in_flight-cropped.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="2334" data-file-height="2301" data-file-type="bitmap" height="217" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Bee_hummingbird_%28Mellisuga_helenae%29_adult_male_in_flight-cropped.jpg/330px-Bee_hummingbird_%28Mellisuga_helenae%29_adult_male_in_flight-cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Bee_hummingbird_%28Mellisuga_helenae%29_adult_male_in_flight-cropped.jpg/440px-Bee_hummingbird_%28Mellisuga_helenae%29_adult_male_in_flight-cropped.jpg 2x" id="mwBqE"/></a><figcaption id="mwBqI">An adult <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bee_hummingbird" title="Bee hummingbird" id="mwBqM">bee hummingbird</a>, the smallest known dinosaur</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBqQ">There were larger dinosaurs, but knowledge of them is based entirely on a small number of fragmentary fossils. Most of the largest herbivorous specimens on record were discovered in the 1970s or later, and include the massive <i id="mwBqU">Argentinosaurus</i>, which may have weighed <span style="white-space:nowrap" about="#mwt710" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"gaps","href":"./Template:Gaps"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"80"},"2":{"wt":"000"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBqY">80<span style="margin-left:0.25em">000</span></span> to <span style="white-space:nowrap" about="#mwt711" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"gaps","href":"./Template:Gaps"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"100"},"2":{"wt":"000"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBqc">100<span style="margin-left:0.25em">000</span></span><span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBqg"> </span>kilograms (90 to 110<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBqk"> </span>short tons) and reached lengths of <span about="#mwt712" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"30"},"2":{"wt":"to"},"3":{"wt":"40"},"4":{"wt":"m"},"5":{"wt":"ft"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBqo">30 to 40 meters (98 to 131</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt712"> </span><span about="#mwt712">ft)</span>; some of the longest were the <span about="#mwt713" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"33.5"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"sp":{"wt":"us"},"adj":{"wt":"mid"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBqs">33.5-meter (110</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt713"> </span><span about="#mwt713">ft)</span> long <i id="mwBqw">Diplodocus hallorum</i><sup about="#mwt720" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-KC06_140-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"KC06"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-KC06-140" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 139;" id="mwBq0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBq4">[139]</span></a></sup> (formerly <i id="mwBq8">Seismosaurus</i>), the <span about="#mwt714" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"33"},"2":{"wt":"to"},"3":{"wt":"34"},"4":{"wt":"m"},"5":{"wt":"ft"},"sp":{"wt":"us"},"adj":{"wt":"mid"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBrA">33-to-34-meter (108 to 112</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt714"> </span><span about="#mwt714">ft)</span> long <i id="mwBrE"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Supersaurus" title="Supersaurus" id="mwBrI">Supersaurus</a></i>,<sup about="#mwt721" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-LHW07_147-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"LHW07"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-LHW07-147" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 146;" id="mwBrM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBrQ">[146]</span></a></sup> and <span about="#mwt715" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"37"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"feet"},"sp":{"wt":"us"},"adj":{"wt":"mid"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBrU">37-meter (121</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt715"> </span><span about="#mwt715">ft)</span> long <i id="mwBrY">Patagotitan</i>; and the tallest, the <span about="#mwt716" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"18"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"sp":{"wt":"us"},"adj":{"wt":"mid"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBrc">18-meter (59</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt716"> </span><span about="#mwt716">ft)</span> tall <i id="mwBrg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sauroposeidon" title="Sauroposeidon" id="mwBrk">Sauroposeidon</a></i>, which could have reached a sixth-floor window. The heaviest and longest dinosaur may have been <i id="mwBro"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Maraapunisaurus" title="Maraapunisaurus" id="mwBrs">Maraapunisaurus</a></i>, known only from a now lost partial vertebral <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vertebra#Structure" title="Vertebra" id="mwBrw">neural arch</a> described in 1878. Extrapolating from the illustration of this bone, the animal may have been <span about="#mwt717" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"58"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBr0">58 meters (190</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt717"> </span><span about="#mwt717">ft)</span> long and weighed <span style="white-space:nowrap" about="#mwt718" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"gaps","href":"./Template:Gaps"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"122"},"2":{"wt":"400"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBr4">122<span style="margin-left:0.25em">400</span></span> kg (<span style="white-space:nowrap" about="#mwt719" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"gaps","href":"./Template:Gaps"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"270"},"2":{"wt":"000"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBr8">270<span style="margin-left:0.25em">000</span></span> lb).<sup about="#mwt722" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-KC06_140-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"KC06"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-KC06-140" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 139;" id="mwBsA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBsE">[139]</span></a></sup> However, as no further evidence of sauropods of this size has been found, and the discoverer, Cope, had made typographic errors before, it is likely to have been an extreme overestimation.<sup about="#mwt727" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-148" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-148"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-148" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 147;" id="mwBsI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBsM">[147]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBsQ">The largest carnivorous dinosaur was <i id="mwBsU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spinosaurus" title="Spinosaurus" id="mwBsY">Spinosaurus</a></i>, reaching a length of <span about="#mwt733" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"12.6"},"2":{"wt":"to"},"3":{"wt":"18"},"4":{"wt":"m"},"5":{"wt":"ft"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBsc">12.6 to 18 meters (41 to 59</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt733"> </span><span about="#mwt733">ft)</span>, and weighing <span about="#mwt734" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"7"},"2":{"wt":"to"},"3":{"wt":"20.9"},"4":{"wt":"MT"},"5":{"wt":"ST"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBsg">7 to 20.9 metric tons (7.7 to 23.0 short tons)</span>.<sup about="#mwt737" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-SMBM06_149-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"SMBM06"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-SMBM06-149" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 148;" id="mwBsk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBso">[148]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt738" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-TH07_150-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"TH07"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-TH07-150" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 149;" id="mwBss"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBsw">[149]</span></a></sup> Other large carnivorous theropods included <i id="mwBs0"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Giganotosaurus" title="Giganotosaurus" id="mwBs4">Giganotosaurus</a></i>, <i id="mwBs8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carcharodontosaurus" title="Carcharodontosaurus" id="mwBtA">Carcharodontosaurus</a></i> and <i id="mwBtE">Tyrannosaurus</i>.<sup about="#mwt739" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-TH07_150-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"TH07"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-TH07-150" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 149;" id="mwBtI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBtM">[149]</span></a></sup> <i id="mwBtQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Therizinosaurus" title="Therizinosaurus" id="mwBtU">Therizinosaurus</a></i> and <i id="mwBtY"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deinocheirus" title="Deinocheirus" id="mwBtc">Deinocheirus</a></i> were among the tallest of the theropods. The largest ornithischian dinosaur was probably the hadrosaurid <i id="mwBtg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shantungosaurus" title="Shantungosaurus" id="mwBtk">Shantungosaurus giganteus</a></i> which measured <span about="#mwt735" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"16.6"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"feet"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBto">16.6 meters (54</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt735"> </span><span about="#mwt735">ft)</span>.<sup about="#mwt743" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-151" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-151"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-151" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 150;" id="mwBts"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBtw">[150]</span></a></sup> The largest individuals may have weighed as much as <span about="#mwt736" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"16"},"2":{"wt":"MT"},"3":{"wt":"ST"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBt0">16 metric tons (18 short tons)</span>.<sup about="#mwt745" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-152" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-152"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-152" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 151;" id="mwBt4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBt8">[151]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBuA">The smallest dinosaur known is the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bee_hummingbird" title="Bee hummingbird" id="mwBuE">bee hummingbird</a>,<sup about="#mwt760" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-153" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-153"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-153" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 152;" id="mwBuI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBuM">[152]</span></a></sup> with a length of only <span about="#mwt754" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"5"},"2":{"wt":"cm"},"3":{"wt":"in"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBuQ">5 centimeters (2.0</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt754"> </span><span about="#mwt754">in)</span> and mass of around <span about="#mwt755" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"1.8"},"2":{"wt":"g"},"3":{"wt":"oz"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBuU">1.8</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt755"> </span><span about="#mwt755">g (0.063</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt755"> </span><span about="#mwt755">oz)</span>.<sup
