about="#mwt764" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-154" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-154"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-154" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 153;" id="mwBuY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBuc">[153]</span></a></sup> The smallest known non-<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Avialae" title="Avialae" id="mwBug">avialan</a> dinosaurs were about the size of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pigeon" title="Pigeon" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBuk">pigeons</a> and were those theropods most closely related to birds.<sup about="#mwt765" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-zhang2008_155-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"zhang2008"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-zhang2008-155" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 154;" id="mwBuo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBus">[154]</span></a></sup> For example, <i id="mwBuw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Anchiornis_huxleyi" title="Anchiornis huxleyi" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBu0">Anchiornis huxleyi</a></i> is currently the smallest non-avialan dinosaur described from an adult specimen, with an estimated weight of <span about="#mwt756" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"110"},"2":{"wt":"g"},"3":{"wt":"oz"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBu4">110</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt756"> </span><span about="#mwt756">g (3.9</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt756"> </span><span about="#mwt756">oz)</span><sup about="#mwt766" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-anchiadvance_156-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"anchiadvance"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-anchiadvance-156" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 155;" id="mwBu8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBvA">[155]</span></a></sup> and a total skeletal length of <span about="#mwt757" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"34"},"2":{"wt":"cm"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBvE">34 centimeters (1.12</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt757"> </span><span about="#mwt757">ft)</span>.<sup about="#mwt767" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-zhang2008_155-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"zhang2008"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-zhang2008-155" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 154;" id="mwBvI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBvM">[154]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt768" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-anchiadvance_156-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"anchiadvance"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-anchiadvance-156" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 155;" id="mwBvQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBvU">[155]</span></a></sup> The smallest herbivorous non-avialan dinosaurs included <i id="mwBvY"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Microceratus" title="Microceratus" id="mwBvc">Microceratus</a></i> and <i id="mwBvg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wannanosaurus" title="Wannanosaurus" id="mwBvk">Wannanosaurus</a></i>, at about <span about="#mwt758" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"60"},"2":{"wt":"cm"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwBvo">60 centimeters (2.0</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt758"> </span><span about="#mwt758">ft)</span> long each.<sup about="#mwt769" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Holtz2007_157-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Holtz2007"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Holtz2007-157" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 156;" id="mwBvs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBvw">[156]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt770" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-butler&amp;zhao2009_158-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"butler&amp;zhao2009"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-butler&amp;zhao2009-158" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 157;" id="mwBv0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBv4">[157]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="19" id="mwBv8"><h3 id="Behavior">Behavior</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBwA"><a href="./File:Maiasaurusnest.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBwE"><img resource="./File:Maiasaurusnest.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Maiasaurusnest.jpg/220px-Maiasaurusnest.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="480" data-file-type="bitmap" height="165" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Maiasaurusnest.jpg/330px-Maiasaurusnest.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Maiasaurusnest.jpg/440px-Maiasaurusnest.jpg 2x" id="mwBwI"/></a><figcaption id="mwBwM">A nesting ground of the hadrosaur <i id="mwBwQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Maiasaura" title="Maiasaura" id="mwBwU">Maiasaura peeblesorum</a></i> was discovered in 1978</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwBwY">Many modern birds are highly social, often found living in flocks. There is general agreement that some behaviors that are common in birds, as well as in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crocodile" title="Crocodile" id="mwBwc">crocodiles</a> (closest living relatives of birds), were also common among extinct dinosaur groups. Interpretations of behavior in fossil species are generally based on the pose of skeletons and their <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Habitat_(ecology)" title="Habitat (ecology)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBwg">habitat</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Computer_simulation" title="Computer simulation" id="mwBwk">computer simulations</a> of their biomechanics, and comparisons with modern animals in similar ecological niches.<sup about="#mwt772" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-alexander2006_133-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"alexander2006"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-alexander2006-133" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 132;" id="mwBwo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBws">[132]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBww">The first potential evidence for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Herd" title="Herd" id="mwBw0">herding</a> or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Flocking_(behavior)" title="Flocking (behavior)" id="mwBw4">flocking</a> as a widespread behavior common to many dinosaur groups in addition to birds was the 1878 discovery of 31<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwBw8"> </span><i id="mwBxA">Iguanodon</i>, ornithischians that were then thought to have perished together in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bernissart" title="Bernissart" id="mwBxE">Bernissart</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Belgium" title="Belgium" id="mwBxI">Belgium</a>, after they fell into a deep, flooded <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sinkhole" title="Sinkhole" id="mwBxM">sinkhole</a> and drowned.<sup about="#mwt780" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Yans_159-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Yans"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Yans-159" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 158;" id="mwBxQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBxU">[158]</span></a></sup> Other mass-death sites have been discovered subsequently. Those, along with multiple trackways, suggest that gregarious behavior was common in many early dinosaur species. Trackways of hundreds or even thousands of herbivores indicate that duck-billed (hadrosaurids) may have moved in great herds, like the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./American_bison" title="American bison" id="mwBxY">American bison</a> or the African <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Springbok" title="Springbok" id="mwBxc">Springbok</a>. Sauropod tracks document that these animals traveled in groups composed of several different species, at least in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oxfordshire" title="Oxfordshire" id="mwBxg">Oxfordshire</a>, England,<sup about="#mwt781" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Day2002_160-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Day2002"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Day2002-160" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 159;" id="mwBxk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBxo">[159]</span></a></sup> although there is no evidence for specific herd structures.<sup about="#mwt782" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-JLW05_161-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"JLW05"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-JLW05-161" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 160;" id="mwBxs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBxw">[160]</span></a></sup> Congregating into herds may have evolved for defense, for <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bird_migration" title="Bird migration" id="mwBx0">migratory</a> purposes, or to provide protection for young. There is evidence that many types of slow-growing dinosaurs, including various theropods, sauropods, ankylosaurians, ornithopods, and ceratopsians, formed aggregations of immature individuals. One example is a site in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Inner_Mongolia" title="Inner Mongolia" id="mwBx4">Inner Mongolia</a> that has yielded remains of over 20 <i id="mwBx8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sinornithomimus" title="Sinornithomimus" id="mwByA">Sinornithomimus</a></i>, from one to seven years old. This assemblage is interpreted as a social group that was trapped in mud.<sup about="#mwt783" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-DVetal08sino_162-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"DVetal08sino"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-DVetal08sino-162" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 161;" id="mwByE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwByI">[161]</span></a></sup> The interpretation of dinosaurs as gregarious has also extended to depicting carnivorous theropods as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pack_hunter" title="Pack hunter" id="mwByM">pack hunters</a> working together to bring down large prey.<sup about="#mwt784" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-LG93_163-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"LG93"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-LG93-163" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 162;" id="mwByQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwByU">[162]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt785" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-maxwell&amp;ostrom1995_164-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"maxwell&amp;ostrom1995"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-maxwell&amp;ostrom1995-164" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 163;" id="mwByY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwByc">[163]</span></a></sup> However, this lifestyle is uncommon among modern birds, crocodiles, and other reptiles, and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Taphonomy" title="Taphonomy" id="mwByg">taphonomic</a> evidence suggesting mammal-like pack hunting in such theropods as <i id="mwByk">Deinonychus</i> and <i id="mwByo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Allosaurus" title="Allosaurus" id="mwBys">Allosaurus</a></i> can also be interpreted as the results of fatal disputes between feeding animals, as is seen in many modern diapsid predators.<sup about="#mwt786" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-RB07_165-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"RB07"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-RB07-165" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 164;" id="mwByw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBy0">[164]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwBy4"><a href="./File:Centrosaurus_dinosaur.png" class="mw-file-description" id="mwBy8"><img resource="./File:Centrosaurus_dinosaur.png" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Centrosaurus_dinosaur.png/220px-Centrosaurus_dinosaur.png" decoding="async" data-file-width="1700" data-file-height="808" data-file-type="bitmap" height="105" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Centrosaurus_dinosaur.png/330px-Centrosaurus_dinosaur.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Centrosaurus_dinosaur.png/440px-Centrosaurus_dinosaur.png 2x" id="mwBzA"/></a><figcaption id="mwBzE">Restoration of two <i id="mwBzI"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Centrosaurus" title="Centrosaurus" id="mwBzM">Centrosaurus apertus</a></i> engaged in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Intra-specific_combat" title="Intra-specific combat" class="mw-redirect" id="mwBzQ">intra-specific combat</a></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwBzU">The crests and frills of some dinosaurs, like the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Marginocephalia" title="Marginocephalia" id="mwBzY">marginocephalians</a>, theropods and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lambeosaurinae" title="Lambeosaurinae" id="mwBzc">lambeosaurines</a>, may have been too fragile to be used for active defense, and so they were likely used for sexual or aggressive displays, though little is known about dinosaur mating and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Territory_(animal)" title="Territory (animal)" id="mwBzg">territorialism</a>. Head wounds from bites suggest that theropods, at least, engaged in active aggressive confrontations.<sup about="#mwt788" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-PC98_166-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"PC98"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-PC98-166" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 165;" id="mwBzk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwBzo">[165]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwBzs">From a behavioral standpoint, one of the most valuable dinosaur fossils was discovered in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gobi_Desert" title="Gobi Desert" id="mwBzw">Gobi Desert</a> in 1971. It included a <i id="mwBz0"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Velociraptor" title="Velociraptor" id="mwBz4">Velociraptor</a></i> attacking a <i id="mwBz8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Protoceratops" title="Protoceratops" id="mwB0A">Protoceratops</a></i>,<sup about="#mwt793" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-AMNH_167-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"AMNH"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-AMNH-167" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 166;" id="mwB0E"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB0I">[166]</span></a></sup> providing evidence that dinosaurs did indeed attack each other.<sup about="#mwt794" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-carpenter1998_168-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"carpenter1998"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-carpenter1998-168" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 167;" id="mwB0M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB0Q">[167]</span></a></sup> Additional evidence for attacking live prey is the partially healed tail of an <i id="mwB0U"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Edmontosaurus" title="Edmontosaurus" id="mwB0Y">Edmontosaurus</a></i>, a hadrosaurid dinosaur; the tail is damaged in such a way that shows the animal was bitten by a tyrannosaur but survived.<sup about="#mwt795" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-carpenter1998_168-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"carpenter1998"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-carpenter1998-168" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 167;" id="mwB0c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB0g">[167]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cannibalism_(zoology)" title="Cannibalism (zoology)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB0k">Cannibalism</a> amongst some species of dinosaurs was confirmed by tooth marks found in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Madagascar" title="Madagascar" id="mwB0o">Madagascar</a> in 2003, involving the theropod <i id="mwB0s"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Majungasaurus" title="Majungasaurus" id="mwB0w">Majungasaurus</a></i>.<sup about="#mwt796" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-rogersetal2003_169-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"rogersetal2003"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-rogersetal2003-169" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 168;" id="mwB00"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB04">[168]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwB08">Comparisons between the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sclerotic_ring" title="Sclerotic ring" id="mwB1A">scleral rings</a> of dinosaurs and modern birds and reptiles have been used to infer daily activity patterns of dinosaurs. Although it has been suggested that most dinosaurs were active during the day, these comparisons have shown that small predatory dinosaurs such as dromaeosaurids, <i id="mwB1E"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Juravenator" title="Juravenator" id="mwB1I">Juravenator</a></i>, and <i id="mwB1M"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Megapnosaurus" title="Megapnosaurus" id="mwB1Q">Megapnosaurus</a></i> were likely <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nocturnal" title="Nocturnal" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB1U">nocturnal</a>. Large and medium-sized herbivorous and omnivorous dinosaurs such as ceratopsians, sauropodomorphs, hadrosaurids, ornithomimosaurs may have been <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cathemeral" title="Cathemeral" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB1Y">cathemeral</a>, active during short intervals throughout the day, although the small ornithischian <i id="mwB1c"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Agilisaurus" title="Agilisaurus" id="mwB1g">Agilisaurus</a></i> was inferred to be <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diurnality" title="Diurnality" id="mwB1k">diurnal</a>.<sup about="#mwt798" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-SchmitzMotani2011_170-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"SchmitzMotani2011"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-SchmitzMotani2011-170" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 169;" id="mwB1o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB1s">[169]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwB1w">Based on fossil evidence from dinosaurs such as <i id="mwB10"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oryctodromeus" title="Oryctodromeus" id="mwB14">Oryctodromeus</a></i>, some ornithischian species seem to have led a partially <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fossorial" title="Fossorial" id="mwB18">fossorial</a> (burrowing) lifestyle.<sup about="#mwt805" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-VMK07_171-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"VMK07"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-VMK07-171" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 170;" id="mwB2A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB2E">[170]</span></a></sup> Many modern birds are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arboreal" title="Arboreal" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB2I">arboreal</a> (tree climbing), and this was also true of many Mesozoic birds, especially the enantiornithines.<sup about="#mwt807" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-172" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-172"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-172" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 171;" id="mwB2M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB2Q">[171]</span></a></sup> While some early bird-like species may have already been arboreal as well (including dromaeosaurids) such as <i id="mwB2U">Microraptor</i><sup about="#mwt808" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-chatterjee2007_173-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"chatterjee2007"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-chatterjee2007-173" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 172;" id="mwB2Y"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB2c">[172]</span></a></sup>) most non-avialan dinosaurs seem to have relied on land-based locomotion. A good understanding of how dinosaurs moved on the ground is key to models of dinosaur behavior; the science of biomechanics, pioneered by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Robert_McNeill_Alexander" title="Robert McNeill Alexander" id="mwB2g">Robert McNeill Alexander</a>, has provided significant insight in this area. For example, studies of the forces exerted by muscles and gravity on dinosaurs' skeletal structure have investigated how fast dinosaurs could run,<sup about="#mwt809" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-alexander2006_133-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"alexander2006"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-alexander2006-133" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 132;" id="mwB2k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB2o">[132]</span></a></sup> whether <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Diplodocid" title="Diplodocid" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB2s">diplodocids</a> could create <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sonic_boom" title="Sonic boom" id="mwB2w">sonic booms</a> via <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Whip" title="Whip" id="mwB20">whip</a>-like tail snapping,<sup about="#mwt810" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-goriely_174-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"goriely"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-goriely-174" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 173;" id="mwB24"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB28">[173]</span></a></sup> and whether sauropods could float.<sup about="#mwt811" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Henderson2006_175-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Henderson2006"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Henderson2006-175" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 174;" id="mwB3A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB3E">[174]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="20" id="mwB3I"><h3 id="Communication">Communication</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwB3M"><a href="./File:Lambeosaurus_magnicristatus_DB.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwB3Q"><img resource="./File:Lambeosaurus_magnicristatus_DB.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Lambeosaurus_magnicristatus_DB.jpg/220px-Lambeosaurus_magnicristatus_DB.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="676" data-file-type="bitmap" height="198" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Lambeosaurus_magnicristatus_DB.jpg/330px-Lambeosaurus_magnicristatus_DB.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Lambeosaurus_magnicristatus_DB.jpg/440px-Lambeosaurus_magnicristatus_DB.jpg 2x" id="mwB3U"/></a><figcaption id="mwB3Y">Restoration of a striking and unusual visual display in a <i id="mwB3c"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lambeosaurus" title="Lambeosaurus" id="mwB3g">Lambeosaurus magnicristatus</a></i></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwB3k">Modern birds are known to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Animal_communication" title="Animal communication" id="mwB3o">communicate</a> using visual and auditory signals, and the wide diversity of visual display structures among fossil dinosaur groups, such as horns, frills, crests, sails, and feathers, suggests that visual communication has always been important in dinosaur biology.<sup about="#mwt815" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-senter2008_176-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"senter2008"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-senter2008-176" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 175;" id="mwB3s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB3w">[175]</span></a></sup> Reconstruction of the plumage color of <i id="mwB30">Anchiornis</i>, suggest the importance of color in visual communication in non-avian dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt816" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Li2010_177-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Li2010"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Li2010-177" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 176;" id="mwB34"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB38">[176]</span></a></sup> The evolution of dinosaur vocalization is less certain. Paleontologist Phil Senter has suggested that non-avian dinosaurs relied mostly on visual displays and possibly non-vocal acoustic sounds like hissing, jaw grinding or clapping, splashing and wing beating (possible in winged maniraptoran dinosaurs). He states they were unlikely to have been capable of vocalizing since their closest relatives, crocodilians and birds, use different means to vocalize, the former via the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Larynx" title="Larynx" id="mwB4A">larynx</a> and the latter through the unique <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Syrinx_(bird_anatomy)" title="Syrinx (bird anatomy)" id="mwB4E">syrinx</a>, suggesting they evolved independently and their common ancestor was mute.<sup about="#mwt817" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-senter2008_176-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"senter2008"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-senter2008-176" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 175;" id="mwB4I"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB4M">[175]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwB4Q">The earliest remains of a syrinx, which has enough mineral content for fossilization, was found in a specimen of the duck-like <i id="mwB4U"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vegavis" title="Vegavis" id="mwB4Y">Vegavis iaai</a></i> dated 69 –66<span typeof="mw:Entity" id="mwB4c"> </span>million years ago, and this organ is unlikely to have existed in non-avian dinosaurs. However, in contrast to Senter, other researchers have suggested that dinosaurs could vocalize and that the syrinx-based vocal system of birds evolved from a larynx-based one, rather than the two systems evolving independently.<sup about="#mwt823" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Clarke2016_178-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Clarke2016"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Clarke2016-178" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 177;" id="mwB4g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB4k">[177]</span></a></sup> In 2023, a fossilized larynx was described from a specimen of the ankylosaurid <i id="mwB4o"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pinacosaurus" title="Pinacosaurus" id="mwB4s">Pinacosaurus</a></i>. The researchers suggest that the animal was capable of making loud, possibly bird-like vocalizations.<sup about="#mwt824" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-:1_179-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":":1"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-:1-179" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 178;" id="mwB4w"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB40">[178]</span></a></sup> A 2016 study concludes that some dinosaurs may have produced closed mouth vocalizations like cooing, hooting and booming. These occur in both reptiles and birds and involve inflating the esophagus or tracheal pouches. Such vocalizations evolved independently in extant archosaurs numerous times, following increases in body size.<sup about="#mwt825" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Tobias2016_180-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Tobias2016"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Tobias2016-180" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 179;" id="mwB44"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB48">[179]</span></a></sup> The crests of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lambeosaurini" title="Lambeosaurini" id="mwB5A">Lambeosaurini</a> and nasal chambers of ankylosaurids have been suggested to have functioned in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Acoustic_resonance" title="Acoustic resonance" id="mwB5E">acoustic resonance</a>.<sup about="#mwt826" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Weishampel981_181-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Weishampel981"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Weishampel981-181" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 180;" id="mwB5I"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB5M">[180]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt827" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Witmer_182-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Witmer"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Witmer-182" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 181;" id="mwB5Q"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB5U">[181]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="21" id="mwB5Y"><h3 id="Reproductive_biology">Reproductive biology</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt828" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"see also","href":"./Template:See_also"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Dinosaur egg"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwB5c"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt828" id="mwB5g">See also: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dinosaur_egg" title="Dinosaur egg">Dinosaur egg</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwB5k"><a href="./File:Gniazdo_sieweczki_RB.JPG" class="mw-file-description" id="mwB5o"><img alt="Three bluish eggs with black speckling sit atop a layer of white mollusk shell pieces, surrounded by sandy ground and small bits of bluish stone" resource="./File:Gniazdo_sieweczki_RB.JPG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Gniazdo_sieweczki_RB.JPG/220px-Gniazdo_sieweczki_RB.JPG" decoding="async" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="960" data-file-type="bitmap" height="165" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Gniazdo_sieweczki_RB.JPG/330px-Gniazdo_sieweczki_RB.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Gniazdo_sieweczki_RB.JPG/440px-Gniazdo_sieweczki_RB.JPG 2x" id="mwB5s"/></a><figcaption id="mwB5w">Nest of a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Plover" title="Plover" id="mwB50">plover</a> (<i id="mwB54"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Charadrius" title="Charadrius" id="mwB58">Charadrius</a></i>)</figcaption></figure>

<p id="mwB6A">All dinosaurs laid <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Amniote" title="Amniote" id="mwB6E">amniotic eggs</a>. Dinosaur eggs were usually laid in a nest. Most species create somewhat elaborate nests which can be cups, domes, plates, beds scrapes, mounds, or burrows.<sup about="#mwt834" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Hansell_183-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Hansell"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Hansell-183"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Hansell-183" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 182;" id="mwB6I"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB6M">[182]</span></a></sup> Some species of modern bird have no nests; the cliff-nesting <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Common_murre" title="Common murre" id="mwB6Q">common guillemot</a> lays its eggs on bare rock, and male <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Emperor_penguin" title="Emperor penguin" id="mwB6U">emperor penguins</a> keep eggs between their body and feet. Primitive birds and many non-avialan dinosaurs often lay eggs in communal nests, with males primarily incubating the eggs. While modern birds have only one functional <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oviduct" title="Oviduct" id="mwB6Y">oviduct</a> and lay one egg at a time, more primitive birds and dinosaurs had two oviducts, like crocodiles. Some non-avialan dinosaurs, such as <i id="mwB6c"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Troodon" title="Troodon" id="mwB6g">Troodon</a></i>, exhibited iterative laying, where the adult might lay a pair of eggs every one or two days, and then ensured simultaneous hatching by delaying <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Broodiness#Broodiness_in_non-avian_animals" title="Broodiness" id="mwB6k">brooding</a> until all eggs were laid.<sup about="#mwt838" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Varrichioetal.02_184-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Varrichioetal.02"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Varrichioetal.02-184"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Varrichioetal.02-184" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 183;" id="mwB6o"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB6s">[183]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwB6w">When laying eggs, females grow a special type of bone between the hard outer bone and the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bone_marrow" title="Bone marrow" id="mwB60">marrow</a> of their limbs. This medullary bone, which is rich in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Calcium" title="Calcium" id="mwB64">calcium</a>, is used to make eggshells. A discovery of features in a <i id="mwB68">Tyrannosaurus</i> skeleton provided evidence of medullary bone in extinct dinosaurs and, for the first time, allowed paleontologists to establish the sex of a fossil dinosaur specimen. Further research has found medullary bone in the carnosaur <i id="mwB7A">Allosaurus</i> and the ornithopod <i id="mwB7E"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tenontosaurus" title="Tenontosaurus" id="mwB7I">Tenontosaurus</a></i>. Because the line of dinosaurs that includes <i id="mwB7M">Allosaurus</i> and <i id="mwB7Q">Tyrannosaurus</i> diverged from the line that led to <i id="mwB7U">Tenontosaurus</i> very early in the evolution of dinosaurs, this suggests that the production of medullary tissue is a general characteristic of all dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt840" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-LW08_185-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"LW08"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-LW08-185" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 184;" id="mwB7Y"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB7c">[184]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwB7g"><a href="./File:Citipati_IGM_100_979.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwB7k"><img resource="./File:Citipati_IGM_100_979.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Citipati_IGM_100_979.jpg/220px-Citipati_IGM_100_979.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="3008" data-file-height="2000" data-file-type="bitmap" height="146" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Citipati_IGM_100_979.jpg/330px-Citipati_IGM_100_979.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Citipati_IGM_100_979.jpg/440px-Citipati_IGM_100_979.jpg 2x" id="mwB7o"/></a><figcaption id="mwB7s">Fossil interpreted as a nesting <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oviraptoridae" title="Oviraptoridae" id="mwB7w">oviraptorid</a> <i id="mwB70"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Citipati" title="Citipati" id="mwB74">Citipati</a></i> at the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./American_Museum_of_Natural_History" title="American Museum of Natural History" id="mwB78">American Museum of Natural History</a>. Smaller fossil far right showing inside one of the eggs.</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwB8A">Another widespread trait among modern birds (but see below in regards to fossil groups and extant <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Megapodes" title="Megapodes" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB8E">megapodes</a>) is parental care for young after hatching. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jack_Horner_(paleontologist)" title="Jack Horner (paleontologist)" id="mwB8I">Jack Horner's</a> 1978 discovery of a <i id="mwB8M"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Maiasaura" title="Maiasaura" id="mwB8Q">Maiasaura</a></i> ("good mother lizard") nesting ground in Montana demonstrated that parental care continued long after birth among ornithopods.<sup about="#mwt846" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-HM79_186-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"HM79"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-HM79-186" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 185;" id="mwB8U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB8Y">[185]</span></a></sup> A specimen of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oviraptoridae" title="Oviraptoridae" id="mwB8c">oviraptorid</a> <i id="mwB8g"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Citipati" title="Citipati" id="mwB8k">Citipati osmolskae</a></i> was discovered in a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chicken#Broodiness" title="Chicken" id="mwB8o">chicken-like brooding position</a> in 1993,<sup about="#mwt847" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-search.eb_187-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"search.eb"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-search.eb-187" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 186;" id="mwB8s"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB8w">[186]</span></a></sup> which may indicate that they had begun using an insulating layer of feathers to keep the eggs warm.<sup about="#mwt849" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-188" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-188"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-188" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 187;" id="mwB80"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB84">[187]</span></a></sup> An embryo of the basal sauropodomorph <i id="mwB88"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Massospondylus" title="Massospondylus" id="mwB9A">Massospondylus</a></i> was found without teeth, indicating that some parental care was required to feed the young dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt850" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Reiszetal05_189-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Reiszetal05"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Reiszetal05-189" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 188;" id="mwB9E"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB9I">[188]</span></a></sup> Trackways have also confirmed parental behavior among ornithopods from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Isle_of_Skye" title="Isle of Skye" id="mwB9M">Isle of Skye</a> in northwestern <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scotland" title="Scotland" id="mwB9Q">Scotland</a>.<sup about="#mwt851" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-BBCtracks_190-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"BBCtracks"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-BBCtracks-190" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 189;" id="mwB9U"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB9Y">[189]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwB9c">However, there is ample evidence of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Precociality" title="Precociality" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB9g">precociality</a> or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Precociality#Superprecociality" title="Precociality" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB9k">superprecociality</a> among many dinosaur species, particularly theropods. For instance, non-<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Euornithes" title="Euornithes" id="mwB9o">ornithuromorph</a> birds have been abundantly demonstrated to have had slow growth rates, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Megapode" title="Megapode" id="mwB9s">megapode</a>-like egg burying behavior and the ability to fly soon after birth.<sup about="#mwt861" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-191" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-191"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-191" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 190;" id="mwB9w"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB90">[190]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt865" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-192" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-192"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-192" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 191;" id="mwB94"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB98">[191]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt869" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-193" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-193"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-193" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 192;" id="mwB-A"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB-E">[192]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt873" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-194" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-194"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-194" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 193;" id="mwB-I"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB-M">[193]</span></a></sup> Both <i id="mwB-Q">Tyrannosaurus</i> and <i id="mwB-U">Troodon</i> had juveniles with clear superprecociality and likely occupying different ecological niches than the adults.<sup about="#mwt874" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Varrichioetal.02_184-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Varrichioetal.02"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Varrichioetal.02-184" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 183;" id="mwB-Y"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB-c">[183]</span></a></sup> Superprecociality has been inferred for sauropods.<sup about="#mwt878" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-195" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-195"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-195" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 194;" id="mwB-g"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB-k">[194]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwB-o">Genital structures are unlikely to fossilize as they lack scales that may allow preservation via pigmentation or residual calcium phosphate salts. In 2021, the best preserved specimen of a dinosaur's <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cloacal_vent" title="Cloacal vent" class="mw-redirect" id="mwB-s">cloacal vent</a> exterior was described for <i id="mwB-w">Psittacosaurus</i>, demonstrating lateral swellings similar to crocodylian musk glands used in social displays by both sexes and pigmented regions which could also reflect a signalling function. However, this specimen on its own does not offer enough information to determine whether this dinosaur had sexual signalling functions; it only supports the possibility. Cloacal visual signalling can occur in either males or females in living birds, making it unlikely to be useful to determine sex for extinct dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt883" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-cloacal-vent_196-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"cloacal-vent"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-cloacal-vent-196"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-cloacal-vent-196" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 195;" id="mwB-0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB-4">[195]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="22" id="mwB-8"><h3 id="Physiology">Physiology</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt884" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Physiology of dinosaurs"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwB_A"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt884" id="mwB_E">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Physiology_of_dinosaurs" title="Physiology of dinosaurs">Physiology of dinosaurs</a></div>
<p id="mwB_I">Because both modern crocodilians and birds have four-chambered hearts (albeit modified in crocodilians), it is likely that this is a trait shared by all archosaurs, including all dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt893" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-CH04_197-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"CH04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-CH04-197" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 196;" id="mwB_M"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB_Q">[196]</span></a></sup> While all modern birds have high metabolisms and are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Endotherm" title="Endotherm" id="mwB_U">endothermic</a> ("warm-blooded"), a vigorous debate has been ongoing since the 1960s regarding how far back in the dinosaur lineage this trait extended. Various researchers have supported dinosaurs as being endothermic, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ectotherm" title="Ectotherm" id="mwB_Y">ectothermic</a> ("cold-blooded"), or somewhere in between.<sup about="#mwt897" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pontzer2009_198-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pontzer2009"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-pontzer2009-198"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-pontzer2009-198" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 197;" id="mwB_c"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB_g">[197]</span></a></sup> An emerging consensus among researchers is that, while different lineages of dinosaurs would have had different metabolisms, most of them had higher metabolic rates than other reptiles but lower than living birds and mammals,<sup about="#mwt901" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-benson2018_199-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"benson2018"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-benson2018-199"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-benson2018-199" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 198;" id="mwB_k"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB_o">[198]</span></a></sup> which is termed <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mesotherm" title="Mesotherm" id="mwB_s">mesothermy</a> by some.<sup about="#mwt905" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-grady2014_200-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"grady2014"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-grady2014-200"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-grady2014-200" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 199;" id="mwB_w"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB_0">[199]</span></a></sup> Evidence from crocodiles and their extinct relatives suggests that such elevated metabolisms could have developed in the earliest archosaurs, which were the common ancestors of dinosaurs and crocodiles.<sup about="#mwt909" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-legendre2016_201-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"legendre2016"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-legendre2016-201"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-legendre2016-201" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 200;" id="mwB_4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwB_8">[200]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt913" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-seymour2004_202-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"seymour2004"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-seymour2004-202"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-seymour2004-202" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 201;" id="mwCAA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCAE">[201]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwCAI"><a href="./File:Pasta-Brontosaurus.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwCAM"><img resource="./File:Pasta-Brontosaurus.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Pasta-Brontosaurus.jpg/220px-Pasta-Brontosaurus.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="4655" data-file-height="3056" data-file-type="bitmap" height="144" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Pasta-Brontosaurus.jpg/330px-Pasta-Brontosaurus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Pasta-Brontosaurus.jpg/440px-Pasta-Brontosaurus.jpg 2x" id="mwCAQ"/></a><figcaption id="mwCAU">This 1897 restoration of <i id="mwCAY"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Brontosaurus" title="Brontosaurus" id="mwCAc">Brontosaurus</a></i> as an aquatic, tail-dragging animal, by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Charles_R._Knight" title="Charles R. Knight" id="mwCAg">Charles R. Knight</a>, typified early views on dinosaur lifestyles.</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwCAk">After non-avian dinosaurs were discovered, paleontologists first posited that they were ectothermic. This was used to imply that the ancient dinosaurs were relatively slow, sluggish organisms, even though many modern reptiles are fast and light-footed despite relying on external sources of heat to regulate their body temperature. The idea of dinosaurs as ectothermic remained a prevalent view until <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Robert_T._Bakker" title="Robert T. Bakker" id="mwCAo">Robert T. Bakker</a>, an early proponent of dinosaur endothermy, published an influential paper on the topic in 1968. Bakker specifically used anatomical and ecological evidence to argue that sauropods, which had hitherto been depicted as sprawling aquatic animals with their tails dragging on the ground, were endotherms that lived vigorous, terrestrial lives. In 1972, Bakker expanded on his arguments based on energy requirements and predator-prey ratios. This was one of the seminal results that led to the dinosaur renaissance.<sup about="#mwt921" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bakker1968_61-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bakker1968"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-bakker1968-61"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-bakker1968-61" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 60;" id="mwCAs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCAw">[60]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt925" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bakker1972_62-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bakker1972"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-bakker1972-62"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-bakker1972-62" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 61;" id="mwCA0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCA4">[61]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt926" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-taylor2010_58-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"taylor2010"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-taylor2010-58" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 57;" id="mwCA8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCBA">[57]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt927" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-parsons2001_203-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"parsons2001"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-parsons2001-203" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 202;" id="mwCBE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCBI">[202]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCBM">One of the greatest contributions to the modern understanding of dinosaur physiology has been <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Histology" title="Histology" id="mwCBQ">paleohistology</a>, the study of microscopic tissue structure in dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt947" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-erickson2014_204-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"erickson2014"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-erickson2014-204"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-erickson2014-204" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 203;" id="mwCBU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCBY">[203]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt951" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bailleul2019_205-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bailleul2019"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-bailleul2019-205"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-bailleul2019-205" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 204;" id="mwCBc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCBg">[204]</span></a></sup> From the 1960s forward, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Armand_de_Ricqlès" title="Armand de Ricqlès" id="mwCBk">Armand de Ricqlès</a> suggested that the presence of fibrolamellar bone—bony tissue with an irregular, fibrous texture and filled with blood vessels—was indicative of consistently fast growth and therefore endothermy. Fibrolamellar bone was common in both dinosaurs and pterosaurs,<sup about="#mwt955" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-dericqles1974_206-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"dericqles1974"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-dericqles1974-206"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-dericqles1974-206" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 205;" id="mwCBo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCBs">[205]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt959" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-dericqles1980_207-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"dericqles1980"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-dericqles1980-207"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-dericqles1980-207" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 206;" id="mwCBw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCB0">[206]</span></a></sup> though not universally present.<sup about="#mwt963" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-padian2004_208-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"padian2004"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-padian2004-208"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-padian2004-208" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 207;" id="mwCB4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCB8">[207]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt967" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-desouza2020_209-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"desouza2020"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-desouza2020-209"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-desouza2020-209" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 208;" id="mwCCA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCCE">[208]</span></a></sup> This has led to a significant body of work in reconstructing <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Growth_curve_(biology)" title="Growth curve (biology)" id="mwCCI">growth curves</a> and modeling the evolution of growth rates across various dinosaur lineages,<sup about="#mwt986" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-physiologyrefs_210-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"physiologyrefs"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-physiologyrefs-210"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-physiologyrefs-210" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 209;" id="mwCCM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCCQ">[209]</span></a></sup> which has suggested overall that dinosaurs grew faster than living reptiles.<sup about="#mwt987" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bailleul2019_205-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bailleul2019"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-bailleul2019-205" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 204;" id="mwCCU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCCY">[204]</span></a></sup> Other lines of evidence suggesting endothermy include the presence of feathers and other types of body coverings in many lineages (see <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dinosaur#Feathers" about="#mwt943" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"sectionlink","href":"./Template:Sectionlink"},"params":{"1":{"wt":""},"2":{"wt":"Feathers"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCCc">§<span typeof="mw:Entity"> </span>Feathers</a>); more consistent ratios of the isotope <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oxygen-18" title="Oxygen-18" id="mwCCg">oxygen-18</a> in bony tissue compared to ectotherms, particularly as latitude and thus air temperature varied, which suggests stable internal temperatures<sup about="#mwt991" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-amiot2006_211-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"amiot2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-amiot2006-211"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-amiot2006-211" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 210;" id="mwCCk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCCo">[210]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt995" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-amiot2010_212-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"amiot2010"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-amiot2010-212"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-amiot2010-212" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 211;" id="mwCCs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCCw">[211]</span></a></sup> (although these ratios can be altered during fossilization<sup about="#mwt999" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-kolodny1996_213-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"kolodny1996"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-kolodny1996-213"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-kolodny1996-213" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 212;" id="mwCC0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCC4">[212]</span></a></sup>); and the discovery of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./South_Polar_region_of_the_Cretaceous#Dinosaurs" title="South Polar region of the Cretaceous" id="mwCC8">polar dinosaurs</a>, which lived in Australia, Antarctica, and Alaska when these places would have had cool, temperate climates.<sup about="#mwt1003" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-paul1988_214-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"paul1988"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-paul1988-214"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-paul1988-214" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 213;" id="mwCDA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCDE">[213]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1007" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-clemens1993_215-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"clemens1993"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-clemens1993-215"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-clemens1993-215" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 214;" id="mwCDI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCDM">[214]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1011" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-rich2002_216-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"rich2002"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-rich2002-216"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-rich2002-216" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 215;" id="mwCDQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCDU">[215]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1015" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-buffetaut2004_217-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"buffetaut2004"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-buffetaut2004-217"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-buffetaut2004-217" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 216;" id="mwCDY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCDc">[216]</span></a></sup></p>

<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwCDg"><a href="./File:Dino_bird_h.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwCDk"><img resource="./File:Dino_bird_h.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Dino_bird_h.jpg/220px-Dino_bird_h.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="999" data-file-height="629" data-file-type="bitmap" height="139" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Dino_bird_h.jpg/330px-Dino_bird_h.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Dino_bird_h.jpg/440px-Dino_bird_h.jpg 2x" id="mwCDo"/></a><figcaption id="mwCDs">Comparison between the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Air_sac" title="Air sac" id="mwCDw">air sacs</a> of an <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Abelisaur" title="Abelisaur" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCD0">abelisaur</a> and a bird</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwCD4">In saurischian dinosaurs, higher metabolisms were supported by the evolution of the avian respiratory system, characterized by an extensive system of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Air_sac" title="Air sac" id="mwCD8">air sacs</a> that extended the lungs and invaded many of the bones in the skeleton, making them hollow.<sup about="#mwt1024" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Sereno2008_218-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Sereno2008"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Sereno2008-218" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 217;" id="mwCEA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCEE">[217]</span></a></sup> Such respiratory systems, which may have appeared in the earliest saurischians,<sup about="#mwt1028" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-oconnor2009_219-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"oconnor2009"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-oconnor2009-219"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-oconnor2009-219" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 218;" id="mwCEI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCEM">[218]</span></a></sup> would have provided them with more oxygen compared to a mammal of similar size, while also having a larger resting <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tidal_volume" title="Tidal volume" id="mwCEQ">tidal volume</a> and requiring a lower breathing frequency, which would have allowed them to sustain higher activity levels.<sup about="#mwt1029" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sander2011_139-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sander2011"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-sander2011-139" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 138;" id="mwCEU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCEY">[138]</span></a></sup> The rapid airflow would also have been an effective cooling mechanism, which in conjunction with a lower metabolic rate<sup about="#mwt1033" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-eagle2011_220-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"eagle2011"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-eagle2011-220"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-eagle2011-220" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 219;" id="mwCEc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCEg">[219]</span></a></sup> would have prevented large sauropods from overheating. These traits may have enabled sauropods to grow quickly to gigantic sizes.<sup about="#mwt1038" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-wedel2003_221-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"wedel2003"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-wedel2003-221"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-wedel2003-221" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 220;" id="mwCEk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCEo">[220]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1042" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-perry2009_222-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"perry2009"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-perry2009-222"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-perry2009-222" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 221;" id="mwCEs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCEw">[221]</span></a></sup> Sauropods may also have benefitted from their size—their small surface area to volume ratio meant that they would have been able to thermoregulate more easily, a phenomenon termed <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gigantothermy" title="Gigantothermy" id="mwCE0">gigantothermy</a>.<sup about="#mwt1043" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sander2011_139-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sander2011"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-sander2011-139" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 138;" id="mwCE4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCE8">[138]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1047" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-alexander1998_223-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"alexander1998"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-alexander1998-223"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-alexander1998-223" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 222;" id="mwCFA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCFE">[222]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCFI">Like other reptiles, dinosaurs are primarily <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Uricotelic" title="Uricotelic" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCFM">uricotelic</a>, that is, their <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Kidney" title="Kidney" id="mwCFQ">kidneys</a> extract nitrogenous wastes from their bloodstream and excrete it as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Uric_acid" title="Uric acid" id="mwCFU">uric acid</a> instead of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Urea" title="Urea" id="mwCFY">urea</a> or <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ammonia" title="Ammonia" id="mwCFc">ammonia</a> via the ureters into the intestine. This would have helped them to conserve water.<sup about="#mwt1056" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-benson2018_199-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"benson2018"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-benson2018-199" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 198;" id="mwCFg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCFk">[198]</span></a></sup> In most living species, uric acid is excreted along with feces as a semisolid waste.<sup about="#mwt1060" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-tsahar2005_224-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"tsahar2005"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-tsahar2005-224"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-tsahar2005-224" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 223;" id="mwCFo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCFs">[223]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1064" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-skadhauge2003_225-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"skadhauge2003"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-skadhauge2003-225"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-skadhauge2003-225" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 224;" id="mwCFw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCF0">[224]</span></a></sup> However, at least some modern birds (such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Hummingbird" title="Hummingbird" id="mwCF4">hummingbirds</a>) can be facultatively <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ammonotelic" title="Ammonotelic" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCF8">ammonotelic</a>, excreting most of the nitrogenous wastes as ammonia.<sup about="#mwt1068" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-preest1997_226-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"preest1997"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-preest1997-226"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-preest1997-226" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 225;" id="mwCGA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCGE">[225]</span></a></sup> This material, as well as the output of the intestines, emerges from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cloaca" title="Cloaca" id="mwCGI">cloaca</a>.<sup about="#mwt1072" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-mora1965_227-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"mora1965"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-mora1965-227"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-mora1965-227" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 226;" id="mwCGM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCGQ">[226]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1076" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-packard1966_228-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"packard1966"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-packard1966-228"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-packard1966-228" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 227;" id="mwCGU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCGY">[227]</span></a></sup> In addition, many species regurgitate <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pellet_(ornithology)" title="Pellet (ornithology)" id="mwCGc">pellets</a>,<sup about="#mwt1080" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-balgooyen1971_229-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"balgooyen1971"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-balgooyen1971-229"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-balgooyen1971-229" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 228;" id="mwCGg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCGk">[228]</span></a></sup> and fossil pellets are known as early as the Jurassic from <i id="mwCGo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Anchiornis" title="Anchiornis" id="mwCGs">Anchiornis</a></i>.<sup about="#mwt1084" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-xu2018_230-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"xu2018"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-xu2018-230"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-xu2018-230" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 229;" id="mwCGw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCG0">[229]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCG4">The size and shape of the brain can be partly reconstructed based on the surrounding bones. In 1896, Marsh calculated ratios between brain weight and body weight of seven species of dinosaurs, showing that the brain of dinosaurs was proportionally smaller than in today's crocodiles, and that the brain of <i id="mwCG8">Stegosaurus</i> was smaller than in any living land vertebrate. This contributed to the widespread public notion of dinosaurs as being sluggish and extraordinarily stupid. Harry Jerison, in 1973, showed that proportionally smaller brains are expected at larger body sizes, and that brain size in dinosaurs was not smaller than expected when compared to living reptiles.<sup about="#mwt1087" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-russell1997_231-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"russell1997"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-russell1997-231" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 230;" id="mwCHA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCHE">[230]</span></a></sup> Later research showed that relative brain size progressively increased during the evolution of theropods, with the highest intelligence – comparable to that of modern birds – calculated for the troodontid <i id="mwCHI">Troodon</i>.<sup about="#mwt1088" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-brusatte2012_232-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"brusatte2012"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-brusatte2012-232" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 231;" id="mwCHM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCHQ">[231]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="23" id="mwCHU"><h2 id="Origin_of_birds">Origin of birds</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1089" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Origin of birds"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCHY"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1089" id="mwCHc">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Origin_of_birds" title="Origin of birds">Origin of birds</a></div>

<p id="mwCHg">The possibility that dinosaurs were the ancestors of birds was first suggested in 1868 by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thomas_Henry_Huxley" title="Thomas Henry Huxley" id="mwCHk">Thomas Henry Huxley</a>.<sup about="#mwt1105" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-huxley1868_233-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"huxley1868"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-huxley1868-233" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 232;" id="mwCHo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCHs">[232]</span></a></sup> After the work of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gerhard_Heilmann" title="Gerhard Heilmann" id="mwCHw">Gerhard Heilmann</a> in the early 20th century, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scientific_theory" title="Scientific theory" id="mwCH0">theory</a> of birds as dinosaur descendants was abandoned in favor of the idea of them being descendants of generalized <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thecodontia" title="Thecodontia" id="mwCH4">thecodonts</a>, with the key piece of evidence being the supposed lack of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Clavicle" title="Clavicle" id="mwCH8">clavicles</a> in dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt1106" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-heilmann_234-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"heilmann"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-heilmann-234" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 233;" id="mwCIA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCIE">[233]</span></a></sup> However, as later discoveries showed, clavicles (or a single fused <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Furcula" title="Furcula" id="mwCII">wishbone</a>, which derived from separate clavicles) were not actually absent;<sup about="#mwt1107" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-KP04_12-3" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"KP04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-KP04-12" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 11;" id="mwCIM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCIQ">[11]</span></a></sup> they had been found as early as 1924 in <i id="mwCIU"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Oviraptor" title="Oviraptor" id="mwCIY">Oviraptor</a></i>, but misidentified as an <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Interclavicle" title="Interclavicle" id="mwCIc">interclavicle</a>.<sup about="#mwt1108" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-HO24_235-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"HO24"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-HO24-235" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 234;" id="mwCIg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCIk">[234]</span></a></sup> In the 1970s, Ostrom revived the dinosaur–bird theory,<sup about="#mwt1109" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ostrom1973_236-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ostrom1973"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-ostrom1973-236" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 235;" id="mwCIo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCIs">[235]</span></a></sup> which gained momentum in the coming decades with the advent of cladistic analysis,<sup about="#mwt1110" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-gauthier1986_237-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"gauthier1986"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-gauthier1986-237" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 236;" id="mwCIw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCI0">[236]</span></a></sup> and a great increase in the discovery of small theropods and early birds.<sup about="#mwt1111" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-TRHJ00_30-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"TRHJ00"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-TRHJ00-30" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 29;" id="mwCI4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCI8">[29]</span></a></sup> Of particular note have been the fossils of the Jehol Biota, where a variety of theropods and early birds have been found, often with feathers of some type.<sup about="#mwt1112" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20161208_68-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NYT-20161208"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-NYT-20161208-68" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 67;" id="mwCJA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCJE">[67]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1113" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-KP04_12-4" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"KP04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-KP04-12" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 11;" id="mwCJI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCJM">[11]</span></a></sup> Birds share over a hundred distinct anatomical features with theropod dinosaurs, which are now generally accepted to have been their closest ancient relatives.<sup about="#mwt1114" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Mayretal2005_238-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Mayretal2005"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Mayretal2005-238" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 237;" id="mwCJQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCJU">[237]</span></a></sup> They are most closely allied with maniraptoran coelurosaurs.<sup about="#mwt1115" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-KP04_12-5" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"KP04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-KP04-12" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 11;" id="mwCJY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCJc">[11]</span></a></sup> A minority of scientists, most notably <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Alan_Feduccia" title="Alan Feduccia" id="mwCJg">Alan Feduccia</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Larry_Martin" title="Larry Martin" id="mwCJk">Larry Martin</a>, have proposed other evolutionary paths, including revised versions of Heilmann's basal archosaur proposal,<sup about="#mwt1116" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-martin2004_239-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"martin2004"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-martin2004-239" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 238;" id="mwCJo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCJs">[238]</span></a></sup> or that maniraptoran theropods are the ancestors of birds but themselves are not dinosaurs, only <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Convergent_evolution" title="Convergent evolution" id="mwCJw">convergent</a> with dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt1117" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-AF02_240-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"AF02"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-AF02-240" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 239;" id="mwCJ0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCJ4">[239]</span></a></sup></p>

<section data-mw-section-id="24" id="mwCJ8"><h3 id="Feathers">Feathers</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1118" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Feathered dinosaurs"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCKA"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1118" id="mwCKE">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Feathered_dinosaurs" title="Feathered dinosaurs" class="mw-redirect">Feathered dinosaurs</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwCKI"><a href="./File:Feathered_non-avian_Maniraptora.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwCKM"><img resource="./File:Feathered_non-avian_Maniraptora.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Feathered_non-avian_Maniraptora.jpg/220px-Feathered_non-avian_Maniraptora.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="2372" data-file-height="2444" data-file-type="bitmap" height="227" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Feathered_non-avian_Maniraptora.jpg/330px-Feathered_non-avian_Maniraptora.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Feathered_non-avian_Maniraptora.jpg/440px-Feathered_non-avian_Maniraptora.jpg 2x" id="mwCKQ"/></a><figcaption id="mwCKU">Various feathered non-avian dinosaurs, including <i id="mwCKY"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Archaeopteryx" title="Archaeopteryx" id="mwCKc">Archaeopteryx</a></i>, <i id="mwCKg"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Anchiornis" title="Anchiornis" id="mwCKk">Anchiornis</a></i>, <i id="mwCKo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Microraptor" title="Microraptor" id="mwCKs">Microraptor</a></i> and <i id="mwCKw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Zhenyuanlong" title="Zhenyuanlong" id="mwCK0">Zhenyuanlong</a></i></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwCK4">Feathers are one of the most recognizable characteristics of modern birds, and a trait that was also shared by several non-avian dinosaurs. Based on the current distribution of fossil evidence, it appears that feathers were an ancestral dinosaurian trait, though one that may have been selectively lost in some species.<sup about="#mwt1131" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-switeknature_241-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"switeknature"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-switeknature-241"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-switeknature-241" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 240;" id="mwCK8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCLA">[240]</span></a></sup> Direct fossil evidence of feathers or feather-like structures has been discovered in a diverse array of species in many non-avian dinosaur groups,<sup about="#mwt1132" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20161208_68-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"NYT-20161208"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-NYT-20161208-68" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 67;" id="mwCLE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCLI">[67]</span></a></sup> both among saurischians and ornithischians.
