Simple, branched, feather-like structures are known from <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Heterodontosauridae" title="Heterodontosauridae" id="mwCLM">heterodontosaurids</a>, primitive <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Neornithischia" title="Neornithischia" id="mwCLQ">neornithischians</a>,<sup about="#mwt1136" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Godefroit2014_242-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Godefroit2014"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Godefroit2014-242"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Godefroit2014-242" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 241;" id="mwCLU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCLY">[241]</span></a></sup> and theropods,<sup about="#mwt1137" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Xuetal2004_243-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Xuetal2004"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Xuetal2004-243" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 242;" id="mwCLc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCLg">[242]</span></a></sup> and primitive ceratopsians. Evidence for true, vaned feathers similar to the flight feathers of modern birds has been found only in the theropod subgroup Maniraptora, which includes oviraptorosaurs, troodontids, dromaeosaurids, and birds.<sup about="#mwt1138" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-KP04_12-6" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"KP04"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-KP04-12" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 11;" id="mwCLk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCLo">[11]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1139" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-GC06_244-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"GC06"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-GC06-244" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 243;" id="mwCLs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCLw">[243]</span></a></sup> Feather-like structures known as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Pterosaur#Pycnofibers" title="Pterosaur" id="mwCL0">pycnofibres</a> have also been found in pterosaurs.<sup about="#mwt1143" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-kellneretal2009_245-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"kellneretal2009"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-kellneretal2009-245"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-kellneretal2009-245" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 244;" id="mwCL4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCL8">[244]</span></a></sup></p> 

<p id="mwCMA">However, researchers do not agree regarding whether these structures share a common origin between lineages (i.e., they are <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Homology_(biology)" title="Homology (biology)" id="mwCME">homologous</a>),<sup about="#mwt1158" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-mayr2016_246-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"mayr2016"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-mayr2016-246"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-mayr2016-246" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 245;" id="mwCMI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCMM">[245]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1159" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-benton2019_247-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"benton2019"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-benton2019-247" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 246;" id="mwCMQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCMU">[246]</span></a></sup> or if they were the result of widespread experimentation with skin coverings among ornithodirans.<sup about="#mwt1163" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-barrett2015_248-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"barrett2015"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-barrett2015-248"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-barrett2015-248" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 247;" id="mwCMY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCMc">[247]</span></a></sup> If the former is the case, filaments may have been common in the ornithodiran lineage and evolved before the appearance of dinosaurs themselves.<sup about="#mwt1164" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-switeknature_241-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"switeknature"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-switeknature-241" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 240;" id="mwCMg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCMk">[240]</span></a></sup> Research into the genetics of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./American_alligator" title="American alligator" id="mwCMo">American alligators</a> has revealed that crocodylian <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Scute" title="Scute" id="mwCMs">scutes</a> do possess feather-keratins during embryonic development, but these keratins are not expressed by the animals before hatching.<sup about="#mwt1168" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-AlibL2006_249-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"AlibL2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-AlibL2006-249"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-AlibL2006-249" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 248;" id="mwCMw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCM0">[248]</span></a></sup> The description of feathered dinosaurs has not been without controversy in general; perhaps the most vocal critics have been Alan Feduccia and Theagarten Lingham-Soliar, who have proposed that some purported feather-like fossils are the result of the decomposition of collagenous fiber that underlaid the dinosaurs' skin,<sup about="#mwt1169" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-TLS03_250-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"TLS03"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-TLS03-250" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 249;" id="mwCM4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCM8">[249]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1170" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-FLH05_251-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"FLH05"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-FLH05-251" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 250;" id="mwCNA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCNE">[250]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1171" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-LSFX07_252-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"LSFX07"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-LSFX07-252" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 251;" id="mwCNI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCNM">[251]</span></a></sup> and that maniraptoran dinosaurs with vaned feathers were not actually dinosaurs, but convergent with dinosaurs.<sup about="#mwt1172" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-AF02_240-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"AF02"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-AF02-240" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 239;" id="mwCNQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCNU">[239]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1173" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-FLH05_251-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"FLH05"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-FLH05-251" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 250;" id="mwCNY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCNc">[250]</span></a></sup> However, their views have for the most part not been accepted by other researchers, to the point that the scientific nature of Feduccia's proposals has been questioned.<sup about="#mwt1174" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Prum2003_253-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Prum2003"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Prum2003-253" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 252;" id="mwCNg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCNk">[252]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCNo"><i id="mwCNs"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Archaeopteryx" title="Archaeopteryx" id="mwCNw">Archaeopteryx</a></i> was the first fossil found that revealed a potential connection between dinosaurs and birds. It is considered a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Transitional_fossil" title="Transitional fossil" id="mwCN0">transitional fossil</a>, in that it displays features of both groups. Brought to light just two years after <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Charles_Darwin" title="Charles Darwin" id="mwCN4">Charles Darwin</a>'s seminal <i id="mwCN8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./On_the_Origin_of_Species" title="On the Origin of Species" id="mwCOA">On the Origin of Species</a></i> (1859), its discovery spurred the nascent debate between proponents of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Evolutionary_biology" title="Evolutionary biology" id="mwCOE">evolutionary biology</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Creationism" title="Creationism" id="mwCOI">creationism</a>. This early bird is so dinosaur-like that, without a clear impression of feathers in the surrounding rock, at least one specimen was mistaken for the small theropod <i id="mwCOM"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Compsognathus" title="Compsognathus" id="mwCOQ">Compsognathus</a></i>.<sup about="#mwt1178" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-PW88_254-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"PW88"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-PW88-254" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 253;" id="mwCOU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCOY">[253]</span></a></sup> Since the 1990s, a number of additional feathered dinosaurs have been found, providing even stronger evidence of the close relationship between dinosaurs and modern birds. Many of these specimens were unearthed in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lagerstätten" title="Lagerstätten" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCOc">lagerstätten</a> of the Jehol Biota.<sup about="#mwt1182" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-benton2019_247-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"benton2019"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-benton2019-247"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-benton2019-247" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 246;" id="mwCOg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCOk">[246]</span></a></sup> If feather-like structures were indeed widely present among non-avian dinosaurs, the lack of abundant fossil evidence for them may be due to the fact that delicate features like skin and feathers are seldom preserved by fossilization and thus often absent from the fossil record.<sup about="#mwt1186" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Schweitzeretal1999_255-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Schweitzeretal1999"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Schweitzeretal1999-255"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Schweitzeretal1999-255" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 254;" id="mwCOo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCOs">[254]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="25" id="mwCOw"><h3 id="Skeleton">Skeleton</h3>
<p id="mwCO0">Because feathers are often associated with birds, feathered dinosaurs are often touted as the missing link between birds and dinosaurs. However, the multiple skeletal features also shared by the two groups represent another important line of evidence for paleontologists. Areas of the skeleton with important similarities include the neck, pubis, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Wrist" title="Wrist" id="mwCO4">wrist</a> (semi-lunate <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carpal" title="Carpal" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCO8">carpal</a>), arm and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shoulder_girdle" title="Shoulder girdle" id="mwCPA">pectoral girdle</a>, furcula (wishbone), and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Keel_(bird_anatomy)" title="Keel (bird anatomy)" id="mwCPE">breast bone</a>. Comparison of bird and dinosaur skeletons through cladistic analysis strengthens the case for the link.<sup about="#mwt1191" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-archaeopteryxucmp_256-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"archaeopteryxucmp"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-archaeopteryxucmp-256"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-archaeopteryxucmp-256" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 255;" id="mwCPI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCPM">[255]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="26" id="mwCPQ"><h3 id="Soft_anatomy">Soft anatomy</h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwCPU"><a href="./File:Pneumatopores_on_the_left_ilium_of_the_theropod_Aerosteon_riocoloradensis.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwCPY"><img resource="./File:Pneumatopores_on_the_left_ilium_of_the_theropod_Aerosteon_riocoloradensis.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Pneumatopores_on_the_left_ilium_of_the_theropod_Aerosteon_riocoloradensis.jpg/220px-Pneumatopores_on_the_left_ilium_of_the_theropod_Aerosteon_riocoloradensis.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1876" data-file-height="2342" data-file-type="bitmap" height="275" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Pneumatopores_on_the_left_ilium_of_the_theropod_Aerosteon_riocoloradensis.jpg/330px-Pneumatopores_on_the_left_ilium_of_the_theropod_Aerosteon_riocoloradensis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Pneumatopores_on_the_left_ilium_of_the_theropod_Aerosteon_riocoloradensis.jpg/440px-Pneumatopores_on_the_left_ilium_of_the_theropod_Aerosteon_riocoloradensis.jpg 2x" id="mwCPc"/></a><figcaption id="mwCPg">Pneumatopores on the left <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ilium_(bone)" title="Ilium (bone)" id="mwCPk">ilium</a> of <i id="mwCPo"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aerosteon" title="Aerosteon" id="mwCPs">Aerosteon riocoloradensis</a></i></figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwCPw">Large meat-eating dinosaurs had a complex system of air sacs similar to those found in modern birds, according to a 2005 investigation led by Patrick M. O'Connor. The lungs of theropod dinosaurs (carnivores that walked on two legs and had bird-like feet) likely pumped air into hollow sacs in their skeletons, as is the case in birds. "What was once formally considered unique to birds was present in some form in the ancestors of birds", O'Connor said.<sup about="#mwt1196" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-OConnorClaessens2005_257-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"OConnorClaessens2005"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-OConnorClaessens2005-257" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 256;" id="mwCP0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCP4">[256]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1201" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-258" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-258"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-258" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 257;" id="mwCP8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCQA">[257]</span></a></sup> In 2008, scientists described <i id="mwCQE"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aerosteon" title="Aerosteon" id="mwCQI">Aerosteon riocoloradensis</a></i>, the skeleton of which supplies the strongest evidence to date of a dinosaur with a bird-like breathing system. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./CT_scan" title="CT scan" id="mwCQM">CT scanning</a> of <i id="mwCQQ">Aerosteon'</i>s fossil bones revealed evidence for the existence of air sacs within the animal's body cavity.<sup about="#mwt1202" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Sereno2008_218-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Sereno2008"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Sereno2008-218" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 217;" id="mwCQU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCQY">[217]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1203" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-newswise2_259-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"newswise2"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-newswise2-259" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 258;" id="mwCQc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCQg">[258]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="27" id="mwCQk"><h3 id="Behavioral_evidence">Behavioral evidence</h3>
<p id="mwCQo">Fossils of the troodonts <i id="mwCQs"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mei_long" title="Mei long" id="mwCQw">Mei</a></i> and <i id="mwCQ0"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sinornithoides" title="Sinornithoides" id="mwCQ4">Sinornithoides</a></i> demonstrate that some dinosaurs slept with their heads tucked under their arms.<sup about="#mwt1207" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-XUNorell2004_260-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"XUNorell2004"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-XUNorell2004-260" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 259;" id="mwCQ8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCRA">[259]</span></a></sup> This behavior, which may have helped to keep the head warm, is also characteristic of modern birds. Several <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deinonychosauria" title="Deinonychosauria" id="mwCRE">deinonychosaur</a> and oviraptorosaur specimens have also been found preserved on top of their nests, likely brooding in a bird-like manner.<sup about="#mwt1211" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-norell1995_261-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"norell1995"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-norell1995-261"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-norell1995-261" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 260;" id="mwCRI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCRM">[260]</span></a></sup> The ratio between egg volume and body mass of adults among these dinosaurs suggest that the eggs were primarily brooded by the male, and that the young were highly precocial, similar to many modern ground-dwelling birds.<sup about="#mwt1215" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-Varricchioetal2008_262-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"Varricchioetal2008"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-Varricchioetal2008-262"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-Varricchioetal2008-262" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 261;" id="mwCRQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCRU">[261]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCRY">Some dinosaurs are known to have used <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gizzard" title="Gizzard" id="mwCRc">gizzard</a> stones like modern birds. These stones are swallowed by animals to aid digestion and break down food and hard fibers once they enter the stomach. When found in association with fossils, gizzard stones are called gastroliths.<sup about="#mwt1217" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-wings2007_263-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"wings2007"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-wings2007-263" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 262;" id="mwCRg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCRk">[262]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="28" id="mwCRo"><h2 id="Extinction_of_major_groups">Extinction of major groups</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1218" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCRs"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1218" id="mwCRw">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cretaceous–Paleogene_extinction_event" title="Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event">Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event</a></div>
<p id="mwCR0">All non-avian dinosaurs and most lineages of birds<sup about="#mwt1233" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-longrich2011_264-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"longrich2011"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-longrich2011-264"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-longrich2011-264" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 263;" id="mwCR4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCR8">[263]</span></a></sup> became extinct in a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Extinction_event" title="Extinction event" id="mwCSA">mass extinction event</a>, called the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cretaceous–Paleogene_extinction_event" title="Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event" id="mwCSE">Cretaceous–Paleogene (K-Pg) extinction event</a>, at the end of the Cretaceous period. Above the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cretaceous–Paleogene_boundary" title="Cretaceous–Paleogene boundary" id="mwCSI">Cretaceous–Paleogene boundary</a>, which has been dated to 66.038 ± 0.025 million years ago,<sup about="#mwt1237" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-renne2013_265-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"renne2013"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-renne2013-265"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-renne2013-265" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 264;" id="mwCSM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCSQ">[264]</span></a></sup> fossils of non-avian dinosaurs disappear abruptly; the absence of dinosaur fossils was historically used to assign rocks to the ensuing Cenozoic. The nature of the event that caused this mass extinction has been extensively studied since the 1970s, leading to the development of two mechanisms that are thought to have played major roles: an extraterrestrial <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Impact_event" title="Impact event" id="mwCSU">impact event</a> in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Yucatán_Peninsula" title="Yucatán Peninsula" id="mwCSY">Yucatán Peninsula</a>, along with <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Flood_basalt" title="Flood basalt" id="mwCSc">flood basalt</a> volcanism in India. However, the specific mechanisms of the extinction event and the extent of its effects on dinosaurs are still areas of ongoing research.<sup about="#mwt1241" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-brusatte2014_266-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"brusatte2014"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-brusatte2014-266"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-brusatte2014-266" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 265;" id="mwCSg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCSk">[265]</span></a></sup> Alongside dinosaurs, many other groups of animals became extinct: pterosaurs, marine reptiles such as mosasaurs and plesiosaurs, several groups of mammals, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ammonoidea" title="Ammonoidea" id="mwCSo">ammonites</a> (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Nautilus" title="Nautilus" id="mwCSs">nautilus</a>-like <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mollusca" title="Mollusca" id="mwCSw">mollusks</a>), <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Rudist" title="Rudist" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCS0">rudists</a> (<a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Reef" title="Reef" id="mwCS4">reef</a>-building <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bivalvia" title="Bivalvia" id="mwCS8">bivalves</a>), and various groups of marine plankton.<sup about="#mwt1242" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-macleod1997_267-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"macleod1997"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-macleod1997-267" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 266;" id="mwCTA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCTE">[266]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1243" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-archibald1982_268-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"archibald1982"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-archibald1982-268" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 267;" id="mwCTI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCTM">[267]</span></a></sup> In all, approximately 47% of genera and 76% of species on Earth became extinct during the K-Pg extinction event.<sup about="#mwt1247" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-jablonski1991_269-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"jablonski1991"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-jablonski1991-269"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-jablonski1991-269" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 268;" id="mwCTQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCTU">[268]</span></a></sup> The relatively large size of most dinosaurs and the low diversity of small-bodied dinosaur species at the end of the Cretaceous may have contributed to their extinction;<sup about="#mwt1251" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-270" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-270"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-270" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 269;" id="mwCTY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCTc">[269]</span></a></sup> the extinction of the bird lineages that did not survive may also have been caused by a dependence on forest habitats or a lack of adaptations to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Seed_predation" title="Seed predation" id="mwCTg">eating seeds</a> for survival.<sup about="#mwt1255" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-field2018_271-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"field2018"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-field2018-271"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-field2018-271" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 270;" id="mwCTk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCTo">[270]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1259" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-larson2016_272-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"larson2016"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-larson2016-272"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-larson2016-272" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 271;" id="mwCTs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCTw">[271]</span></a></sup></p>

<section data-mw-section-id="29" id="mwCT0"><h3 id="Pre-extinction_diversity">Pre-extinction diversity</h3>
<p id="mwCT4">Just before the K-Pg extinction event, the number of non-avian dinosaur species that existed globally has been estimated at between 628 and 1078.<sup about="#mwt1278" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-leloeuff2012_273-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"leloeuff2012"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-leloeuff2012-273"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-leloeuff2012-273" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 272;" id="mwCT8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCUA">[272]</span></a></sup> It remains uncertain whether the diversity of dinosaurs was in gradual decline before the K-Pg extinction event, or whether dinosaurs were actually thriving prior to the extinction. Rock formations from the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Maastrichtian" title="Maastrichtian" id="mwCUE">Maastrichtian</a> epoch, which directly preceded the extinction, have been found to have lower diversity than the preceding <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Campanian" title="Campanian" id="mwCUI">Campanian</a> epoch, which led to the prevailing view of a long-term decline in diversity.<sup about="#mwt1279" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-macleod1997_267-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"macleod1997"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-macleod1997-267" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 266;" id="mwCUM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCUQ">[266]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1283" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-archibald1982_268-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"archibald1982"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-archibald1982-268"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-archibald1982-268" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 267;" id="mwCUU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCUY">[267]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1287" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-carpenter1983_274-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"carpenter1983"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-carpenter1983-274"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-carpenter1983-274" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 273;" id="mwCUc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCUg">[273]</span></a></sup> However, these comparisons did not account either for varying preservation potential between rock units or for different extents of exploration and excavation.<sup about="#mwt1288" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-brusatte2014_266-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"brusatte2014"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-brusatte2014-266" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 265;" id="mwCUk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCUo">[265]</span></a></sup> In 1984, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Dale_Russell" title="Dale Russell" id="mwCUs">Dale Russell</a> carried out an analysis to account for these biases, and found no evidence of a decline;<sup about="#mwt1292" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-russell1984_275-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"russell1984"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-russell1984-275"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-russell1984-275" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 274;" id="mwCUw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCU0">[274]</span></a></sup> another analysis by David Fastovsky and colleagues in 2004 even showed that dinosaur diversity continually increased until the extinction,<sup about="#mwt1296" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-fastovsky2004_276-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"fastovsky2004"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-fastovsky2004-276"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-fastovsky2004-276" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 275;" id="mwCU4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCU8">[275]</span></a></sup> but this analysis has been rebutted.<sup about="#mwt1300" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sullivan2006_277-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sullivan2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-sullivan2006-277"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-sullivan2006-277" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 276;" id="mwCVA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCVE">[276]</span></a></sup> Since then, different approaches based on statistics and mathematical models have variously supported either a sudden extinction<sup about="#mwt1301" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-brusatte2014_266-2" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"brusatte2014"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-brusatte2014-266" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 265;" id="mwCVI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCVM">[265]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1302" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-leloeuff2012_273-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"leloeuff2012"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-leloeuff2012-273" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 272;" id="mwCVQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCVU">[272]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1306" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-chiarenza2019_278-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"chiarenza2019"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-chiarenza2019-278"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-chiarenza2019-278" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 277;" id="mwCVY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCVc">[277]</span></a></sup> or a gradual decline.<sup about="#mwt1310" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-lloyd2011_279-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"lloyd2011"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-lloyd2011-279"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-lloyd2011-279" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 278;" id="mwCVg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCVk">[278]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1314" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sakamoto2016_280-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sakamoto2016"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-sakamoto2016-280"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-sakamoto2016-280" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 279;" id="mwCVo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCVs">[279]</span></a></sup> End-Cretaceous trends in diversity may have varied between dinosaur lineages: it has been suggested that sauropods were not in decline, while ornithischians and theropods were in decline.<sup about="#mwt1318" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-barrett2009_281-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"barrett2009"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-barrett2009-281"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-barrett2009-281" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 280;" id="mwCVw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCV0">[280]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1322" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-upchurch2011_282-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"upchurch2011"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-upchurch2011-282"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-upchurch2011-282" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 281;" id="mwCV4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCV8">[281]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="30" id="mwCWA"><h3 id="Impact_event">Impact event</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1323" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Chicxulub crater"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCWE"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1323" id="mwCWI">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chicxulub_crater" title="Chicxulub crater">Chicxulub crater</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwCWM"><a href="./File:LWA_with_Walt.JPG" class="mw-file-description" id="mwCWQ"><img resource="./File:LWA_with_Walt.JPG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/LWA_with_Walt.JPG/170px-LWA_with_Walt.JPG" decoding="async" data-file-width="1566" data-file-height="2100" data-file-type="bitmap" height="228" width="170" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/LWA_with_Walt.JPG/255px-LWA_with_Walt.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/LWA_with_Walt.JPG/340px-LWA_with_Walt.JPG 2x" id="mwCWU"/></a><figcaption id="mwCWY"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Luis_Walter_Alvarez" title="Luis Walter Alvarez" id="mwCWc">Luis</a> (left) and his son <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Walter_Alvarez" title="Walter Alvarez" id="mwCWg">Walter Alvarez</a> (right) at the K-T Boundary in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gubbio" title="Gubbio" id="mwCWk">Gubbio</a>, Italy, 1981</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwCWo"><a href="./File:Chicxulub_radar_topography.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwCWs"><img resource="./File:Chicxulub_radar_topography.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Chicxulub_radar_topography.jpg/220px-Chicxulub_radar_topography.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="715" data-file-height="799" data-file-type="bitmap" height="246" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Chicxulub_radar_topography.jpg/330px-Chicxulub_radar_topography.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Chicxulub_radar_topography.jpg/440px-Chicxulub_radar_topography.jpg 2x" id="mwCWw"/></a><figcaption id="mwCW0">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chicxulub_Crater" title="Chicxulub Crater" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCW4">Chicxulub Crater</a> at the tip of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Yucatán_Peninsula" title="Yucatán Peninsula" id="mwCW8">Yucatán Peninsula</a>; the impactor that formed this crater may have caused the dinosaur <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Extinction" title="Extinction" id="mwCXA">extinction</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwCXE">The <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Alvarez_hypothesis" title="Alvarez hypothesis" id="mwCXI">bolide impact hypothesis</a>, first brought to wide attention in 1980 by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Walter_Alvarez" title="Walter Alvarez" id="mwCXM">Walter Alvarez</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Luis_Walter_Alvarez" title="Luis Walter Alvarez" id="mwCXQ">Luis Alvarez</a>, and colleagues, attributes the K-Pg extinction event to a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bolide" title="Bolide" id="mwCXU">bolide</a> (extraterrestrial projectile) impact.<sup about="#mwt1339" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-283" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-283"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-283" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 282;" id="mwCXY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCXc">[282]</span></a></sup> Alvarez and colleagues proposed that a sudden increase in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Iridium" title="Iridium" id="mwCXg">iridium</a> levels, recorded around the world in rock deposits at the Cretaceous–Paleogene boundary, was direct evidence of the impact.<sup about="#mwt1340" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-alvarez1980_284-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"alvarez1980"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-alvarez1980-284" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 283;" id="mwCXk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCXo">[283]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Shocked_quartz" title="Shocked quartz" id="mwCXs">Shocked quartz</a>, indicative of a strong shockwave emanating from an impact, was also found worldwide.<sup about="#mwt1344" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bohor1987_285-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bohor1987"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-bohor1987-285"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-bohor1987-285" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 284;" id="mwCXw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCX0">[284]</span></a></sup> The actual impact site remained elusive until a <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Chicxulub_crater" title="Chicxulub crater" id="mwCX4">crater</a> measuring <span about="#mwt1334" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"180"},"2":{"wt":"km"},"3":{"wt":"mi"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCX8">180</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1334"> </span><span about="#mwt1334">km (110</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1334"> </span><span about="#mwt1334">mi)</span> wide was discovered in the Yucatán Peninsula of southeastern <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mexico" title="Mexico" id="mwCYA">Mexico</a>, and was publicized in a 1991 paper by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Alan_R._Hildebrand" title="Alan R. Hildebrand" id="mwCYE">Alan Hildebrand</a> and colleagues.<sup about="#mwt1348" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hildebrand1991_286-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hildebrand1991"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-hildebrand1991-286"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-hildebrand1991-286" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 285;" id="mwCYI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCYM">[285]</span></a></sup> Now, the bulk of the evidence suggests that a bolide <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020198016" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" about="#mwt1335" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"5"},"2":{"wt":"to"},"3":{"wt":"15"},"4":{"wt":"km"},"5":{"wt":"mi"},"frac":{"wt":"2"},"abbr":{"wt":"off"},"sp":{"wt":"us"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCYQ">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style><span about="#mwt1335">5 to 15 kilometers (3 to </span><span class="frac" role="math" about="#mwt1335">9<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span><span typeof="mw:Entity">⁄</span><span class="den">2</span></span><span about="#mwt1335"> miles)</span> wide impacted the Yucatán Peninsula 66 million years ago, forming this crater<sup about="#mwt1349" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pope1996_287-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pope1996"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-pope1996-287" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 286;" id="mwCYU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCYY">[286]</span></a></sup> and creating a "kill mechanism" that triggered the extinction event.<sup about="#mwt1353" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-schulte2010_288-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"schulte2010"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-schulte2010-288"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-schulte2010-288" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 287;" id="mwCYc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCYg">[287]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1357" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-kring2007_289-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"kring2007"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-kring2007-289"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-kring2007-289" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 288;" id="mwCYk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCYo">[288]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1361" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-chiarenza2020_290-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"chiarenza2020"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-chiarenza2020-290"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-chiarenza2020-290" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 289;" id="mwCYs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCYw">[289]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCY0">Within hours, the Chicxulub impact would have created immediate effects such as earthquakes,<sup about="#mwt1376" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ivanov2005_291-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ivanov2005"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-ivanov2005-291"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-ivanov2005-291" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 290;" id="mwCY4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCY8">[290]</span></a></sup> tsunamis,<sup about="#mwt1380" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-matsui2002_292-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"matsui2002"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-matsui2002-292"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-matsui2002-292" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 291;" id="mwCZA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCZE">[291]</span></a></sup> and a global firestorm that likely killed unsheltered animals and started wildfires.<sup about="#mwt1384" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-robertson2004_293-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"robertson2004"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-robertson2004-293"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-robertson2004-293" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 292;" id="mwCZI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCZM">[292]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1388" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-robertson2013_294-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"robertson2013"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-robertson2013-294"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-robertson2013-294" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 293;" id="mwCZQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCZU">[293]</span></a></sup> However, it would also have had longer-term consequences for the environment. Within days, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sulphate" title="Sulphate" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCZY">sulphate</a> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Aerosol" title="Aerosol" id="mwCZc">aerosols</a> released from rocks at the impact site would have contributed to <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Acid_rain" title="Acid rain" id="mwCZg">acid rain</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Ocean_acidification" title="Ocean acidification" id="mwCZk">ocean acidification</a>.<sup about="#mwt1392" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-pope1997_295-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"pope1997"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-pope1997-295"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-pope1997-295" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 294;" id="mwCZo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCZs">[294]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1393" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ohno2014_296-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ohno2014"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-ohno2014-296" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 295;" id="mwCZw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCZ0">[295]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Soot" title="Soot" id="mwCZ4">Soot</a> aerosols are thought to have spread around the world over the ensuing months and years; they would have cooled the surface of the Earth by reflecting <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Thermal_radiation" title="Thermal radiation" id="mwCZ8">thermal radiation</a>, and greatly slowed <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Photosynthesis" title="Photosynthesis" id="mwCaA">photosynthesis</a> by blocking out sunlight, thus creating an <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Impact_winter" title="Impact winter" id="mwCaE">impact winter</a>.<sup about="#mwt1394" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-brusatte2014_266-3" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"brusatte2014"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-brusatte2014-266" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 265;" id="mwCaI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCaM">[265]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1398" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-kaiho2016_297-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"kaiho2016"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-kaiho2016-297"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-kaiho2016-297" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 296;" id="mwCaQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCaU">[296]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1402" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-lyons2020_298-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"lyons2020"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-lyons2020-298"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-lyons2020-298" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 297;" id="mwCaY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCac">[297]</span></a></sup> (This role was ascribed to sulphate aerosols until experiments demonstrated otherwise.<sup about="#mwt1406" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-ohno2014_296-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"ohno2014"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-ohno2014-296"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-ohno2014-296" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 295;" id="mwCag"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCak">[295]</span></a></sup>) The cessation of photosynthesis would have led to the collapse of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Food_web" title="Food web" id="mwCao">food webs</a> depending on leafy plants, which included all dinosaurs save for grain-eating birds.<sup about="#mwt1407" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-larson2016_272-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"larson2016"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-larson2016-272" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 271;" id="mwCas"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCaw">[271]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="31" id="mwCa0"><h3 id="Deccan_Traps">Deccan Traps</h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1408" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Deccan Traps"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCa4"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1408" id="mwCa8">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deccan_Traps" title="Deccan Traps">Deccan Traps</a></div> <!-- This section is linked from [[Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event]] -->

<p id="mwCbA">At the time of the K-Pg extinction, the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deccan_Traps" title="Deccan Traps" id="mwCbE">Deccan Traps</a> flood basalts of India were actively erupting. The eruptions can be separated into three phases around the K-Pg boundary, two prior to the boundary and one after. The second phase, which occurred very close to the boundary, would have extruded 70 to 80% of the volume of these eruptions in intermittent pulses that occurred around 100,000 years apart.<sup about="#mwt1425" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-chenet2009_299-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"chenet2009"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-chenet2009-299"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-chenet2009-299" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 298;" id="mwCbI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCbM">[298]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1429" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-schoene2019_300-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"schoene2019"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-schoene2019-300"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-schoene2019-300" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 299;" id="mwCbQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCbU">[299]</span></a></sup> <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Greenhouse_gases" title="Greenhouse gases" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCbY">Greenhouse gases</a> such as <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide" id="mwCbc">carbon dioxide</a> and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Sulphur_dioxide" title="Sulphur dioxide" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCbg">sulphur dioxide</a> would have been released by this volcanic activity,<sup about="#mwt1433" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-mclean1985_301-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"mclean1985"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-mclean1985-301"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-mclean1985-301" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 300;" id="mwCbk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCbo">[300]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1437" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-self2006_302-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"self2006"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-self2006-302"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-self2006-302" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 301;" id="mwCbs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCbw">[301]</span></a></sup> resulting in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Climate_change" title="Climate change" id="mwCb0">climate change</a> through temperature perturbations of roughly <span about="#mwt1420" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"3"},"2":{"wt":"C-change"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCb4">3</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1420"> </span><span about="#mwt1420">°C (5.4</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1420"> </span><span about="#mwt1420">°F)</span> but possibly as high as <span about="#mwt1421" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"7"},"2":{"wt":"C-change"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCb8">7</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1421"> </span><span about="#mwt1421">°C (13</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1421"> </span><span about="#mwt1421">°F)</span>.<sup about="#mwt1441" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-tobin2017_303-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"tobin2017"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-tobin2017-303"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-tobin2017-303" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 302;" id="mwCcA"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCcE">[302]</span></a></sup> Like the Chicxulub impact, the eruptions may also have released sulphate aerosols, which would have caused acid rain and global cooling.<sup about="#mwt1445" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-schmidt2016_304-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"schmidt2016"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-schmidt2016-304"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-schmidt2016-304" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 303;" id="mwCcI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCcM">[303]</span></a></sup> However, due to large error margins in the dating of the eruptions, the role of the Deccan Traps in the K-Pg extinction remains unclear.<sup about="#mwt1446" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-renne2013_265-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"renne2013"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-renne2013-265" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 264;" id="mwCcQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCcU">[264]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1447" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-brusatte2014_266-4" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"brusatte2014"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-brusatte2014-266" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 265;" id="mwCcY"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCcc">[265]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1448" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-hofman2000_305-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"hofman2000"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-hofman2000-305" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 304;" id="mwCcg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCck">[304]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCco">Before 2000, arguments that the Deccan Traps eruptions—as opposed to the Chicxulub impact—caused the extinction were usually linked to the view that the extinction was gradual. Prior to the discovery of the Chicxulub crater, the Deccan Traps were used to explain the global iridium layer;<sup about="#mwt1457" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-mclean1985_301-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"mclean1985"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-mclean1985-301" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 300;" id="mwCcs"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCcw">[300]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1461" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sahni1988_306-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sahni1988"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-sahni1988-306"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-sahni1988-306" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 305;" id="mwCc0"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCc4">[305]</span></a></sup> even after the crater's discovery, the impact was still thought to only have had a regional, not global, effect on the extinction event.<sup about="#mwt1465" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-glasby1996_307-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"glasby1996"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-glasby1996-307"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-glasby1996-307" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 306;" id="mwCc8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCdA">[306]</span></a></sup> In response, Luis Alvarez rejected volcanic activity as an explanation for the iridium layer and the extinction as a whole.<sup about="#mwt1469" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-alvarez1987_308-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"alvarez1987"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-alvarez1987-308"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-alvarez1987-308" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 307;" id="mwCdE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCdI">[307]</span></a></sup> Since then, however, most researchers have adopted a more moderate position, which identifies the Chicxulub impact as the primary progenitor of the extinction while also recognizing that the Deccan Traps may also have played a role. Walter Alvarez himself has acknowledged that the Deccan Traps and other ecological factors may have contributed to the extinctions in addition to the Chicxulub impact.<sup about="#mwt1470" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-alvarez1997_309-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"alvarez1997"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-alvarez1997-309" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 308;" id="mwCdM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCdQ">[308]</span></a></sup> Some estimates have placed the start of the second phase in the Deccan Traps eruptions within 50,000 years after the Chicxulub impact.<sup about="#mwt1474" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-renne2015_310-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"renne2015"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-renne2015-310"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-renne2015-310" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 309;" id="mwCdU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCdY">[309]</span></a></sup> Combined with mathematical modelling of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Seismic_wave" title="Seismic wave" id="mwCdc">seismic waves</a> that would have been generated by the impact, this has led to the suggestion that the Chicxulub impact may have triggered these eruptions by increasing the permeability of the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Mantle_plume" title="Mantle plume" id="mwCdg">mantle plume</a> underlying the Deccan Traps.<sup about="#mwt1478" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-richards2015_311-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"richards2015"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-richards2015-311"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-richards2015-311" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 310;" id="mwCdk"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCdo">[310]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1482" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-khazins2019_312-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"khazins2019"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-khazins2019-312"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-khazins2019-312" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 311;" id="mwCds"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCdw">[311]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCd0">Whether the Deccan Traps were a major cause of the extinction, on par with the Chicxulub impact, remains uncertain. Proponents consider the climatic impact of the sulphur dioxide released to have been on par with the Chicxulub impact, and also note the role of flood basalt volcanism in other mass extinctions like the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Permian-Triassic_extinction_event" title="Permian-Triassic extinction event" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCd4">Permian-Triassic extinction event</a>.<sup about="#mwt1491" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-archibald2010_313-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"archibald2010"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-archibald2010-313"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-archibald2010-313" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 312;" id="mwCd8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCeA">[312]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1495" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-courtillot2010_314-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"courtillot2010"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-courtillot2010-314"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-courtillot2010-314" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 313;" id="mwCeE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCeI">[313]</span></a></sup> They consider the Chicxulub impact to have worsened the ongoing climate change caused by the eruptions.<sup about="#mwt1499" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-keller2014_315-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"keller2014"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-keller2014-315"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-keller2014-315" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 314;" id="mwCeM"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCeQ">[314]</span></a></sup> Meanwhile, detractors point out the sudden nature of the extinction and that other pulses in Deccan Traps activity of comparable magnitude did not appear to have caused extinctions. They also contend that the causes of different mass extinctions should be assessed separately.<sup about="#mwt1503" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-schulte2010reply_316-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"schulte2010reply"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-schulte2010reply-316"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-schulte2010reply-316" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 315;" id="mwCeU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCeY">[315]</span></a></sup> In 2020, Alfio Chiarenza and colleagues suggested that the Deccan Traps may even have had the opposite effect: they suggested that the long-term warming caused by its carbon dioxide emissions may have dampened the impact winter from the Chicxulub impact.<sup about="#mwt1504" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-chiarenza2020_290-1" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"chiarenza2020"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-chiarenza2020-290" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 289;" id="mwCec"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCeg">[289]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="32" id="mwCek"><h3 id="Possible_Paleocene_survivors">Possible Paleocene survivors</h3>
<p id="mwCeo">Non-avian dinosaur remains have occasionally been found above the K-Pg boundary. In 2000, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Spencer_G._Lucas" title="Spencer G. Lucas" id="mwCes">Spencer Lucas</a> and colleagues reported the discovery of a single hadrosaur right femur in the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./San_Juan_Basin" title="San Juan Basin" id="mwCew">San Juan Basin</a> of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./New_Mexico" title="New Mexico" id="mwCe0">New Mexico</a>, and described it as evidence of Paleocene dinosaurs. The rock unit in which the bone was discovered has been dated to the early <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Paleocene" title="Paleocene" id="mwCe4">Paleocene</a> epoch, approximately 64.8 million years ago.<sup about="#mwt1513" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-fassett2011_317-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"fassett2011"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-fassett2011-317" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 316;" id="mwCe8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCfA">[316]</span></a></sup> If the bone was not <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Deposition_(geology)" title="Deposition (geology)" id="mwCfE">re-deposited</a> by weathering action, it would provide evidence that some dinosaur populations may have survived at least half a million years into the Cenozoic.<sup about="#mwt1514" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-fassett2009_318-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"fassett2009"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-fassett2009-318" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 317;" id="mwCfI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCfM">[317]</span></a></sup> Other evidence includes the presence of dinosaur remains in the Hell Creek Formation up to <span about="#mwt1512" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"convert","href":"./Template:Convert"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"1.3"},"2":{"wt":"m"},"3":{"wt":"ft"},"abbr":{"wt":"on"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCfQ">1.3</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1512"> </span><span about="#mwt1512">m (4.3</span><span typeof="mw:Entity" about="#mwt1512"> </span><span about="#mwt1512">ft)</span> above the Cretaceous–Paleogene boundary, representing 40,000 years of elapsed time. This has been used to support the view that the K-Pg extinction was gradual.<sup about="#mwt1515" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-sloan1986_319-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"sloan1986"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-sloan1986-319" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 318;" id="mwCfU"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCfY">[318]</span></a></sup> However, these supposed Paleocene dinosaurs are considered by many other researchers to be <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Reworked_fossil" title="Reworked fossil" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCfc">reworked</a>, that is, washed out of their original locations and then re-buried in younger sediments.<sup about="#mwt1519" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-lucas2009_320-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"lucas2009"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-lucas2009-320"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-lucas2009-320" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 319;" id="mwCfg"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCfk">[319]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1523" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-renne2012_321-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"renne2012"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-renne2012-321"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-renne2012-321" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 320;" id="mwCfo"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCfs">[320]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1527" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-lofgren1990_322-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"lofgren1990"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-lofgren1990-322"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-lofgren1990-322" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 321;" id="mwCfw"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCf0">[321]</span></a></sup> The age estimates have also been considered unreliable.<sup about="#mwt1531" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-koenig2012_323-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"koenig2012"},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-koenig2012-323"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-koenig2012-323" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 322;" id="mwCf4"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCf8">[322]</span></a></sup></p>

</section></section><section data-mw-section-id="33" id="mwCgA"><h2 id="Cultural_depictions">Cultural depictions</h2>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" about="#mwt1532" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Main","href":"./Template:Main"},"params":{"1":{"wt":"Cultural depictions of dinosaurs"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCgE"/><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" about="#mwt1532" id="mwCgI">Main article: <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Cultural_depictions_of_dinosaurs" title="Cultural depictions of dinosaurs">Cultural depictions of dinosaurs</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwCgM"><a href="./File:Iguanodon_Crystal_Palace.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwCgQ"><img resource="./File:Iguanodon_Crystal_Palace.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Iguanodon_Crystal_Palace.jpg/220px-Iguanodon_Crystal_Palace.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="704" data-file-type="bitmap" height="151" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Iguanodon_Crystal_Palace.jpg/330px-Iguanodon_Crystal_Palace.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Iguanodon_Crystal_Palace.jpg/440px-Iguanodon_Crystal_Palace.jpg 2x" id="mwCgU"/></a><figcaption id="mwCgY">Outdated <i id="mwCgc">Iguanodon</i> statues created by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Benjamin_Waterhouse_Hawkins" title="Benjamin Waterhouse Hawkins" id="mwCgg">Benjamin Waterhouse Hawkins</a> for the <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crystal_Palace_Park" title="Crystal Palace Park" id="mwCgk">Crystal Palace Park</a> in 1853</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb" id="mwCgo"><a href="./File:Ghost_of_Slumber_Mountain.jpg" class="mw-file-description" id="mwCgs"><img resource="./File:Ghost_of_Slumber_Mountain.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Ghost_of_Slumber_Mountain.jpg/220px-Ghost_of_Slumber_Mountain.jpg" decoding="async" data-file-width="425" data-file-height="304" data-file-type="bitmap" height="157" width="220" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Ghost_of_Slumber_Mountain.jpg/330px-Ghost_of_Slumber_Mountain.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c9/Ghost_of_Slumber_Mountain.jpg 2x" id="mwCgw"/></a><figcaption id="mwCg0">The battles that may have occurred between <i id="mwCg4"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Tyrannosaurus" title="Tyrannosaurus" id="mwCg8">Tyrannosaurus</a></i> and <i id="mwChA"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Triceratops" title="Triceratops" id="mwChE">Triceratops</a></i> are a recurring theme in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Popular_science" title="Popular science" id="mwChI">popular science</a> and depictions of dinosaurs in culture, shown here in <i id="mwChM"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./The_Ghost_of_Slumber_Mountain" title="The Ghost of Slumber Mountain" id="mwChQ">The Ghost of Slumber Mountain</a></i> (1918)</figcaption></figure>
<p id="mwChU">By human standards, dinosaurs were creatures of fantastic appearance and often enormous size. As such, they have captured the popular imagination and become an enduring part of human culture. The entry of the word "dinosaur" into the common <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Vernacular" title="Vernacular" id="mwChY">vernacular</a> reflects the animals' cultural importance: in English, "dinosaur" is commonly used to describe anything that is impractically large, obsolete, or bound for extinction.<sup about="#mwt1536" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-m-w_324-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"m-w"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-m-w-324" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 323;" id="mwChc"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwChg">[323]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwChk">Public enthusiasm for dinosaurs first developed in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Victorian_era" title="Victorian era" id="mwCho">Victorian</a> England, where in 1854, three decades after the first scientific descriptions of dinosaur remains, a menagerie of lifelike <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crystal_Palace_dinosaurs" title="Crystal Palace dinosaurs" class="mw-redirect" id="mwChs">dinosaur sculptures</a> was unveiled in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./London" title="London" id="mwChw">London</a>'s <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Crystal_Palace_Park" title="Crystal Palace Park" id="mwCh0">Crystal Palace Park</a>. The Crystal Palace dinosaurs proved so popular that a strong market in smaller replicas soon developed. In subsequent decades, dinosaur exhibits opened at parks and <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Natural_history_museum" title="Natural history museum" id="mwCh4">museums</a> around the world, ensuring that successive generations would be introduced to the animals in an immersive and exciting way.<sup about="#mwt1539" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-torrens1993_325-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"torrens1993"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-torrens1993-325" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 324;" id="mwCh8"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCiA">[324]</span></a></sup> The enduring popularity of dinosaurs, in its turn, has resulted in significant public funding for dinosaur science, and has frequently spurred new discoveries. In the United States, for example, the competition between museums for public attention led directly to the Bone Wars of the 1880s and 1890s, during which a pair of feuding paleontologists made enormous scientific contributions.<sup about="#mwt1540" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-breithaupt1997_326-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"breithaupt1997"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-breithaupt1997-326" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 325;" id="mwCiE"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCiI">[325]</span></a></sup></p>

<p id="mwCiM">The popular preoccupation with dinosaurs has ensured their appearance in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Literature" title="Literature" id="mwCiQ">literature</a>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Film" title="Film" id="mwCiU">film</a>, and other <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Media_(communication)" title="Media (communication)" id="mwCiY">media</a>. Beginning in 1852 with a passing mention in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens" id="mwCic">Charles Dickens</a><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;" about="#mwt1544" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"&apos;","href":"./Template:&apos;"},"params":{},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCig"><span typeof="mw:Entity">'</span></span> <i id="mwCik"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Bleak_House" title="Bleak House" id="mwCio">Bleak House</a></i>,<sup about="#mwt1545" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-bleakhouse_327-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"bleakhouse"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-bleakhouse-327" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 326;" id="mwCis"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCiw">[326]</span></a></sup> dinosaurs have been featured in large numbers of <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Fiction" title="Fiction" id="mwCi0">fictional</a> works. <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jules_Verne" title="Jules Verne" id="mwCi4">Jules Verne</a>'s 1864 novel <i id="mwCi8"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Journey_to_the_Center_of_the_Earth" title="Journey to the Center of the Earth" id="mwCjA">Journey to the Center of the Earth</a></i>, <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Arthur_Conan_Doyle" title="Arthur Conan Doyle" id="mwCjE">Sir Arthur Conan Doyle</a>'s 1912 book <i id="mwCjI"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./The_Lost_World_(Doyle_novel)" title="The Lost World (Doyle novel)" id="mwCjM">The Lost World</a></i>, the 1914 animated film <i id="mwCjQ"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Gertie_the_Dinosaur" title="Gertie the Dinosaur" id="mwCjU">Gertie the Dinosaur</a></i> (featuring the first animated dinosaur), the iconic 1933 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Motion_picture" title="Motion picture" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCjY">film</a> <i id="mwCjc"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./King_Kong_(1933_film)" title="King Kong (1933 film)" id="mwCjg">King Kong</a></i>, the 1954 <i id="mwCjk"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Godzilla_(1954_film)" title="Godzilla (1954 film)" id="mwCjo">Godzilla</a></i> and its many sequels, the best-selling 1990 novel <i id="mwCjs"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jurassic_Park_(novel)" title="Jurassic Park (novel)" id="mwCjw">Jurassic Park</a></i> by <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Michael_Crichton" title="Michael Crichton" id="mwCj0">Michael Crichton</a> and its 1993 <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Jurassic_Park_(film)" title="Jurassic Park (film)" id="mwCj4">film adaptation</a> are just a few notable examples of dinosaur appearances in fiction. Authors of general-interest <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Non-fiction" title="Non-fiction" id="mwCj8">non-fiction</a> works about dinosaurs, including some prominent paleontologists, have often sought to use the animals as a way to educate readers about science in general. Dinosaurs are ubiquitous in <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Advertising" title="Advertising" id="mwCkA">advertising</a>; numerous <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Company_(law)" title="Company (law)" class="mw-redirect" id="mwCkE">companies</a> have referenced dinosaurs in printed or televised advertisements, either in order to sell their own products or in order to characterize their rivals as slow-moving, dim-witted, or obsolete.<sup about="#mwt1546" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-DFGlut1997_328-0" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{"name":"DFGlut1997"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-DFGlut1997-328" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 327;" id="mwCkI"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCkM">[327]</span></a></sup><sup about="#mwt1550" class="mw-ref reference" id="cite_ref-329" rel="dc:references" typeof="mw:Extension/ref" data-mw='{"name":"ref","attrs":{},"body":{"id":"mw-reference-text-cite_note-329"}}'><a href="./Dinosaur#cite_note-329" style="counter-reset: mw-Ref 328;" id="mwCkQ"><span class="mw-reflink-text" id="mwCkU">[328]</span></a></sup></p>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="34" id="mwCkY"><h2 id="See_also">See also</h2>

<li id="mwCkw"><a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./Lists_of_dinosaur-bearing_stratigraphic_units" title="Lists of dinosaur-bearing stratigraphic units" id="mwCk0">Lists of dinosaur-bearing stratigraphic units</a></li>

<div style="clear:both;" about="#mwt1551" typeof="mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"Clear","href":"./Template:Clear"},"params":{},"i":0}}]}' id="mwClY"></div>

</section><section data-mw-section-id="35" id="mwClc"><h2 id="Further_reading">Further reading</h2>

<li id="mwCmQ"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1133582631" about="#mwt1566" typeof="mw:Extension/templatestyles mw:Transclusion" data-mw='{"parts":[{"template":{"target":{"wt":"cite book ","href":"./Template:Cite_book"},"params":{"author":{"wt":"Stewart, Tabori &amp; Chang"},"year":{"wt":"1997"},"title":{"wt":"The Humongous Book of Dinosaurs"},"location":{"wt":"New York"},"publisher":{"wt":"[[Abrams Books|Stewart, Tabori &amp; Chang]]"},"isbn":{"wt":"978-1-55670-596-0"},"lccn":{"wt":"97000398"},"oclc":{"wt":"1037269801"},"title-link":{"wt":"The Humongous Book of Dinosaurs"}},"i":0}}]}' id="mwCmU"/><cite id="CITEREFStewart,_Tabori_&amp;_Chang1997" class="citation book cs1" about="#mwt1566">Stewart, Tabori &amp; Chang (1997). <a rel="mw:WikiLink" href="./The_Humongous_Book_of_Dinosaurs" title="The Humongous Book of Dinosaurs"><i>The Humongous Book of Dinosaurs</i></a>.
